Praefatio.	Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After completing for you, my sons, this book, which is the final work on medical science with its complement, and having reached the end of it through his expositions and explanations, I saw that it was necessary to complete it for you with this treatise, which is part of practical application, that is, surgery by hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since practical work with the hands has been abandoned in our region and our time: until perhaps its knowledge is lost, and its traces are completely erased; and there remain only small descriptions in old books, which have been altered by hand: and these have suffered errors and uncertainty, until their intentions are misunderstood and their meaning distorted; I saw that it was necessary to revive it with the ordering of this treatise on practical application according to the way of exposition, explanation, and abridgment: and to come with descriptions of the forms of cautery instruments and other tools for the work: which is done by adding explanations and detailing what is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	The reason why a good practitioner of this skill with his own hands is not found in our time is: because the art of medicine is long, and its author must be trained beforehand in the science of anatomy, as described by Galen, until he knows the helpful parts of members, and their shapes, and their joining together, and separation, and has knowledge of bones, nerves, sinews, and their number, and their course, and the pulsating and quiet veins, and the places where they exit.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And for this reason Hippocrates said that the name is great with a name but little with a deed, and especially in the art of the hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have indeed spoken of this in the introduction to this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Since those who are not knowledgeable about what we have said regarding anatomy cannot be evacuated without already falling into error, by which people are killed: just as I have seen many of them who are taught in this science and boast themselves about it without knowledge and without experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	What happened is because I saw a foolish physician cut away a scrofulous abscess on a woman's neck and he cut some arteries in her neck: therefore the woman's blood flowed until she fell down dead between his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I saw another physician who presumptuously attempted to remove a stone from an elderly man, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	It therefore happened to him that he removed it along with a piece of the bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Therefore, the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And for my part, I had already been called to remove it; and upon seeing the size of the stone and condition of the patient, I knew he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I saw another physician who was taking a fee from one of the Dukes of our land for his services: and it happened that a black eunuch who belonged to him suffered a broken leg near the heel; and with great haste, due to his ignorance, the doctor bound up the fracture over the wound with bandages and with strong splints that did not permit any discharge from the injury.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he discharged him according to his desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Afterwards he let him go a few days later and instructed him not to loosen the bandages; and so he stood still until his leg and foot were abscessed, and it came about that he was lost.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was called to him; I hurried to release the ligament; and tranquility followed, and he escaped from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	However, the corruption was already established in the limb; and I could not restrain it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Therefore, the corruption ceased to walk about in the limb until it perished.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another physician who pierced a cancerous abscess; and it became ulcerated after days until its evil was magnified before its owner.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	This is because when it is a pure cancer from melancholy humour, then one ought not to approach it with iron at all unless it be in a limb that can bear having the whole of it cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And for this reason, o sons, it is necessary for you to know that operations with the hand are divided into two divisions, namely, an operation associated with a cure and an operation which involves danger in many ways.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have aroused you already in every place of this book where an operation comes up which involves fear and dread.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Why it is necessary for you to beware of this and put it aside so that fools do not find a way to talk about it and bring dishonour upon it.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Take therefore the measure with care and protection, and your patients with ease and firmness, and take the better way leading by the grace of God to salvation and commendable succession; and put aside severe illnesses difficult of cure, and remove from yourselves that which makes you afraid so that hesitation does not enter into your faith and your advantage.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	It is indeed more beneficial for your glory, and higher status in this world, and ultimately for your wealth.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	Galen has indeed said in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not treat an evil disease, lest you be called bad doctors.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	I have now divided this Treatise into three Chapters.
Capitulum primum.	Chapter one.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	On cauterization with fire and acute medicinal cauterization, categorized by part of the body from head to toe, along with the shapes of instruments and tools for cauterization; and all that is necessary for its execution.
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter two.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	On incision, perforation, bloodletting and swelling; on the extraction of arrows and similar objects; all categorized by part of the body from head to toe, along with the shapes of instruments and tools.
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter three.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	On the restoration of bones, their dislocations and treatment for torsion; all categorized by part of the body from head to toe, along with the shapes of instruments and tools.
Soli Deo Gloria.	Glory be to God alone.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	Albucasis's Book of Surgery.
Pars I.	Part one.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	On the harm of cauterization; on those of complexions for whom it is suitable and at what time; whether with an iron or gold tool.
Caput I.	Head one.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before we turn to the actual description of how this is done, it is necessary for me to explain about the harm and benefit of cauterization; on those of complexions for whom it is suitable and at what time; whether with an iron or gold tool.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say, therefore, that discourse on the quality of cauterization and its harmful effects is extensive, subtle, scientific, and an esoteric secret.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	There also spoke a multitude of sages about it, and they disagreed among themselves; as for me, I have had enough from their discourses, fearing the length.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say, therefore, that cauterization is generally suitable for all constitutions, whether they are with or without matter; excepting two constitutions, which are the warm constitution without matter and the dry one without it.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	However, they disagreed about the warm-moist and dry-moist constitutions.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	For some said that cauterization is beneficial for it.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And others said the opposite of this, namely that cauterization is not suitable for an illness caused by heat and dryness; since nature's fire is heat, it is unsuitable to heal a hot-dry illness with hot-dry means.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who said the opposite stated that cauterization is beneficial for every hot-dry illness occurring in human bodies; since when you compare a human body and its humours to a fiery constitution, you find the former cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I say according to his discourse, for experience has already proven this to me several times.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	However, one ought not to apply it unless he is already proven and practiced in the final exercise of cauterization; has understood the variety of human constitutions, recognized the nature of illnesses within themselves, their causes, incidents, and duration.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	Among other constitutions, there is no need to fear for you; especially in regards to cold and moist illnesses.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For indeed all physicians have already agreed upon them; and they did not dissent from benefiting with cauterization on these.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And know, my sons, that from the secret of curing with the cautery by fire, and its superiority over the cautery with burning medicine is evident; for fire is simple, whose action does not reach unless to the member which is cauterized: and it does not harm another member joined to it, except with a small injury.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	However, the action of burning medicine reaches that which extends from members: and perhaps it causes to happen in the member a difficult-to-heal illness, and perhaps it kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	But fire, because of its subtlety and goodness of substance, does not do this unless it is excessive.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Indeed, this has become known to us through experience because of the length of our service and study with the art, and our position above truths of things; and I am excused from the length of my words.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it were not for the fact that this book of mine does not allow me to bring you the hidden secret in fire and the quality of its operation in bodies by its expulsion, by which it expels illnesses with a demonstrated philosophical discourse sharpened by your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know, my sons, that they themselves dissent about the time when it is appropriate to perform a cautery, and set a better time according to truth.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say that a cautery is appropriate at all times; because any harm caused by the timing is submerged by the benefit gained from the cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And especially if the cauterization is due to pains arising from necessary, strong, urgent pains that do not tolerate delay: for it is feared that a greater evil may occur which is more harmful than a slight injury left untreated for some time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And do not let it enter your minds, O sons, that which is not esteemed, except by the common people and foolish doctors, namely, that for an illness being treated by cauterization, there is not always a relapse: and they assume its consequences, but the matter is not as they think; for cauterization is nothing other than a local medicine, which alters the complexion, and dries up moistures which are causes of pain.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	However, cauterization surpasses medicine due to the speed of its cure, and the power of its operation, and the intensity of its dominance: and it is possible that an illness may relapse after some time according to the complexion of the patient, and the location of their illness, and its strength; and also what has been prepared in the body through the accumulation of excesses in it, and what has reached them in their acquisition from food, and similar causes, unless the illness is one where cauterization is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	A subtle illness in a limb with few excesses and moistures, such as dental cauterization due to pain, and similar instances can possibly not relapse with that same pain.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But this occurs in few cases.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	However, the common people's talk that cauterization is the last resort of medicine is correct; not for what they intend in it, because they believe there is no cure which can accompany medicine or anything else after cauterization has been performed.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	The reality, however, is the opposite of that, and the intent is that cauterization is the last resort in medicine, not unless we apply the methods of treatment for a particular illness and those medicines do not help; then we use cauterization as a final recourse, and it helps. Thus, it follows that cauterization being the last resort in medicine is not according to the intent understood by the masses and many foolish doctors.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	The ancients said that cauterization with gold is better than with iron, and they did not say this unless because of the equality of gold and the loftiness of its substance; and they also stated that a cauterized area does not form pus.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	But that is not absolutely true; because I have already proven it and found that cauterization does indeed form pus in some bodies but not others.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And cauterization with gold is good and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	However, when you ignite the gold cautery tool with fire, it does not indicate to you when it has reached the desired temperature due to the redness of the gold; and when it quickly becomes cold again, if you add more heat to it, it melts into the fire and turns into flakes.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	That is why the craftsman falls short with it and, because of this, iron cautery instruments are faster and more convenient for us to use in practice.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I have indeed arranged this Chapter on cautery according to topics and ordered them from head to toe so as to assist the seeker in finding what they want.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	On the method of cauterizing the head at the coronal suture.
Caput II.	Chapter Two.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	The cauterization here is attributed to the dominance of moisture and coldness in the brain: which are two causes of melancholy, and the abundance of humors flowing from the head into the eyes and ears, and an overabundance of sleep, and toothache, and sore throat; and universally every disease that occurs due to coldness, such as paralysis, melancholy, epilepsy, apoplexy, and similar ailments.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is to instruct the patient: to first evacuate their head with a purging medicine for three or four nights, depending on the strength of the patient and his age and habits.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then instruct them to shave their head with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then have them sit between your hands in a square position, such that they've already placed their hands on their chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your palm on the root of their nose between their eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Wherever your middle finger arrives, mark that spot with the cautery iron.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then fire up the cautery iron, which is of this shape.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place the heated iron on that marked spot, pressing it down until your hand is contracted little by little and you're turning it around.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then lift up your hand quickly and inspect the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see that the depth of the cauterization has reached the thickness of a bean or the length of fingernail, then lift your hand up.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	If not, repeat this process with your hand and the same iron instrument or another one if that has become cold; until you see the bones I mentioned to you.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt, dissolve it in water, soak the dressing in it, and place it on the wound; leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then place the dressing soaked in butter on top of it and leave it there until the fire-phlegm is destroyed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with the four-ingredient ointment until it is healed.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	They have already said that the longer a wound stays open, the more it discharges pus; which is why this way is better and more helpful.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them have said that the skin should be cauterized all the way to the bone; and that the cautery tool must be held there until something solid from the bone burns.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then after that part of the bone which has been burned is scraped off; it should be treated.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And others say that the cautery must be applied to the very end until it makes a mark on the bone like the imprint of a seal; so that this part of the bone falls out and becomes like a mould for making small bells: or an instrument which women use to stamp letters onto wax; and they believe that vapours from the head come out through this place, so the wound must be left open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then it should be treated until it is healed.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	But to me, these two types of cautery do not seem effective except perhaps on people prone to fearful temperaments.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	I will let him go, for his well-being is more important to me.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	The head weakens due to the disruption of its natural continuity; as we have observed with other body parts. This is especially true when the patient's head is naturally weak and I find the first type of cautery procedure safer and better, so that is what I use. Therefore, proceed with caution for the well-being of the patient.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	On treating head pain through cauterization.
Caput III.	Head, Chapter 3.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When a patient experiences persistent head pain that continues for an extended period and they have tried various treatments such as herbs, leeches, clysters, oils, and emplastrums without success...
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if the patient has already been treated with one type of cautery as we described earlier and it has not brought them any relief, then you must consider...
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	But if the patient's head is naturally strong and not weak, yet they experience extreme coldness, then cauterize with a different type of cautery, but only slightly.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Cauterize the entire horn of their head with this cautery, but do not penetrate through the skin and expose the amount of bone as we described earlier.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	Cauterize it with one type of cautery on the back of their head, in the spot known as 'vas', which is where the windpipe is located. Raise your cautery here and do not expose any bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For the patient will find this pain to be severe and different from the pain of all other types of head cauterizations.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I shall call this cautery by its proper name: it is a cautery that is used for the horns of the head and the back of the skull; it must be gentler than the one used to cauterize the middle of the head.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	On the method of performing cautery on the temples, both with red-hot irons and with a knife.
Caput IIII.	Chapter Four.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When pain and swelling occur on one side of the head or extend to the eye, and it is evacuated with cleansers applied to the head, and the rest of the treatment that I mentioned in the classifications of diseases does not bring improvement; then cauterization is performed according to two methods: either with a caustic medicine or with a knife.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	The cautery with a caustic medicine is performed by taking one other person's tooth, removing its bark, and cutting off its ends on both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then cut the area of pain at an opportune time with a broad lancet until there is formed beneath the skin a space where the tooth can be placed.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Introduce it beneath the skin until it is hidden; then bind over it with a suitable ligature and leave it for fifteen hours before releasing it, and remove the tooth two or three days later; afterward, apply to it a poultice submerged in butter until the area forms pus; then treat it with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish to do it with certain caustic medicines that I have written about in the twelfth treatise on Caustic Medicines,
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	The cauterization with iron is done in this way.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	Cautery by fire, which has this form.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called a claw because the shape of its head is like that of a nail, which has some curvature, and in the middle there is a small bump.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it on the spot and hold your hand; turn the iron slowly with speed; and let the amount burnt be equal to half its thickness.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Raise your hand so as not to burn the artery below and cause bleeding.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then dip the cautery in salt water and place it on the spot; let it be there for three days; then apply butter; afterwards treat with an ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you wish, cauterize this hemicrania with the knife-like end of the cautery.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And beware of cutting the artery in this hemicrania, not an old one properly.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	On the way of cauterizing an old hemicrania.
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you treat a hemicrania, with what we said in the previous cure, and what we said in the divisions of illnesses, and it does not get better; and you see from the illness that it is not enough for it what we said about the first cautery with medicine, or with fire cautery, then one must use the knife-like cautery until it turns white after you marked on the spot of pain a line whose length is half your finger, or nearly so; and remove your hand once, and press it until you cut the artery, and reach the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	However, it is necessary for you to beware of the continuity of the mandible, which moves during chewing, lest the side be burned or the nerve that moves it, whence a spasm may occur.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And be mindful of the cost and caution against arterial blood loss from the severed artery.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For its severance entails fear, especially for the one who is ignorant of what they are doing and is neither studious nor experienced, and abandons the operation with him first.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I shall come with the reminder of the treatment for accidental arterial bleeding as it is described and in its place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If you see from the ailment that it is not sufficient for this cautery and you see the patient's body enduring the cautery at the center of the head as we described, tend to the wound until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, apply the cautery as we said in the chapter on arterial ligation with a cautery having two blades.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For this type of cauterization is better and more effective.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	On the method of cauterizing earache.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When there is an earache due to cold and it is treated with a solution and the remaining treatment we described in the section on external applications, and the pain is not removed, then use a cautery by fire: and this is what is called a Point, whose form is thus.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then make points with it after its ignition all around the ear as it is turned; or all around either one if pain is simultaneously in both.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And extend yourself with the caustic iron from the root of the ear for a moment, after you have marked the places with the encaustic; and let the amount of the caustic be ten points on each ear, and so forth.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then treat those places until they are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	The method of cauterization for the torticollis.
Caput VII.	Chapter Seven.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	The torticollis that is treated with cauterization is not anything but the kinds which happen from excess phlegm, according to what we have said about the divisions of illnesses.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And turn the cauterization towards the kind that happens from desiccation and nerve spasm.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this kind of torticollis with eardrops and head-purgings and gargles, and your treatment does not help, then it is necessary that you cauterize the patient with three caustic irons: one near the root of the ear, a second just below the earlobe, and a third at the joining of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your caustic iron on the opposite side of the affected part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	Because softening does not happen unless it appears on a healthy part.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of this kind of cauterization is that you cauterize with a caustic iron at the outer edge of the upper ear, just below the horn of the head; and again on the earlobe itself, whose length should be according to the length of your thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And leave your hand with the caustic iron until half the thickness of the skin has been burnt.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the shape of a cautery, and it is a type made from a surgical knife, whose form was presented above; however, it is not any finer than that, as you can see: and there should be a knife inside it that is slightly thicker than usual.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then treat the places with what has preceded; until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	A paragraph on the method of cauterizing an old apoplectic condition.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When an old apoplectic condition is treated and you treat it with what we have said, and your treatment does not help, and the patient has no fever, then cauterize them with four cauteries over each corner of their head, and one in the middle of the head, as we have said, and one at the back of the head, according to what has preceded; and make the cautery according to what has been said before.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	It is also cauterized with a cautery over the mouth of the stomach; and this is more effective.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then it should be treated with what has been said before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	A paragraph on the method of cauterizing for forgetfulness.
Caput IX.	Chapter 9.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary that the patient first be given large amounts of liquor, and cleansing pills for the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then shave the patient's head entirely, and place on their occipital bone a plaster of mustard seed described in the treatise on plasters; and put it there several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	For this is the way of cauterization; and do it in the same manner that I have described there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If it heals through this, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not, then perform three cauterizations on the back of their head, which should extend from the top of the head down to the lower part of the eye; and leave a finger's width between each cauterization.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then treat the cauterizations with the same method as before.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	If you wish to add more and the patient can tolerate it, then perform a cauterization in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	If you wish to add more, cauterize it above the two corners (i.e., the temples).
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then treat it until it heals; let the cauterization be oiled according to the form which has been described.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	On the method of cauterizing for paralysis and softening (i.e., scar tissue).
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary to proceed with cleansing the head using urine, and what we have said before (i.e., cauterization).
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then shave the patient's head; afterwards cauterize it with a cauterization in the middle of the head, and one above each corner of the head, and one at the back, and three on the vertebrae of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If you need to soften the patient's body in many places because of a strong illness, and they can tolerate it: then cauterize them with four cauterizations on the vertebrae of their back; and for the last one, burn through as much skin as possible, but raise your hand before causing injury.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then treat it until it heals; oil the cauterization in this way.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	The method of cauterization for epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	An epileptic is not cauterized unless it is one whose epilepsy arises from phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	Therefore, it is necessary that you cleanse his brain first with hyoscyamus, and with the other treatment we mentioned in the division; when the patient is large or can tolerate the acceptance of medicines.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	But if it is a child who cannot tolerate medicines, then give him gargles and cleansing chews for the brain, many days beforehand with an improvement of diet.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then shave his head and afterwards cauterize it with a cautery once on the middle of the head as previously mentioned; with another one on the back of his head, and over every corner of his head.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	If the patient is strong and can tolerate it, then cauterize him with the cauteries that I mentioned in having paralysis, and soften his body over the vertebrae of the neck and the back; and let the cautery be olive-oil as described previously.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	But if the patient is a child then put on a fine cautery in this way.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	Chapter 12.
Caput XII.	Chapter 12.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholy is corrupt humours and thick phlegm then cauterize it with the cauteries that we mentioned for having paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is an excess downwards to the melancholy and the body of the patient is moist, then give him in drink something that cleanses his brain as mentioned previously; afterwards shave the head of the patient and make a pad from decently made linen like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it on the middle of the head; and let the patient sit square being held from every side.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then present the ointment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is more worthy from old egg butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And warm it over a fire with moderate heat, as much as the finger can bear when inserted into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then evacuate it onto the middle of their head in a circle, and leave it until it cools.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this to the patient once every week along with the rest of their good regimen until they are healed.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterise it by making very small multiple points on it, except for where you hold the hand with the cauteriser: let it be fumigated below.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For this kind of cautery moistens the brain with moisture.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place on it a poultice soaked in butter or chicken fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	On the method of cauterising downwards towards the eye.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When you are told that there is a beginning of water in the eye by signs, which I mentioned in the division, then begin and let the patient drink with what cleanses their head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And keep them away from all moisture, and make them sit in a bath fasting for some days.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then instruct him to scrape his head, and cauterise it on the middle of their head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize it above the two temples with two cauterizations, if there is an onset of water drainage from both eyes at once; or from one side, if there is water drainage from one eye only: and cut off with the cauterization all the veins and arteries that are under the skin; and let the cauterizations be as long as the width of the temples; and beware of any bleeding.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If you see anything coming out of it, then cut it off immediately with whatever medicine is possible; and I will come with wisdom regarding the extraction of arteries, their cutting, and caution against bleeding.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And sometimes it is cauterized on the neck, below the two bones, with two cauterizations applied at the very end.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	On the method of cauterizing for old tears.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 14.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are old and persistent: and they appear on the veins and arteries that are visible on the outside of the head, it is verified that this is due to excess cold and phlegmatic humors; then cauterize with the same cauterization method I described at the beginning for water drainage, applying a cauterization in the middle of the head, two cauterizations above the two temples, and two cauterizations on the neck below the two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if you require additional treatment, then cauterize it carefully on every side of the eye, at the end of the eyebrow with a small cauterization tool.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	On the method of cauterizing for nasal odor.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you treat it with what we have said in the division, and the treatment does not take effect; then hasten and give him an infirmocochias potion for three nights: then shave his head and cauterize it with a central cauterization using an olive oil cauterizer.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with two clavicle-shaped cauteries, above the two eyebrows a little under the hair.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And guard against the artery, lest you cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the shape of the clavicle cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	On the method of cauterizing a softened eyelid.
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid of an eye softens due to illness or moisture, then cauterize the eyelid with a single cautery, with this lunar cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize it above the two eyebrows a little with two cauteries on each side; and they extend from the two temples: and let the length of every cautery be according to the lengths of the eyebrow; and do not remove your hand with the cautery, but according to the amount that is burned away of the third eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the shape of the cautery according to this method of lunar cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	On the method of cauterizing an eyelid with inverted hairs that irritate the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter 17.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	The cautery is of two kinds; either with fire, or with a caustic medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	But in the case of a fire cautery, tell the patient beforehand to let his hair grow if he is one who keeps it clean-shaven, until they lengthen and equalize.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If however they prick him at their roots, then bind his eyes with a cloth so that they do not move until they are born.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When they are born and equalized, then place the patient's head in your lap; next, brand over their eyelids with a cautery iron, marking it in the shape of a myrtle leaf, and let the beginning of the brand be near the eyelashes.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Next, place over their eye a poultice soaked in egg white; or use linseed mucilage instead.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then heat the following type of iron with fire.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Next sear the skin around that mark with many slow touchings of the iron until its surface blisters over completely in the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And you will see your operation has been successful when the eyelid is seen to twitch and the eyelashes by it rise up.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	So raise your hand then, and let them go after three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Next place over this a poultice with butter in it until the scar is sloughed away.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat them with an ointment until they recover.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	If any of the eyelashes grow back afterwards and the eyelid becomes flabby, then repeat the cautery on that place as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	But if the eyelashes are on their lower lid, then sear it until they rise up to their proper place; and equalize them so that the lashes do not prick the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	=In the method of using a burning medicine as a brand instead, proceed like this...=
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	Let it be that you advise the patient to leave hair alone until it grows back and becomes even again.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make from cloth a piece of paper shaped like a myrtle leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take of known soap and of lime not slaked from each one ounce in weight or as much as that; then pound them together well and make it with haste so that it does not cool down.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then spread from that onto the paper you made in the shape of a myrtle leaf and place it over one eyelid or two.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And put under the eye wool soaked in egg white; and let the patient's head be in your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And put your index finger on top of the medicine and press it down for a moment.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you will move it as often as the patient feels a sting from the medicine because its sting is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While therefore he persists with this thing which he found to be a sting, then leave the medicine and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When therefore the sting calms down then remove the medicine and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And consider then if you see the eyelid is raised like it has been with fire or with a cut; and if not then repeat on it the medicine where the medicine did not stick, nor darken until your operation becomes even and the eye contracts.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then put on it wool with butter until burnt skin is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with diaphanicon ointment, or another, until it is healed.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And when performing the operation, you must be careful to protect the patient's eye, lest any of the medicine fall into it.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	If the eyelid becomes softened after a few days and there is still something fighting to come out of the eye, then repeat the application of medicine on that specific area which has become soft due to the eyelid, as you did initially.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it is healed.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And you should know that human eyes vary in size and smallness.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore, let your consideration be according to that: the way of righteousness is not hidden from one who has a zeal for this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	On the method of cauterizing a fistula in the tear duct.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you treat a fistula as we described in the section on diseases and your treatment does not take effect, then it is necessary that you cauterize it in this way.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Instruct the patient to place their head in your lap and have your assistant hold their head securely between their hands so that it cannot be moved or shaken.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then place a caustic paste made of gallnut extract or flaxen mucilage on their eye; afterwards, use this form of cautery instrument.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Let it be a hollow cautery like the shape of an eagle's quill feather from one end with which the cautery is done; and if you want to make it penetrating right through to the other end, so do it. If you wish to make its point upwards, so do that instead.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	However, this cavity is better for your operation.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Next squeeze the abscess, if it is open, and remove its purulent fluid, then dry it out; and if it is not open, then open it up, and extract its pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then place upon it a very hot cautery.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold your hand with it for a moment near the cautery from the eye, towards the side of the nose, so that your hand does not stray, or the patient is disturbed; and place the cautery on the fat of the eye, and burn it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If therefore you penetrate with your cautery right up to the bone, then that will be good.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not: then repeat the cautery once or twice, if you need to; and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then apply a poultice with butter, and treat it with drying ointment until it is healed.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	But if forty days elapse and it does not heal: then place on it a caustic medicine until the bone is exposed; and scrape it according to what was said in your chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of cautery for abscesses, which some ancients have described.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Attend to the place of the abscess, and find it; then place into its fissure a slender probe, that is, a fine cannula, whose form is this: [illustration].
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it the quantity of a drachma's worth of molten lead, and hold your hand with the cannula firmly, and do not let the patient move at all, so that [the lead] does not run or reach his eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	You must place a poultice infused with egg white over the patient's eye, or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	For lead burns the site of the fistula, and heals it with a wondrous healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	If the fistula is healed, with what we have said about cauterization and treatment, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, then it is necessary to administer a nasal hole, and redirect the fistula towards the nose's passage, according to what will come to its proper place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	On the method of cauterizing cracks in the lips.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Cracks often occur in the lip, which are called "pili," especially in the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When you treat these cracks, as we have said in the division of ailments, and the treatment does not take effect, then use a small knife-shaped cauterizer with fire, according to this form.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let it be hollowed out according to the thinness of the knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then place it, burning hot, quickly into the cracks themselves, until the cauterization reaches the deepest part of the crack.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with a caustic [substance], until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	On the method of cauterizing an oral fistula.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When an abscess happens at the root of the gums, or on the palate, or at the roots of teeth: then it makes pus and ruptures; afterward, it festers and runs with pus, and becomes a fistula: then you treat it, but the treatment does not take effect in it, then you must use a cauterizer according to its size which will fit into the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Insert the heated iron into the opening of the fistula and hold your hand there until the hot iron reaches its depth and end; do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then treat it afterwards with what we have said about the treatment until it is healed.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If therefore the pus discharges and heals, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if it does not heal, then you must uncover the location and remove the rotten bone as will come to its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	On the method of cauterizing gums and softened teeth.
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gums are softened by moisture, and the teeth become loose, and you treat them with medicine but it does not help; then place the patient's head in your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then use the cautery fire with this shape, so that you place a pipe over the tooth; and quickly insert in it a heated cauterizer: and hold your hand there for some time until the patient feels the heat of the fire has reached the root of their tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And lift your hand; then repeat the cautery several times as you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then have the patient fill their mouth with salt water, hold it there for an hour; and spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the loose tooth is firmed, and the softened gums tighten, and the corrupted moisture dries up.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	On the method of cauterizing for toothache.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When tooth pain is due to coldness, or there are worms within and treatment with medicine does not help, then cauterization on the tooth itself is done in two ways: either cauterization with butter, or cauterization with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	The cauterization with butter is done by taking goat's butter and boiling it in an iron spoon or pot.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Next, take the cauterizing instrument (a red-hot iron) and wrap it with a cloth at its end.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then dip the instrument into the boiled butter and quickly place it on the painful tooth, holding it there until it cools down. Repeat this several times until the heat reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	If you wish, you may also dip wool or a cloth into cold butter and place it on the aching tooth; then put a red-hot iron on top of that until the heat reaches deep inside the cavity of the tooth.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	The cauterization with fire is done by applying either an air pipe or an iron pipe to the area.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	If there is any thickness on the body of the patient which prevents the sharpness of the fire from reaching their mouth...
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Next, take the fire cautery of this shape and place it on that tooth; hold your hand there until the cautery cools down.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Repeat this several times; for the pain will be relieved either that same day or on the next day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	The patient should fill their mouth with good butter to cover the mark of the cautery and hold it there for an hour; then spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	And this is the form of cauterization.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Cauterize with any end you wish according to what is possible: and this is the form of the cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	On the method of cauterizing with a hot iron.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When the ulcers are due to phlegm and cold humours, and they do not yield to medicinal treatment, and you wish to bring about their quick cure: then use a concave cautery of this form.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two tight ends so that the smoke may come out at one end of the cautery: and place it burning on the ulcer once or twice if you need to until you reach the bottom of the ulcer.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	But if the ulcer is small: then place the cautery according to the size of the ulcer.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then leave it for three days, and place on it cotton soaked in butter until what the fire burnt is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then treat it with tooth-alkali ointment until the form of the cannula heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	On the method of cauterizing for hoarseness of voice and shortness of breath.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When humours gather over the trachea and especially when there is coldness of constitution, then it ought to be evacuated first by means of dissolving medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize it by night at the root of the throat in a hollow place: and take care not to reach with the cautery the gullet nor the skin unless some of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize it with another cautery near the neck joint at his last vertebra, finishing [the operation]: and let the cautery be a clavicle-shaped one similar to the previous one.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with what preceded until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	On the method of cauterization for lung disease and cough.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.
