When cough and lung disease are caused by cold humors, the patient has no fever nor any sign of phthisis, and it is an old disease: then cauterize them with two cauteries above the clavicle in shallow, soft, empty spots.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And with another cautery in the middle of the chest between two nipples: and let this second cautery be cannula-shaped like the previous one.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if you wish your cauterization to be performed by pricking with a cautery called "the Point", whose shape was mentioned earlier for earache pricking: and let the number of points be from thirty up until almost forty.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with what preceded until it heals.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And now let the cautery have three branches: like this shape.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Why is the cautery mitigated with what you do with three cauteries at once?
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	On the method of cauterization for shoulder dislocation and tickling.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head of the humerus is dislocated because of moisture and it does not return to its place at once upon being relocated until it becomes accustomed to returning, then it dislocates from a slight movement as we have already testified that this happens, then you should relocate the joint first.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	The patient should then lie down on their back, or on their healthy side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then elevate the skin that is inside the elbow towards the upper part with the fingers of your left hand: and if the joint is dislocated inwardly.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then have a cauterizing fire with two rods.
Cuius forma est haec.	Its form is as follows.
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then cauterize the skin until it penetrates to the other side, and there will appear a figure of cauterization with four cauteries.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And sometimes the cauterization is done with a cautery having three rods, so that the figure of cauterization appears as six cauteries; and the rods are chosen according to their fineness.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	And this is the form of the three-rod cautery.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And sometimes one is added to this configuration, resulting in eight cauteries.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then place crushed leeks with salt on the cautery.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then make sure to keep the patient calm so that they do not move their limbs until they are healed.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if the dislocation is upward, which happens rarely, then you should cauterize it on the shoulder with a ball-shaped cautery, or by pricking it with several small cauteries.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the joint is made firm again, moisture removed; and the patient heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	On the method of cauterizing the stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When there is coldness and excessive moisture in the stomach until it is removed from its own constitution, and catarrhs begin to increase towards it, and frequent modes of treatment are applied without benefit: then the patient should be laid supine on their back with their legs and arms outstretched.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with three cauterizations; with a sub-spoonful cautery of the chest the size of one finger alongside a clavicle cautery, and two additional cauteries below from either side by one cautery until the shape of the cauterization becomes triangular.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And leave some space between each so that they do not join up when they produce pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And the depth of the cauterization should be two-thirds the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And the shape of the cauterizations should be as follows without addition, and if you wish to cauterize with a large cautery in the middle of the stomach it should be shaped thusly; let the device that performs this cauterization have one circular shape like so.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And the stomach is cauterized by being pricked with a needle which has been heated red-hot in this cautery; and it will be done such that you prick onto the stomach as many times as desired with an iron; then cauterize each spot with a single point cautery; afterwards treat each of them according to the treatment prescribed until they are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	On the method of performing a cold cauterization on the spleen:
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When there is pain in the spleen due to coldness and moisture, or from thick wind, until it leaves its natural constitution with an excessive discharge, and the patient is treated as we have said but makes no progress; then they should be laid supine on their neck, and you should mark out three cauteries like so, of this size, at the same place beneath the spleen from where a man's elbow reaches down to: let there be between each one a space equal to the thickness of a finger, and let them all be as long as a straight line; do not press your hand very much on the cautery.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And let the amount that is cauterized be in proportion to the thickness of the skin, with half its size not added; and let the patient stand on his own feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	But if he cannot stand, then let him lie down, having already stretched out his legs and raised his arms.
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of the cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And it is indeed possible for you to use these knife-cautery techniques with the actual cautery iron when you have skill and wisdom in this art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And be careful not to go too far in your cauterization, and that you do not burn through the entire thickness of the skin, for if you do it will burn the whole body and reach the intestines: for the skin there is thin, so you must know this.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	On the method of cauterizing liver abscesses.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When it happens and you wish to know whether the abscess is in the liver's flesh or its capsule, then if it is in the liver's flesh, the patient feels a dull pain with weight but no sharpness; and if it is in the liver's capsule there is pain that has severe acuteness: and already you see how wearisome this cure was to his physicians.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	Therefore, the patient must lie on their back with their neck exposed.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Next, mark the abscess site with an ink-burn; then take a fire-heated cautery iron that is like a rod.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	Cauterize with that one iron until all the skin is burned and it reaches the bone, until all pus has come out; then cure this with the cure for discharging sores, until he is healed.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	And one should not use this type of cauterization unless their studies in the art of medicine are prolonged, and these ailments have rushed through their hands with some experimentation; then indeed will they dare to perform such an operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	But as for letting it go, in my view, it is better with me.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	[Regarding] the method of cauterization in [the case of] pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancients said, "Cauterization with the roots of *Aristolochia* for cold pleurisy in this way.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And it is such that you should take from the dry roots of *Aristolochia*, one longer root which is found within, and let it be as thick as a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then immerse it in oil, and light it on fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize with one large cauterizer where the collar bone meets the neck, and two small ones slightly sloped downwards towards the side which is under the jaw.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And with two more cauterizers on the spot between the fifth and sixth ribs sloped slightly towards the back, one in the center of the chest, and another over the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And three more from behind; one between the shoulder blades, and two on either side of the chest, the lower one again being between the shoulder blades.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	And you must not press your hand with the cauterizer, rather it should be held away from the skin, sniffing the smell.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And some ancients have said that there are those who use an iron cauterizer like a radius (a bone in the forearm); they light it on fire and insert it between the ribs until they reach the abscess, and pus flows out, as we have said with regard to liver abscesses.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But in this perforation, when using a caustic, there is the fear that either the patient dies immediately or a fistula occurs in the place, which has no cure.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	On the method of cauterizing the spleen - Chapter 32.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you are treating a spleen disease, as we have mentioned previously when discussing the different types of illnesses, and your treatment is not effective, then cauterization on it can be done in three ways, all of which are appropriate.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	One of which is to make three or four caustic applications by lining them up along the length of the spleen according to the shape of the liver cauteries described previously.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And let there be between each caustic application an amount equal to the thickness of a finger or more or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And let the method of caustic application be as described for liver cauteries equally.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	And do not press your hand when applying the caustic; let the patient be lying prone on their back.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	Another method of cauterization is to use a caustic with two prongs as we described in the chapter on dislocation of the shoulder: and lift the skin that is over the spleen where the patient's left elbow reaches; and let your lifting be such that you raise the skin according to the width of their body so that the caustics fall along the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then introduce the two ignited prongs until you pierce through the skin on the other side; then withdraw the caustic; thus four caustics are made.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish to use another type of caustic with three prongs.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then treat the cautery after you discharge it to emit pus for many days: it is more beneficial than the rest of what preceded in the cure.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	On the method of cauterizing with hydropsy.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	The cautery does not fall out in hydropsy unless it is proper to the ascites.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you treat hydropsy with the methods of treatment that we have mentioned in the division and the cure does not improve, then it is necessary for you to cauterize it with four cauteries around the navel, one cautery over the stomach, another over the liver, a third over the spleen, two behind the back between the vertebrae, one directed at the chest, and the other at the stomach: and let the depth of the cautery be close to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then leave the open cautery so that it emits pus for a long time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	And you will not discharge the patient from treatment after the cautery with it, which must be applied to him twice: and healing will hasten towards it with God's help.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	The shape of the cautery with which the belly is cauterized should be a nail according to its previous form; and that of the one used for the back an olive-leaf according to its former shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	On the method of cauterizing feet and legs.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When there are blisters on the hydropsy and they are filled with yellow water, you must cauterize over the back of the foot in the night-watch between the auricular and annular [phalanges]: then raise your hand with the cautery and do not twist it; afterwards raise your hand, and do not repeat it at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	The yellow water should be boiled and used as a caustic in this form.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make two caustic irons over the two legs, with a knife-shaped tip on each iron; and let one of these be made according to the length of the leg, one below the knee, and the other beneath that one, roughly in the middle of the leg; and then two more caustics over the entire thigh. Leave the irons open for some time without treatment: so as a little water may boil out of them: then treat it with the rest which we mentioned earlier.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	On how to cauterize an open belly wound.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When an open belly wound is caused by cold and moisture, until it weakens the retentive and digestive faculties which are in the stomach and intestines; and when you treat it with conventional remedies but it does not heal: and you see a patient bearing the caustic iron on account of his superabundant vitality, then cauterize him with a large caustic iron over his belly as mentioned before for cauterizing the stomach with a circular caustic iron, and four small caustic irons around the navel, with a needle-like caustic iron; and with one or two large caustic irons on top of the alchosos.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if you see abundant moisture and the patient bearing it well, then cauterize him with a caustic iron over the spine; and another one over the entire flank: perhaps also adding two small caustic irons on top of the belly near the large one.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	It is indeed a successful treatment where its benefit does not go astray.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	On how to cauterize haemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When there are many old hemorrhoids in the anus or just one that is caused by thick, cold, and corrupt humors, and it does not heal when treated as we said before: then cauterize with three cauteries on the lower spine below the shoulder blades a little triangularly, and with another cautery under the navel about two fingers long.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that their stomach is chilled and the food is not being digested, and you see that their face has pustules, then cauterize them on their stomach with a large cautery as previously described; also with another cautery above their liver, and one over their spleen, along with one at the clavicle: leave the cauteries open for some time. Then treat them until they are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	On the method of cauterizing hemorrhoids after their excision:
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 37.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you excise the hemorrhoids, then ignite a cautery that resembles a spoke.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then insert the ignited cautery into the excised hemorrhoid; and keep your hand there until you reach the opening of the vein from which blood is flowing: do this once or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If therefore there are many hemorrhoids, then cauterize each one with a cautery as we have described.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then treat them with salves that suit them until they are healed.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you cauterize with a large cautery over the navel, it is more effective for improvement.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	The method of cauterizing a fistula in ano.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVIII.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the patient does not obey the incision and operation that we have described in its proper place, and is afraid of it, he may perhaps be cured with a cauterization.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	So when someone gets a fistula and it becomes old, pus runs from it, and there are corrupted fluids.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	It is appropriate then that you should examine it with a thin probe.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then determine the depth of it with the probe.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Next heat up the circular cautery.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then introduce yourself, heated, into the fistula itself, for as long as the probe went in.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And repeat the cautery on it, until they burn all those corrupted parts of the body - once or twice or three times, depending on how much is necessary.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And beware of burning the nerve if it is there or a large vein - or if the fistula goes into the body of the bladder or the intestines, then take care from all these places.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	And do not do it unless the fistula is in fleshy tissue and you think that it will not penetrate.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then look after the place until it is healed.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	But if the place is sealed up, and materials are cut off from it, and this remains so for a long time - then you know that he has now been thoroughly healed.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And if they do not cut away the matter from it, then know that it is penetrating, or there is a corrupted bone deep inside, or almost like one of those: whose description will come in its place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	On the method of cauterising kidneys.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When there is pain in the kidneys due to cold or thick windiness and it weakens because of that, then one ought to cauterise them over almethenem on top of the kidneys themselves with a clavicle cautery, whose description has preceded this.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we cauterise it again within the almeidat itself.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Why three lined ones will come.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Thus they shall be more beneficial as the last resort.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	On the method of cauterising the bladder.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When there is weakness and softening in the bladder due to cold and moisture such that the afflicted person cannot hold urine, then one ought to cauterise it on the lower part of suminis over the bladder where hair starts to grow with a right-handed sumin cautery and another from its left; and let its length be according to the size of the thumb's knuckle; and cauterise it further down the back with one or two cauteries if needed, and let them be as per the preceding clavicle cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	On the method of cauterising the uterus.
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When cold and dampness occur in the uterus, preventing conception, and her menses are corrupted, and their onset is delayed, and she experiences pain at their arrival, then she ought to be cauterized with three cauteries around the navel, as we said in the cauterization of vesico-uterine fistula, and a cautery below the back over the sacrum, or two cauteries; and let the cautery be clavicle-sized.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	On the method of cauterizing the ancle in dislocation.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When the mucous moistures are poured out onto the ancle-bone and become the cause of its exit from its place; and its sign is that the leg is lengthened over the other when they are compared with each other, and the place of dislocation is found to be empty in it.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	It is necessary therefore that you cauterize the weak above the ancle-bone with a cautery of similar circle: after you have marked it with encaustics around the ancle, as it rotates; and so that the bone itself falls into the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And let this cautery have a shape which preceded in stomach cauterization.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	But if this cautery is not present to you, then cauterize it with three cauteries, with a large oil-lamp cautery; and let the depth of the cautery be according to the thickness of all the skin.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	On the method of cauterizing sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When there is pain in the hip joint and its cause is cold and moisture: treat the patient with what we have said in the section on divisions, but if treatment does not help and the problem persists, you must then relieve the patient of thick humors using foul-smelling pills or artificial pills and similar substances.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize them.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And there are two methods of cauterization: either with medications that burn or with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	Cauterization by fire is done in many ways.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	One of which is to place three triangular cauterizations on the hip joint in this shape.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make them either deep or shallow.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	The space between each cauterization should be the width of a finger, and they should be made with an olive-oil cautery iron.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	Sometimes there is also a cauterization in the center, right above the head of the hip joint.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	Because these four cauterizations form a cross-shape.
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you want to cauterize with a circle, whose form was previously used in the cauterization of hip dislocations, ensure it is a circle that contains the entire hip joint.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	Burn away all the thick skin entirely.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the method of cauterization for sciatica when there is pain attached to the hip joint that does not reach as far as the thigh and leg.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	However, if it does extend to the thigh and leg, then cauterize them with two cauterizations on the thigh over the spot where they indicate pain is present; add your own fourth cauterization four fingers from the extremity using a knife-shaped iron.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	The depth of the cauterization should correspond to the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	If the patient indicates that the pain extends close to their toes, then cauterize them there where they indicate with a point, three, four, or more cauterizations, as required.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if they indicate the pain is below the knee towards the leg, then cauterize them there with a single knife-like cauterization.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And take care in all your cauterizations not to go so far with the cauterization that you burn a nerve or large artery and cause great harm or contraction to the patient through it.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	And I myself have seen one and another, among those who cauterized above the shin and overdid it in their cauterization, and the leg became swollen until the swelling reached the foot, and it was all perforated and completely corrupted; then there occurred a rupture of the belly and death afterwards.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	If the pain is in two places at once, cauterize both in this way.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And some wise men have said about the cauterization of the hip that this is its method.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a tube-like instrument from iron whose diameter is half the width of your palm; and let it be at its opening as thick as a thumb or slightly less; and inside this instrument there should be another smaller one.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And let the space that is between each instrument be of the length of a knuckle; and they should all have openings at both ends; and their height should be as long as one or two knuckles; and attach a handle to them made from iron, which fits awkwardly.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then it is heated in fire until it reddens and throws sparks; then it is placed on an earthenware vessel with the weak lying down propped up on the healthy side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	Therefore, cauterize him with three round cauteries one after another.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then leave him alone for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Later, apply ointments with butter; and leave the wound open for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with an ointment until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasis says, with this type of cauterization, my sons, we have used it rarely due to the fear of its appearance; and also because there are few whom we find willing to endure it.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	However, it is among the good cauterizations for him who endures it; and he will find its place.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	But if you want to make a cautery with medicinal smokes, then make two pieces of wood having a perforated ring into which descends the hinge of its door made out of brass or iron as long as the wall; and at their height let there be two knots, or something similar.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And let there be the space between each one of the thickness of a finger; and let them be open at the bottom and top; and let them fit into each other according to this form.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then place it on the earthenware vessel with the weak lying down propped up on the healthy side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And press your hand hard over the earthenware vessel.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Next, immerse the two circles in warm water, which has been heated for a short while with fire, and hold it there for an hour's time; the patient can withstand its bite and burning since he finds its bite like that of fire until the biting stops.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Next, lift your hand with the instrument, and wipe off the warm water from the entire wound with fresh water; then leave it there for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And place butter on top of it until the blackness of burning is removed; leave it there for a few days and pus will drain from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	For this is indeed the last part of treatment.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Next treat it with ointments until it heals.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	But if the pain extends to the hip or leg; make for him an apparatus on that part which contains water, as you did for the wound equally.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	And this is the method of warm water; and I have already written it down in my book on medicinal preparations.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take one part alkali and one part unslaked lime; grind both of them, and put them in a new pot whose lower part has a single small hole according to the size that will be taken up by this radius; place under the base of the pot another worn-out pot; throw over the alkali and the lime from fresh water which should submerge both by one finger's breadth; after you have pressed it down with your hand firmly; leave the pot until cold water comes out of the lower part of the worn-out pot.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Next collect all that water and throw it over another lime; stir until it is renewed.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	It will then have great sharpness, which is applied to many medical procedures and to the cauterisation of other body parts.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	Because it makes fire do its job.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And from medicine are those with which they cauterise the ankle, just like with thuya and nut butter, and lime mixed with soap so that both can be applied together.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	Galen indeed told the story of a man from ancient times whose treatment cured ankle and sciatic vein pain, and praised its effectiveness greatly.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	He said that no other treatment was needed and he had healed in one go until he told how the man perhaps entered a bath carried by others and left it completely healed.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	And it is to be made from green thuya and if not found fresh then take the dry one instead; grind a lot of this with some fat and apply it over where the pain is whether ankle, leg or hip bone: bandage this on and leave for three hours but let the patient remove when they feel enough burning.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then put him into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When his body is then moistened, place him on a couch.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain goes away and he heals.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And you should know that no one must use the cautery with these medicines unless after a bowel movement.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides who said this also stated that goat droppings, when mixed with the above and used to cauterise a sciatic vein, help it heal; and so is made this kind of cautery.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	Let wool be taken and soaked in old oil, then placed on the deep spot which is between the big toe and the next one, closest to the latter.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take dry goat dung and set it on fire until it becomes charcoal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then place the charcoal over the wool and leave it there until it is extinguished.
Deinde itera illud.	Then repeat this process.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	Keep doing it until sensation returns to the ankle area via touch and the pain subsides.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And this method of cauterization is called Goat-Brand Cautery.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	On the cauterization of back pain:
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	Back pain can arise from many causes, such as strain, blows or excessive discharge, and by the introduction of cold moist matter; cauterization is only used for this last type of pain.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	It is therefore necessary to apply foul pills and the like on the back, over three lines of width corresponding with the patient's waist, after which you mark each line with five cauteries or more according to the amount that comes out depending upon the endurance of the patient; perform a needle-cautery cauterization.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, cauterize with three or four cauteries in a central row, according to this pattern: [insert illustration of the pattern].
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	On the method of cauterization for beginning hump formation:
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	This illness occurs many times in small children.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of its onset in children is: that it happens to him with a tightness during breathing upon elevation and movement; and you find at the lower end of the spine and its knots, which has now begun to protrude above the other vertebrae.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When therefore you see it, and wish to treat it, then cauterize it with a cautery which is a circle of this shape.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	And let the cautery take hold over the entire area of the vertebra equally; and if you wish to cauterize around the vertebra, use a point cautery in two or three lines, and let the points be close to each other.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then treat the place until it is healed with what we have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And beware, do not apply the cautery to a hump which forms from a nerve spasm.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	On the method of cauterization for podagra and joint pains.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When joint pains are from cold moist humours which are poured into any part of the body; then when they happen in the feet it is customary for physicians to call this podagra specifically.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	When therefore podagra from cold causes is treated with therapeutic methods, and the pains are not removed; then the cautery removes them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is as if you cauterize him after evacuation around the joints of the feet with multiple cauteries; and let the cautery be an Olive-shaped one.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is its form.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you need to make an incision on the surface of the foot, then make punctures with the cautery.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	But if the pains ascend to the knees or other joints and this often happens, then cauterize it over the entire knee with three cauteries, or four on all sides, using the same Clavulanic cautery.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	If however you need more of this cautery, then cauterize it further.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	And do not immerse your hand with the cautery, rather let it be about as thick as the skin.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	If however the pains ascend to the knees and back: then apply what we have said about the cautery in its own chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	If the pains are in the hands alone, then make incisions around the wrists where two lines revolve.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	If any of the pain remains in the fingers, then make incisions on them, over every knuckle with an incision and over the comb of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If however the pains ascend after days to the elbows or shoulders, then cauterize both on all sides.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not discharge the sick person from their good diet or from taking their medicines.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if a good diet is kept and the phlegm is discharged, he will be cured by God's help with this cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	On the method of cauterization for ruptures.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 47.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When there is a rupture in the groin and the intestine or caecum descends towards the testicle and it begins to draw near, then you must instruct the patient to fast for one day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And he should use laxatives so that the stool descends from his abdomen.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then have him sit between your hands on his back and tell him to hold his breath until either the caecum or intestine comes out.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then bring it back with your fingers and mark with cauterizer under the rupture on the pectineal bone with a sign whose end is similar to half of a circle at the top of the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then heat the cautery of this shape until it turns white and starts to give off sparks.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then return the caecum or intestine to its cavity.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then have the assistant put his hand over this place so that the intestine does not come out: and you now open between the patient's legs, placing a pillow under him and another servant holding down the patient's legs while one holds their hands on their chest.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then place the cautery back over that mark with your hand holding it straight.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold it there until you reach the bone with it or repeat this process again if you did not reach the bone on your first attempt.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	Carefully observe the exit of the intestine when you are cauterizing, lest you burn it and cause either death or great harm to come upon the patient.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And you should understand that when your cauterization does not reach the bone then this operation is of no benefit.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	The tool should be delicate and proportionate to their size for infants.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the rest of the ointments until it is healed.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And if he has been lying on his back for forty days until the wound seals over.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	You must provide nourishment for the length of his treatment with a gentle food to ease his stomach; so that it doesn't leave his intestines during straining and defecation.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when he wishes to get up after forty days, then apply a bandage made too loose and keep it on for another forty days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	He should be spared from work, and over-eating or drinking, and shouting loudly.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when he follows this regimen, thus he recovers with a complete recovery.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I shall describe the treatment of ruptures involving incisions in its own chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When however ruptures occur in the rest of the belly and are starting out, if you wish that they not spread, then cauterize his rupture with a round cautery according to its size; and let what is burned be from there on like one third of it.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then treat it with that which we have described; and it will not spread.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And now some early writers have said that the rupture should be cauterized with a triangular cautery in this shape.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	After it is sealed with caustic, and you place a line which runs across the width on the upper side of the rupture, and another line below.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	Place your hand in the middle with a heated iron.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But first, the iron is easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	On cauterizing sores caused by an accident or a blow.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter 48.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When there is pain in any limb caused by an accident or blow and the pain persists for a long time without healing with medicines, then it must be cauterized with a point cautery.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And let the iron be of a size proportionate to that of the limb and its thickness and weakness and strength and the place of the twisting and pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If therefore it heals with the first cauterization, it is well.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not, then repeat on it the cauterization.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	For it is customary for these pains to shift from the limb to that which adjoins it.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Why you must follow up on them with the iron until the patient is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	On the method of cauterizing in leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	However, sometimes lepers benefit from the greatest aid of the iron.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the type of leprosy that occurs due to the putrefaction of phlegm and melancholy: when you wish to cauterize it, consider this.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If therefore the leprosy is in its beginning and you have treated it with that which we said in the division, and it has neither descended nor stopped, and you fear for the patient, lest corruption should spread over his entire complexion: then cauterize him on the head with five iron marks: one in the middle of the scalp; a second below it towards the front at the hairline; two above the two horns [temples], and one behind on the nape of the neck.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And with your hand holding the cautery for a short while, until it leaves on the bone a small impression and the chips are dislodged from it: so as to ease the exhalation of large vapors from this wound, cauterize also right above the spleen with the same cautery.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	But if leprosy has already spread over the patient and appears manifestly, you should then cauterize with these same cauteries which we have mentioned in the head, one on the tip of the nose, two on both cheeks, two on the nape of the neck, six on the vertebrae of the back, and one large one above the coccyx and another over it itself at almeidati: and two on the hips - that is to say, a single one over each hip and two on the knees - one for every knee; and two on the shoulders, two on the elbows, two on the tenderness of his chest, and cauterize him also over all joint junctions, especially those of the fingers of both hands and feet: and cauterize too over both heel bones of their feet and palms of their hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	Be careful to avoid the nerves which lie over the heel bone so as not to burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	Sometimes you must cauterize with one cautery over the breastbone, another over the stomach, and yet a third over the liver.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	Know that the more you apply of the cautery, the greater is its benefit and efficacy.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And know that the patient will not experience pain from the cautery as healthy people do because their body is already numb.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	And the cauteries ought to be of sizes and smallness suitable for limbs and joints as required by types of tools.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat the cautery with herb flour and honey, and continue with the remaining treatment until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	On how to cauterize for stupor.
Caput L.	Chapter 50.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When any member is stunned and treated with medicines, oils, and plasters but does not heal, then cauterize the stunned member with a cautery according to its size or smallness.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And let your cautery be as thick as the skin.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with an ointment until it heals.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	Sometimes it is also cauterized for a kind of stupor that happens to the hand and foot, at the vertebrae of the back near where nerves emerge which move that member, and the stupor goes away.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	But do not venture this unless you are knowledgeable about the anatomy of members and where the nerves emerge which move the body.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	On how to cauterize for albaras.
Caput LI.	Chapter 51.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When albaras lasts long and you apply nothing from your medical skills to it: then cauterize right on it with a deep cautery according to the thickness of the skin until its whiteness is removed and its colour changes.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with herb flour and lentils with rose oil and arnoglossae leaves and pigeon blood and swallow blood; let there be equal parts of each one: mix all these things together and apply them on a cloth and let it stick in place until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	On the method of cauterization for cancer.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52.
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When cancer is beginning, and you wish to stop it: then cauterize it with a circular cautery around its circumference, as if it were turning.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	The wise have said that it should be cauterized with the last cautery in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	That does not seem right to me, because I fear that it may be ulcerated; and indeed I have seen this happen several times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	And it is better that it be cauterized around its circumference with a circle, as we have said; or with multiple cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	On the method of cauterization for abscesses.
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When someone has an abscess that is delayed in maturing, due to excessiveness causing it, or because of the age and little blood of the patient, or because of time constraints when you wish to hasten its maturation, then cauterize around its circumference with multiple small cauteries by puncturing.
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then leave it be.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For itself will hasten with its own maturation.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	If you wish to make an opening in it with the cautery, then heat the cautery which is of this form.
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it on the abscess until it penetrates the skin; and let the patient be from one who follows, so that his path may be alleviated.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Treat it until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	On the way of cauterizing a corrosive sore.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 54.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	A corrosive sore is nothing but an ongoing corruption of the limb, and it corrodes itself; like a fire consumes dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	If you see a corrosive sore in a place that can tolerate fire-based cautery, then use many hot cauterizing irons of different sizes and lengths, depending on what is suitable for the location of the sore.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize it from all sides until you eradicate the entire corruption, leaving nothing of it remaining whatsoever.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	After that, leave it for three days, then apply powdered sulfur mixed with oil over the cauterized areas until all scabs and any remaining corruption is eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then treat it with ointments that generate flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	If you see healthy new flesh generated after three days with no sign of corruption, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not, then repeat the cautery over what remains of the corrupted areas.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	A corrosive sore is sometimes treated with an acute medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	For that medicine arises in the place of the cautery.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	However, fire-based cautery provides quicker relief; and I have indeed mentioned its use with acute medicine previously - take that where it is needed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	On the way of cauterizing warts and corns.
Caput LV.	Chapter 50.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	Many times this disease occurs in the lower parts of the feet: it is a thick, filtered substance that injures the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	And indeed the cautery on them is according to two methods: cautery with fire, and cautery with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	As for the amount when using fire, make a flat cautery like an eagle's feather: it should be made of iron and sized to hold a nail on all sides; and let its edges be thin.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then place it, heated, on a nail.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Then turn the hand with the cautery around the nail until it reaches the depth of the nail; and leave it there for three days until it begins to discharge pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then plaster it with crushed wild apples mixed with salt; and leave the plaster on overnight.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	For it will indeed eradicate itself from its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then treat the place with flesh-generating ointment until it is healed.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	If they are not converted and often occur on the surface of the body, especially on hands and feet; then apply to them cautery with hot water: you should take a pipe made of brass or iron or an eagle's feather; and place it on a nail or althelul.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then pour a small amount of hot water into the pipe; hold your hand and turn it with your thumb pressure for a moment so that the edge of the pipe is pressed against the root of the nail, allowing the hot water to reach deep down, to the root of the nail: and let the patient wait a little while over this application of hot water for about an hour.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then release it, for the nail is pulled out with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	Do this to one after the other until you have come across all of them that are in the body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then treat them after they have been removed with what generates flesh from the ointments.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	On the method of cauterization in tremor.
Caput LVI.	Chapter 56.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When someone experiences tremors due to cold affecting the nerves or from quartan fever or other causes, you should cauterize with four or five cauteries on the dorsal vertebrae and one between each vertebra, one on their chest, and another on their abdomen.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	For the tremors indeed calm down with an oily cautery, and the cure of a cold disease becomes hastened.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	On the method of performing cauterization according to Al-Bahir.
Caput LVII.	Chapter 57.
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	Sometimes Al-Bahir's foul ones, that is to say, pustules which are formed from coarse corrupted matter, appear on the body.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	So when they appear, it is necessary that you first cauterize over the entire head of the pustule with a fine myrtle wood cautery whose end has been ignited by fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	Or with the root of long aristo-luchia.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or with a disk-shaped cautery.
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	And sometimes they are cauterized while still emerging following this method, and do not increase but the superfluity which produced them is broken down and they heal.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	However, it is necessary that this should be done after evacuation with bloodletting.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	On the method of cauterizing the flowing blood from an artery in a wound.
Caput LVIII.	Chapter 58.
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	It often happens that there is a flow of blood from an artery which has been cut at the site of a wound which occurs externally or at the edge of an abscess or when cauterizing a limb and suchlike procedures; and it becomes difficult to stop it.
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	So when it happens to anyone, then quickly reach with your hand towards the orifice of the artery and place your index finger over it; press on it hard until the blood is dammed under your finger and nothing comes out from it.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then place small olive oil cauterizing irons into the fire and a great number of them; blow on them until they become very hot.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take one of them, small or large depending on the wound and where the artery has been cut; place the cautery iron on that vein after you quickly remove your finger, and hold it there until the blood stops flowing.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	But if the blood is forced out when you lift your finger from over the artery orifice and you put out that hot iron then quickly take another one of those which are prepared in the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Thus do not stop doing this with one after another until the blood stops flowing.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And be careful not to burn any nerve which is there or some other injury will occur for the patient.
