Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from an artery, it is not possible to cut it off; especially when the artery is large, unless with one of four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or by cauterization, as we said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or with extraction, when it is not extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, its ends contract, and the blood is cut off.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it can be tightly tied with a strong binding thread.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or place on it medicines with the property of stopping blood, and bind it with a suitable compress.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	He who causes its ceasing with a binding and compression using a cloth, or the positioning of burning objects and similar things, does not bring it about completely, except rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	If it happens to someone and neither a doctor nor medicine is present: then begin with the placement of the index finger on the vein's orifice as we described, and compress it strongly until the blood is obstructed from the upper part of the wound and over the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger must not be removed from it with cold water of intense coldness always until blood solidifies and swells and is cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And meanwhile one should consider what it needs of cauterization or medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	End of the First Part.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis, Part 2.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On incision, perforation, and bloodletting for wounds and similar things.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have already mentioned in Chapter One, every illness that is suitable for treatment with fire and burning medicine, and its opportunities, causes, instruments, and forms of cauterization.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I placed chapters there from the top to the bottom.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I will proceed in this chapter along the same path, so as to relieve the enquirer of his quest.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin it, you must learn, O sons, that this chapter contains nothing of the terror of what is in Chapter One about cauterization.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And for that reason, greater care must be taken because the operation in this chapter often involves evacuation with blood, which is essential to life when opening a vein or making an incision over an abscess, ulceration, wound, or extraction of an arrowhead, as well as incisions over stones and similar procedures; all of which cause trembling, fear, and death for many.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I warn you not to fall into hesitation on this point because sometimes there present themselves to you in this art different types of people with different types of illnesses.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	Among them is the one who becomes angry with his illness and for whom death is light; because of the intensity of what he experiences from his illness, and the length of its duration.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And with sickness is fear that signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And among them is the one who offers you his flute player and enriches you with it, hoping for health while his illness is deadly.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	You must not agree with him who comes to you from among them, whose manner is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And let your caution be more intense than your greed and avarice.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	Nor should you presume anything about it without subsequent certain knowledge which verifies among you that for which the outcome is praiseworthy.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And employ for all your patients the art of prognosis and indication concerning what is conducive to their recovery appropriately.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in that lies for you help in acquiring fame and glory, memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, my sons, with his understanding and not withhold from you guidance and insight: for that is in his hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I indeed arranged this Chapter by distinguishing it into Chapters, as preceded in the Chapter of Cauterization, from the neck down to the feet: so that your search for what you want from it and need may be alleviated.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	On the treatment of water that accumulates on children's heads.
Caput I.	Chapter 1.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	You should know that this illness often befalls children at birth: or when the midwife grips the child's head without carefulness.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And whenever it also happens from an unknown hidden cause which is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I myself have not seen this sickness among others but only in children; and death hastened for all whom I saw it in; therefore, that sight seemed to me to preclude intervention in the matter.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I have indeed seen among them a boy whose head was filled with water, and his head was growing larger every day until he could no longer sit up by himself due to the size of his own head; and this wetness increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this dampness, it either gathers between the skin and skull; or it gathers beneath the skull bone above the brain.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the procedure for this is that if there is dampness between the skin and skull, and the abscess is small, then you must make an incision into the middle of the head in a single line across its width; and let the length of the cut be about two finger-widths long until the liquid runs out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	And this is the shape of a sharp, thin knife.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If therefore the dampness is more increased, and the abscess larger, then make two such incisions in this manner.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the dampness is beneath the skull bone and you can tell because you see the joints of the skull opened on all sides; and water is pressed down when you compress it with your hand towards the inside, and this is not hidden from you: then you must make three incisions in the middle of the head, arranged like this.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after making the incision, extract all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then bind the incisions with cloths and rags.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	After that, apply wine and oil to it from above until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then loosen the bindings and treat the wound with stitches, and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not leave off binding his head with bandages.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	Feed the invalid with dry food of little moisture until his member is strengthened and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	Another method of incision is to consider where the size of the abscess appears and the collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	Because sometimes it is more in the occipital bone or in the forehead, or on the right or left side.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Therefore, ascend with the incision where the abscess and water accumulation appear to you, and split it as best you can.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	Take note not to cut an artery and cause a flow of blood; the invalid may die from that flow with evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	On incising the arteries which lie behind the ears.
Caput II.	Chapter 2.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When catarrhs happen to a person's eyes or chest and it is protracted and the treatment with medicines does not help, then the ultimate cure for that person lies in incision of these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore when you want to make an incision into them, the invalid ought to bow his head down.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then scrape the place with a rough cloth so that the arteries appear.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then let the invalid bind his neck tightly with any piece of cloth he has.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then consider where the vein pulses.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And their places are the depressed areas behind the ears; rarely is it hidden except in some people.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark with wax on both; and cut each with a spatoula sharpened on both sides, the incision reaching to bone, and let it be as wide as the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you wish, introduce the spatula beneath the artery, and cut it open towards the upper side with an incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be about two joined fingers.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the vein is cut, blood flows out in pulsating manner, jumping up frequently into the inside.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	But if the artery does not appear to the touch, then you should measure from the ear the quantity of three finger-widths.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark it with encaustic wax, and find up to the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And that which ought to be emitted from the blood is six ounces, and perhaps you emit more or less of it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All that according to the quantity which appears to you from the strength of the patient, and the fullness of their artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then look at the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if anything remains down to the bone, then cut it away so that a warm abscess does not occur; then bind up the wound with linen cloths.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with ointment until it is healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	On the extraction of arteries which are in temples.
Caput III.	Chapter III.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When it happens to a man that he has an old hemicrania, or acute catarrh on account of acrimonious humours, and hotness in the temples, or ancient soda, very severe, and things similar to them: and when one is treated with methods of medical cure, but does not recover from it: then we have come across in these sicknesses extraction of arteries out of the temples, or cauterization of them, as we have related.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	The method for this operation is to shave the hair from the cyst and direct attention towards the artery which can be seen protruding from it.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	It is apparent to you from its pulse and rarely hidden unless in a few men or severe coldness.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	If it is hidden from you, the patient should tightly bind their head with any cloth; then rub the area with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Alternatively, they should steam the place with hot water until it becomes apparent to you by clear signs.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take the spatula I made earlier.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Use it to scrape away skin easily until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Now drop a hook into it and extract it upwards until you remove it from the skin and make it escape all the clothes underneath.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If however, the artery is thin; then roll it up with the tip of the hook.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Next cut away from it according to the length its ends extend and retract so that there is no bleeding.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it's not cut away and severed, the blood will not stop flowing entirely.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then remove six ounces of blood until three remain.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If the artery is large you should tie it in two places with a double strand of strong silk thread or tough cord so that putrid matter does not spread to it before the wound heals and cause bleeding.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut away the excess tissue between the two ligaments.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do it at that moment, or soon after.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize it with a knife-shaped cautery tool down to the bone; until its ends have been cut and it remains in place of the same operation.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And this is better unless if the patient has a fever or a warm constitution.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	For the cautery is one of those things which help to dry up moistness.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	So it provides better assistance.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And after the arteries have been extracted, it is necessary to fill up the place with old cotton; and irregular pegs should be placed on top of them.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after cleaning, it should be treated with dry medications that promote flesh growth; as well as lint dressings until the wound has healed.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If during the operation a flow of blood from an artery should occur, then hurry to cut it off with the cautery tool or fill up the place with wax; and squeeze your hand until the bleeding stops.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	If none of these is available to you, then place your finger over the spot until the blood clots.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And bathe the place with very cold water until the sharpness subsides and it contracts as needed.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And for the easier and gentler method of extracting arteries, it is to cauterize the vein with this tool having two knives; with the sharpness of the two blades similar to that of almagdate.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	However, they are much less sharp than two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	Since if they were as sharp as two knives, it hastens cold for both: and does not cut meat with speed.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	As there is a bit of thickness in them, the heat of the fire is held within and meat is cut quickly; with this, therefore, work is better, lighter, and easier.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space between the two knives be equal to the thickness of a finger; after you have marked two spots with encaustic: place both very hot until they reach the mouth and cut the vein at two places, so that what is between its ends is extended.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For these do not heal completely with this caustic.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And here is the form of the caustic.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	Paragraph on treating constant acute inflammation of eyes with tears.
Caput IIII.	Chapter four.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When tears are constant and there is a flow from veins that are on the outside of the head; if you do not apply any medicine to treat it with drugs, and see that the patient's face has already turned red, feeling ants crawling in their forehead: and their eyes are strained, wet so that now their lashes have been worn away by corrosion, and eyelids heated from the sharpness of tears. Then ancient doctors required this operation for treating them; they named this treatment 'with a sword'.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And it is as you prescribe to the patient to shave hair that is on their forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three incisions on the forehead evenly spaced along its length; let each incision be about two fingers long and have one incision at the midpoint of the forehead equidistant from the nose in length, a second according to the length slightly from the movement of the lizards, and a third from another side: and beware of cutting any arteries which are on either side; extend your hand from the junction of the two jaws, and let all the space of the incision be three connected fingers in quantity: and have ready for you a piece of sponge or many dry cloths with which to dry the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then introduce a spatula with two sharp ends of this shape that follows.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the first incision that is from the side of the temple up to the second incision, and scrape with it all the skin which lies between the two incisions, together with any scar which may be over the bone.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do likewise from the middle incision up to the second one.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then extract this spatula and introduce into the first incision again another implement which is called a sharp scalpel with one side blunt, not sharp on the other side.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place its sharp side towards the flesh and bone attached with skin, and its blunt side towards the bone; push it until you reach the middle incision; and cut through all the vessels which run from the head down to the eyes: except for what continues beyond the incision up to that point where the skin appears.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do likewise in the middle incision up to the other one.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And after an equal quantity of blood flows out, squeeze the areas with clotted pieces of sponge.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place a piece of old cotton lint over every crack and put on top of it compresses soaked in wine, oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And see to it that no hot abscess develops.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	On the third day, loosen the bandage and apply a great deal of liquid with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with healing balm and other things that cure wounds until it is healed.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	On the treatment of acute tearing and catarrh affecting the eyes due to internal head conditions.
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When someone has acute, bitter, persistent catarrh and you see their eyes are tired, small, and their vision is already weakened; and the eyelids have become ulcerated, hair falls out from them, and there is sharp, painful head pain in the depths of the skull causing sneezing: then take from these symptoms that this material and the catarrh do not arise except from many veins.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And the best cure for them is this:
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it is necessary to advise the patient to shave their forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make an incision in the forehead, one crack in the middle or another slightly across, and start with a fissure from the left temple to the right; let the incision be made down to the bone; stretch out your hand from the temporal muscles which move during chewing until you feel the bone. Dry all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between the two lips of the crack with old cotton or linen strips.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then press down from above with gauze pads; soak the pads with wine and oil to prevent hot abscesses.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you remove it, and see that the hot abscess has now diminished; then it is necessary to rub the bone until flesh begins to grow on it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then treat it with a drying regimen that makes flesh grow; for instance if you take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony, and prepare a plaster from these, apply it to the birth of flesh on such wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	On the cure for that which falls into the ear.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Everything that falls into the ear is one of four types: either a mineral stone; or something like a stone, such as iron and glass; or it is from a plant, such as chickpeas and beans; or it is a liquid substance, such as water, vinegar and similar things; or some kind of animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When therefore a stone or stony substance falls into the ear from something that is not added to it nor grows in the ear, expose the ear to the sun; if you then see the stone, drop into the ear some of either oil of violets or jasmine.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then perform its extraction and make him sneeze with a powder puff, and close his nostrils at the approach of the sneeze after you put around the ear a wad made from cloths or wool, and stretch out the ear upwards.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	Many times it comes out with this cure.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	But if it does not come out, then perform its extraction with forceps (or pincers); which look like this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If he walks with it, it's good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then administer its extraction with a slender blind hook of little curvature.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If therefore it does not exit through that, then make a copper tube, and insert the end of the tube into the ear hole very deeply, and plug what is in the circuit of the tube with softened wax mixed with oil, so that there may be no way for wind except by the tube; then extract it by your strong drawing force of breath.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	For indeed many times it exits with what we have related.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	But if it does not exit this way: then take from helkalimbat, or from wisco, that is, prepared gluten with which birds are caught, a small thing: and place it at the end of a stick after you wrap around it a rag decently placed: then insert it into the ear hole with ease, after you dry out the ear from moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If therefore it does not exit with all that we have related, then hasten to cut before a hot abscess or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the way of cutting is such that one should weaken it first with a leech on its head: and draw out blood from it according to the measure of its strength.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the patient sit between your hands, and turn their ear upwards, and find a small cut in the root of the ear by its fat in a depressed place there: and let the cut be of lunar figure until you reach the bone: then remove it with what is possible for you from instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then sew up the cut by your hour with speed, and treat it until it is healed.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	If the substance that has fallen into the ear is one of the grains which grow and swell up, then proceed with its removal.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	If it does not yield to you for its removal, then take a thin, slender spatula like this one: [insert diagram here].
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	Use it to scrape out that type of grain which has fallen into the ear and do not attempt its removal until you think that the grain is softened by the moisture of the ear canal; instead, break it up into many pieces first: then remove these fragments with a hook or a slender probe or through suction, as we have said, for its removal will be made easier.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	For water which has entered the ear, the patient must first sneeze repeatedly while holding his nostrils closed; he should then fill his ear with warm old oil and lie on the side where the water is.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If it comes out through this process then it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if it does not come out: then take many stones the length of a finger, thin and smooth, and heat them slightly over fire; and the patient should introduce one of these into his ear canal and jump on to his foot on that side while striking with another stone against the stone which is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	He must not cease doing this with stone on stone until all the water comes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And once the water comes out like this, you should take a piece of dry straw or reed and introduce one end into the ear canal while lighting the other end with fire until it is mostly burnt away.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then repeat with another reed and do this several times until all the water has come out; and remove it along with the cannula as described above, from the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	When extracting an animal that has entered the ear, if it is of a small body, such as a flea, and similar to it, take care of it as I said in the division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is of a large body, which can be sensed: then proceed with its extraction using forceps and hooks; and its removal will be easier than all those that are retained inside the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	When extracting worms that have been generated inside the ear, and you treat it with what we said in the division and in the treatise of distillations, and your treatment does not work; then you must examine the ear in the sun.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If therefore something of the worms appears there, then remove it with forceps or with fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	If however nothing appears there, then take a cannula of this form, narrow below and wide above; and introduce the fine end into the ear to the extent that the patient can tolerate it; then suck strongly with it.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do this several times until all the worms have come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	If however they do not obey you with their exit, then wrap some wax around the circumference of the cannula as I said for the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	If they do not come out with what we have said, then apply the distillations that the ancients already knew for killing worms; and you will find it in the treatise of distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your discharge be with oil and medicines poured into the ear using this instrument, whose form is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	Make it like you see it from silver or brass, narrow below with a small hole, wide above.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Let the plunger that is inside the cavity of the pipe be eccentrically made from brass.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a rod and wrap its end with cotton suitably; then pour oil or juice or any of these medicines that you want into the pipe; let it be placed in the ear; then insert the rod with the cotton above and express it by compressing it with your hand moderately until oil is pushed into the cavity of the hearing organ, and the patient feels it inside; and what is infused into the ear should now be heated a little over fire: and avoid anything that drips cold into it; for medicines do not tolerate such.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	§ On the cure of obstruction of the ear.
Caput VII.	Chapter 7.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Sometimes some infants leave their mothers' wombs unpierced.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And it also happens that some people have blockage of the ear due to injury or tissue growing inside them.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this blockage sometimes occurs at the bottom of the ear cavity which sight cannot follow; and sometimes it happens towards its outer openings a little, where sight can trace them.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	Therefore the one which occurs at the bottom of the ear and which sight cannot grasp is difficult to heal in most cases.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And for the one which follows vision, you must place the patient's ear in the sun, and look into it; then if you see an opaque appearance, open it with a fine spatula whose form is as follows, its end being somewhat wide and slightly pointed: and let the remaining part of the spatula be two smooth sides so that it does not injure the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If therefore the opacification is flesh born in the ear canal: then grasp it with a fine hook, and cut it gently but firmly until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	But if the opacity is deep within the ear: then take a fine and smooth probe, heat it with fire for a moment, and insert it into the ear canal.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If you perceive the opacity with the instrument which the patient found difficult to hear, attempt its opening gently; and be careful not to injure the ear nerves.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then place into the ear a linen plug to fit the size of the opening you have wrapped with Egyptian ointment; do this for several days until you are sure that the wound has healed.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take linen, soak it in rosewater, sprinkle over it some pounded Egyptian ointment powder and use this.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	But if you see the ear already forming a pustule, then remove the linen and leave it with another piece of linen which has been wrapped in cerate made from rose oil until the abscess becomes warm; after that take care of it until it is healed.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If however there is an outflow of blood, then soak a sponge or cloth in cold water and place it over the ear; and use the rest of the treatment described previously in the section on distillations to stop bleeding.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	The treatment for inflammation of the eyelids.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These inflammations which occur on the eyelids of the eye, sometimes are wet, and sometimes they are dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore you should hold them with forceps; or with a hook, and cut them out from their roots with a small knife.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place on the affected area some powdered ginger.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	But if any blood flows from them, then cauterise them with a fine lens-shaped cautery iron.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And to cauterise them is best after cutting.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For often they return when some of their root remains.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterised with fire, those roots are burnt, and do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	The treatment for pimples on the eyelids of the eye.
Caput IX.	Chapter 9.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	It often happens on the eyelids that there is something similar to a pimple in its strength and hardness, and for this reason it is called a pimple; and it is an accumulation of thick moisture on both upper and lower eyelids.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	The operation for them is as follows: you should then consider whether it is a pimple proceeding from the eyelid which appears on its surface and moves around in every direction, and whose substance is soft.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Therefore make an incision across it lengthwise.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then scrape out its contents from every side with ease until nothing remains.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then hang it with a hook and cut it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	However, if its removal is not prepared for you unless after you penetrate the eyelid with a slight incision, then it harms the patient somehow.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	But if the crack is large: then gather it with stitches: and take care of it until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, no harm will come to you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	For the ointment restores it and fleshes it out.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if the pebble is sloping towards the inner depths of the ear towards its interior surface, then turn the eyelid back and hang the pebble with a hook; besides which you need an incision, and press it from every side.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	But if the eyelid is stretched by an incision, it does not harm at all.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after the pebble's incision with saltwater: and take care of the place along with that which fleshes it out until the patient heals.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	On curing axillary swelling in eyelids.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axillary swelling is fat that forms under the eyelids of the upper eyelid; it happens most often to children, and it burdens their eyes, cataracts occur in them at daybreak, and they are unable to look at sunlight because tears run into their eyes, for this reason you see them lying down on their faces all the time, and sleeping on them, and their eyelids under their eyebrows are wet, which inflammation has already covered; and indeed the eminence of Axillary Swelling is apparent to the eye, and when you press that place with your fingers, you feel axillary swelling between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	The method of this operation is for the patient to place their head on your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a linen cloth and prepare some lint on it, and make from this lint a circle of the same size as the area around the navel on all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place this on them and press with your fingers from all sides so that the navel gathers in the middle of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle of this moisture with a knife-like scalpel for splits across its width and do not make a split greater than that made during bloodletting in depth.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or you should split the skin entirely until you reach the navel because in many cases the navel proceeds from a split according to the shape of a piece of white suet.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Extract it therefore with a cloth that you have saturated between your fingers to the outside and turn your hand back and forth until it has been dispersed and take care not to insert into any splits so as not to reach the eye with your knife-like scalpel and damage it.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	But if the navel does not appear to you at the start of the split then insert into it a little with some ease until the navel proceeds.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract it as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then immerse the cloths in vinegar and water and place them on this spot, and bind it with bandages.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And from some people there are those who rub salt and place it into the cavity of this split so that what remains of this moisture is dissolved.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it has healed.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	If there is a warm abscess on a location, treat it with soothing plasters until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	The ways of the twitching eye, that is, when the eyelid softens the eye, causing it to wrinkle as it shouldn't.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When extra hairs grow on the eyelids beyond the natural course of hair growth and they thicken: these then harm the eye and cause symptoms such as frequent tears, softening of the eyelids, and whiteness until it becomes a reason for loss of sight.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	The twitching eye is indeed treated in four ways.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cauterisation with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with sharp medicine, as mentioned earlier in the chapter on cauterisation.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	The twitching eye is treated by incision and suture.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or with tubes, as I will explain.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	It is necessary to place the patient's head in your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eye's eyelid with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If it is thus turned, that is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if not: introduce a needle into it, which has a thread attached from the lower part of the eyelid, and make the needle with thread penetrate from above, and have this be near the hairs themselves, that is, near the edge of the eyelid where the hair grows: and draw the thread upwards along with the eyelid, and turn it with your finger.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find on the inner side of the eyelid under the added hairs with a spatula inserted from the greater tear duct to the lesser tear duct.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then extract the thread and place underneath a small piece of cotton or cloth; then mark over the eyelid with hot wax in the form of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	However it is necessary that the shape be made according to its size and elevation of the eyelid; since this differs among people.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	For there are some who require that an incision be made from the eyelid of significant size according to the amount which softens from the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then with a spatula find the two lines which you marked and begin from the greater tear duct to the lesser tear duct and let there be one fissure close by the natural hairs, of about the thickness of a spoke.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then introduce a hook into one of two corners of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then scrape all of it off.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then bring together the two lips with a needle and fine wool thread; wipe off any blood and stick down any excess threads over the eyebrows using some sticky stuff if you wish to do so; otherwise don't worry about it.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then leave the suture and threads in place for three or four days; afterwards care for it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, leave the wound without suture and care for it with something that dries and tightens it.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid will be raised by the seal of the wound and its closing; but it shall be better still.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	The ancients taught this method of treatment.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	However, there is concern for the patient, and it results from good work, and there is no fear in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And there is another method in Ataxmir as well: it is to make a sign on the eyelid in the shape of a myrtle leaf, as we described.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then lift the eyelid with three separate or combined hooks, according to this shape that follows, then cut away what is superfluous with small scissors, according to this shape, with equal cutting.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	But if you are unable to hold the hook and it does not equalize: then take a needle in which is a thread, and insert it into the middle of the figure; and insert another thread near the larger lachrymal, and a second thread near the smaller lachrymal; and gather between your fingers the threads with equality.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then lift your hand with equal elevation; and lift the skin over which is marked the boil, as we described.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bring together the two lips of the wound with stitches; and take care of it until it is healed.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	If however an abscess occurs at your incision or a crack: soothe that abscess with a compress and similar things, from soothing ointments.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And sometimes it happens also to the eyelid, that its hairs turn inwards.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	It is therefore necessary that you use on it what we said about incisions; but stitching is more artistic for both.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	On the treatment of Ataxmir with tubes.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And it is necessary that you turn back the eyelid and split open the wound inside, as I have described.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then craft two thin canes or sticks with a length equal to the eyelid and a width less than that of a spatula, and you have already cut into both ends on either side where you hold the thread.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then gather each of them carefully over the excess eyelid tissue and tightly bind together both canes on either side with a strong strapping, leaving it in place for several days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For the skin will die off once bound, it will darken, and rot away until it falls by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If then you delay, cut it with scissors.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	Once consolidated, lift the eyelid, but do not pluck any hairs.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the form of two canes which you will make according to this figure, with respect to length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	Regarding the removal of hairs inside the eye using a needle.
Caput XII.	Chapter 12.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The procedure is to take up a thin needle and thread it with fine, soft silk.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then gather its ends together and knot each with a very fine knot; the length of thread should be one palm.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then fasten another thin thread with flax underneath at the short end, and knot its ends if you like.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then have the patient place their head on your lap and be close to the sun so that the operation is illuminated: since it is a delicate or minute operation.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then introduce the needle with the thread into the root of the eyelid and make it penetrate the eyelid quickly until you extract it above a natural eyelash.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then pull the eyelash upwards using the thread and introduce that eyelash into the needle; if there is one or two or three, no more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then pull your hand with it until the eyelash exits along with the thread from the eyelid alongside a natural eyelash.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	But if the thread is pulled and the eyelash does not exit with it, pull the thread downwards with the filament you have tied onto it until the thread exits from the upper hole and see it by eye; then pull the thread and filament and extract both of them, close the eyelid and leave it closed for two or three days until the eyelash attaches to its place and flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the eyelash is short then either attach to it a long one from the natural eyelashes and lift them together or leave it until it grows longer and then raise it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	On the treatment of an abscess which occurs on the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this abscess occurs in the eye it is called a Leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this abscess is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	An accidental abscess thus arises from the healing of an injury or incision or cauterization or similar things.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the method of operating on it is for you to cut open that union and separate its lips, and place between them a linen covering, and bind it until it is healed.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And you should not use things that dry and constrict for its treatment; for if you do so, the Alxatrati will return worse than it was before. Instead, use things that soften, such as fenugreek: and gargle with water in which althea has been cooked, flaxseed: and diaproton ointment, which has been liquified with one of the oils: and wrap with this linen covering, and treat (the wound) with it.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And your aim is to use all skill at your disposal to ensure it does not heal with the same form as before.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And this operation we have described is not a complete correction of the Alxatrati, so that it does not return with the original shape and form.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	§ On the treatment of an Alxatrati which occurs on the lower eyelid; it is a wrinkling or contraction upwards towards the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 14.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This Alxatrati which occurs on the lower eyelid is what is truly called an Alxatrati.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is either natural or accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And the accidental type occurs from a wound, or tear, or burn, or something similar.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the method of operating on it is to take a needle with double thread and dip it into the flesh; then make it penetrate from left lachrymal bone to right lachrymal bone until the thread comes out at both ends.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then stretch the flesh upwards with a needle, and cut it with a spatula that is one span wide.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	So if the shape of the eyelid returns to normal, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, take a rod and place it in the slit, then turn with it the eyelid: and make two slits on the inner side of the eyelid, and let the ends of the two slits be from the two corners of the incision until they meet and form an angle; until when they are brought together this shape is made, and it is the Greek letter lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that flesh by the amount which is its sharp side below from what follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then bring together the separated parts: or sew it up with wool thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then treat them with what we have said, of medicines that soften, and with lint, until they heal.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if any aloes fall out from the slit or suture, or are cauterised: then you must make a flat slit underneath the eyelashes of the eyelid, also according to what has preceded.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between the two lips with lint, as we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the essence of the treatment for aloes, when it is on top or below, is to proceed with the operation according as it has been prepared from the form of the aloes.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For it has many variations in form: and a prudent surgeon prepares his skill with whichever way is possible for him until he returns the shape to its natural form or close to it; and even the patient himself, according as suits him from the operation and instruments in most situations.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	On the adhesion of the eyelid to the conjunctiva, or to the cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	Sometimes this adhesion occurs in many people, so that the upper eyelid becomes adhered to the white of the eye, and prevents it from its natural movements.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	You should therefore insert the end of a thin stick under the eyelid and lift it up; or extend it with a hook; then cut the adhesion with a very fine spatula which is not sharp like a cutting spatula, but rather blunt: so as not to disturb the patient during the operation, and remove the spatula, and hurt the eye with its sharpness; and let your incision be such that you scrape off that adhesion with ease, until the eyelid returns to its natural shape, and the adhesion is healed.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour salt water into the eye, wash it with water; or distill into it from a sieve made of this, of zinja dissolved with water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate between the eyelid and the eye with a piece of fine linen; and place over the eye wool soaked in egg white; and after three days use sief and solidatui until it is healed.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	On the incision of the nail and the prominence of fleshy tissue over the tear ducts.
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	Know that the nail is of two kinds.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Or it is nervous, and is like a hard, thin sieve.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nervous, similar to white frozen moisture; which when it touches cold iron, or you try to grasp it with a hook, it breaks off, and the hook does not become fixed in it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	Both types do not begin unless from the larger lacrimal, as far as it gradually goes, until it covers vision and prevents light and eye movement.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of operating its incision is: that the patient puts their head on your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open his eyes and lift the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then gather the claw with a small hook and extend it upwards.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take a needle and insert into it a hair from a horse, cow or goat; and let the thread be strong, and double the end of the needle a little, and fix it in the middle of the claw: and pierce it with the needle, and tie the claw with the thread, extending it upwards: and scrape with the hair the side of the claw that follows the pupil as if you are plucking it with hair right to its extremity.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then cut the remainder at the root of the lacrimal with a fine spatula or small scissors: and leave the natural lacrimal flesh so that there is no persistent course of tears from its incision.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And sometimes the claw is extended with just a hook: or with thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then scrape it with a gentle spatula of this shape.
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And be careful not to touch the spatula with the hard tunic, lest there is a rupture in it and the pupil is perforated.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then after the incision, throw into the eye some crushed salt, or something made of zinjar, and leave it until the next day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with whatever is necessary until it heals.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	If the hoof is not loose and you cannot insert a needle into it, nor does a hook penetrate it, then this type of hoof condition is often treated with medicines and heals as I described in the section on divisions.
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	If you wish to cut it, then open the patient's eye and take a fine, soft, blunt spatula of this shape.
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And scrape the hoof from above with the edge, carefully.
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	If you see that it becomes thin and breaks up, and the edge presses into it, then drop into the patient's eye every hour from your freshly-made infusion of zedoary, or red lead, or bruised salt: and bind their eyes until the next day.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then repeat this procedure over it until all of it is removed.
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	Unless there is also a hot abscess in their eye; then leave it alone and treat the abscess until it heals.
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat this procedure over it with the edge until it heals.
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.
