However, if a lump of the tear duct flesh is causing great harm to the eye, hang it with a hook and cut off its end; but do not go too far in your cutting so as to avoid damaging the tear ducts.
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then drop into the tear duct some red lead or an infusion made from zedoary until it heals.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	§ On cutting the Alguardeen ulcer and flesh growing in the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter Seventeen.
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	A reddish fleshy growth is sometimes born in the eyes of some humans, either composed on top or overlapping until it covers the pupil, approaches, or constricts above the eyelids and perhaps turns the eyelids outwards; and it resembles a rose bay.
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the operation on this is also such that the patient should put their head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open their eyes and gather all that flesh with suitable hooks; hold it with one pair of forceps or tweezers.
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then cut the flesh first until all of it is finished with a scalpel.
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	And take care to avoid the eye so that you do not injure it during the operation; and let your cut be with a lancet, which we described in cutting fingernails, or with small scissors like those used for trimming eyelashes, as will come according to its form after this chapter.
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	When your cut is complete and all the flesh has been removed, then fill the eye with ground salt; or distill into it red powder and similar corrosive medicines; and put on the outside of the eye a fresh egg white, so that it may be protected from hot pus.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	But if any of the flesh remains and hot blood rules you, and you fear a hot pus; then leave the eye alone and treat it with what soothes the pus.
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	Then repeat over it with an operation until it is healed.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	And do likewise with additional flesh that happens to appear in the eye of this type.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	However, it is necessary that you treat all weak eyes by surgery using iron instruments, either via the natural route or via an accidental one; and do not insert your hand into any of these operations until you have seen that that limb can tolerate that operation.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	On the discharge of pus from the eye.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	Pus is red veins that form over the eye, preventing its function; and it weakens the eye with each passing day.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	You must therefore first consider whether the eye with pus is strong and has no other illness besides the pus; then you can discharge that pus from it.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And you should instruct the patient to place their head in your lap.
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then you should lift those veins with one hook or two according to your discretion; and let the hooks be slender doubled ones of this shape, or two graded into one body of this shape.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then you should collect those veins with slender pincers carefully and wipe the blood away every hour until you see that they have been removed from the eye and broken up; and be careful not to injure the eye with the ends of the spatulas.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	And you should conduct your surgery at midday under the sun's rays and be very strong in your actions; so that you do not cut except for those veins.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	And when you have finished, then you should instill into the eye either green or red sieved liquid; so that its sharpness eats away at whatever is left of the pus.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	If you cannot collect it all in that hour, then apply eye-plasters to it with what will ease the eye pain; leave it for a few days until its pain subsides and is sealed off from pus by heat, then repeat this procedure on it until it heals.
Et haec est forma forficis.	And here's the form of the scissors.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	On setting an arm bone back into place at the nose.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	Physicians call an Arissati fistula which you treat with the cauterizer or with a burning caustic medicine according to what has preceded its account.
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	And if it does not heal, then there is no skill in it; unless you cut over the abscess at its birth and extract all the moisture that is in it and the pus until the bone is revealed.
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	When therefore the bone is revealed and you see it corrupted or blackened, then scrape it with an instrument whose form is this:
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	And it is called the rough-head.
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	Let it be made of hardened iron and let its head be round like an awl which is pitted with a file or the fine pitting of a chisel; and place it over the corrupted part of the bone.
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then roll it between your fingers and press your hand for a while until you know that the corruption is now scraped off; and do this several times.
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the place with drying, styptic medicines.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	If therefore the place is consolidated and flesh grows there and the course of pus is cut off; and it remains for forty days without renewal or abscessing or mishap then you will know that it has healed.
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	And if not, then there is no skill in him unless he can bring the fistula to the nostril opening, according to this form.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	And it is to uncover the bone from the second with iron or sharp medicine; and when the bone is uncovered, then take a drill in this form, let its tip be iron, triangular: and its wood should be a pyramid that tapers off at one end as you see.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then place that over the bone itself, let it be close to the tear duct; and extend your hand away from the eye a little.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then turn your hand with the drill until it penetrates the bone and you feel weakness there; by this air escaping from that place when he holds his hand over his nose.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	Therefore then restore that place with astringent drying medicines as I taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	When flesh forms then hardens in that place, the matter which was discharged outwards returns to the nose; and thus it is lighter on the weak spot.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	§ On reducing eye prominence.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When the eye is prominent with its entire self and no harm or loss of sight occurs, then you must relieve this weakness; thereafter bleed it; afterward place leeches on the neck without any incision but only by their suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Then apply over the eye an ointment made from gum arabic (acacia), aloe vera gel, frankincense resin and scotch myrtle resin.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	Then bind the eye over with a plaster containing many fine feathers.
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	The method of dressing with compresses is as follows: take soft cloths, many of them, and fold each cloth four times; make many such folds; then place them one on top of the other according to the size required for the eye; finally, bind them firmly in place with a hard cloth.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	Repeat the cupping with suction without scarifying.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	Then remove the cups, and leave the eye bound day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	If however the bandage becomes loose again, it must be tightened considerably; then remove the bandage after a day and night, as we have said.
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	If therefore you see that the eye has regained its normal colour, it is good; and if not, then repeat the poultice, compresses, binding, and cupping until it is healed.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	On incising the white of the eye.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	When a rupture occurs in the white of the eye and then protrudes outside the eyelids like a grain of white matter, disfiguring the face because of it and prompting you to want to cut it, an operation is necessary on it as follows: it must be done by inserting a needle into the root of the white from below upwards.
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	Then introduce another needle with doubled thread from the tear duct side and let it penetrate; leave the first needle where it is.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then cut the doubled thread and bind with it the white around the needle; tie it very tight.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then extract the needle and place over the eye wool soaked in albumen of egg; leave it until the thread comes away with the white.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then treat the eye with something that strengthens it until the wound heals.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And sometimes, when the eye is pressed from all sides with a circular cloth until it produces a great swelling.
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then it is pierced with a thin needle that reaches the depth of the eye, and the white liquid flows out, and the eye collapses, and you must enter it immediately; then press on it until it heals.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	On the cure of alcomnia.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This disease called alcomnia is nothing but pus that accumulates in the eye, like water dripping down, and it is not itself.
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	And the way to treat it is to have the patient sit on a prepared seat or remain upright.
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Then take his head in your hands from both sides, and move it until you see pus reach the lower part of the eye with your own eyes.
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then it is bound so that it does not flow down, and the vision is restored; and the patient sees things as he used to see them: and if it does not go below [the eye], know that it is water.
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	If however the pus does not descend as we have said, then have the patient sit between your hands.
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	Then take a thin needle and search with it above the corneal flap near the junction of the conjunctiva with the cornea until pus comes out.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When it does come out, then drip into the eye warm water in which you have mixed honey; or water in which you have already boiled fenugreek and honey; then treat it with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	The treatment for water coming down into the eye, or cataract.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII.
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	I have already mentioned the different types of water in division, and what is suitable for boring with words that declare and explain it, then take the same according to health.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Therefore, you should make the patient sit opposite your hands on a square facing a light near the sun: and tie their healthy eye, pulling it tightly closed; then with your right hand close the eyelid of their left eye if that is where the water is, or the right eye if it is in the right.
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then take some alum with your right hand if the eye is left, or your left hand if it is right.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Next place the tip of the alum close to the white part of the eye near the edge of the pupil; then push it gently and revolve your hand with it until you feel that the alum has reached the empty space.
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	The distance that the alum travels must correspond to the depth of the space between the pupil and the end of the black part, which is the crown of the eye.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	You will see it within the pupil because of the brightness of the cornea.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Next, place the alum at the spot where the water is located.
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then push it downwards with one finger after another.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	If the water comes down immediately, then as soon as the patient opens their eyes they will be able to see it alongside the alum in their eye.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then rest for a little while.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	If therefore water descends, then place it down again, except that almagda comes out of it.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	When therefore it is mixed, and does not rise up: then extract the almagda with ease; and you turn your hand little by little.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve something of clear crystal salt in water; and wash the eye within with it.
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then place outside the eye a whole piece of cloth or wool dipped in rose oil and egg white; and bind with it the healthy eye.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	We however, and those who are of our time, place on it powdered cumin with egg white.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	If almagda does not obey you and enter the eye due to its hardness, since it is of human origin, whose eye is very hard; then you must take a spoon called an *alberid*, which has this form:
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	Therefore pierce with it only the conjunctiva and do not push your hand into the hole; and there is nothing else for you to do except make a way to the almagda in a subtle place.
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then introduce the almagda as we have said.
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	And at the end of your work, prepare for the patient a decently-made bedroom in which they can sleep on their back in a dark house; and prevent them from all movement and coughing: and give them food that soothes their nature; and do not let them move their head to the right or left at all.
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	The bandage should remain in place according to its placement until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	Then you must loosen it in that dark room, and test his sight; make him see things.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	Then apply the bandage again up to the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	And it is not necessary to do so at the time of treatment or immediately after the operation; rather one must avoid it because water rises quickly through intense heat.
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	If however a warm abscess occurs then one must loosen the eye dressing before the seventh day and treat it with what will settle the abscess until settled; after that restore his sight completely and place over his face some sort of visual aid to regulate his vision for a few days, while he is in that dark room.
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	Then let him leave the house gradually and return to his home.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	And remember that the student is not to be exempted from the sight of the procedure on several occasions because he will then dare to perform the surgery himself.
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And now one of them has come to us from Alayra who said that a water-drawing woman was perforated in Alayra.
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	I therefore have not seen anyone in your land do such a thing nor read about it in any of the ancient books and so it is possible that this may be something new.
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	These are the different kinds of covers for the eye as they should be applied by someone who is ignorant of such things.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	They should be made from copper and the ends must have this same pointed triangular shape and sharp point.
Formae magda.	The shapes are many.
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	On the treatment of flesh growing in the nose.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	Occasionally various fleshly growths appear in the nose, one of which resembles a scorpion with many feet; this is carcinomatous flesh, stony to the touch, dark-coloured: and there is also soft flesh that isn't dark-coloured.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	So when you have soft, trustworthy flesh that isn't carcinomatous, you should make the patient sit between your hands facing the sun with his nostrils open; then cast a hook into those growths and draw them out; then cut what you've got hold of on one side with a sharp thin spatula until you're sure all the flesh is removed.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	But if there's something left which can't be cut off, then scrape it away with one of your fine instruments as painlessly as possible until nothing remains of it.
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	But if there's a lot of bleeding or the patient gets a hot abscess, then give him whatever treatment is necessary; but if it's one of those malignant kinds of abscess then burn it quickly with a red-hot iron until all the blood stops and every bit of flesh is removed.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then after you've cut it out, pour vinegar or water into the nose, or wine.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	But if the patient has an open nose with a discharge down to his palate, then you know he's healthy again.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	If there's no discharge as you'd expect then you know the flesh has grown inside on the upper bones of the nose to which your instruments don't reach with their cutting.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	You should then introduce a thread of linen with some thickness and make many knots in it; place between each knot the length of a finger or less; have the patient insert one end of the thread into their nose together with a stick or similar object that is possible for him, after you've made it similar to an arrow; pull on the other end until it reaches the wound and comes out over his throat.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	And indeed many times boys do the same thing like this at school: and it is an easy task for whoever wants to.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then place two ends of the thread: one end that comes out over the nose, and the other which remained inside the nose.
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	Then with your assistant close the wound with the flesh-hook using the knots which are on the thread.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Do this until you're sure that the flesh is now tied with the knots of the thread.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then remove the thread and place in the nose a linen cloth soaked in Egyptian ointment after cleaning away any blood; do this for three days or more until all of the remaining ointment is worn away by the flesh.
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Then finally put into the nose at the end of the treatment a leaden tube for several days until it heals.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	If however he requires drying treatment, use the following method:
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	For the device used for distillation of oils and other medicines into the nose – make this out of silver or brass; it should be like a small lantern with an opening similar to that of a shell, and its nozzle likewise.
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	And if you wish make it closed like a tube.
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	And the small shell of the instrument for making a head purging, let it be full and exposed: which has a handle at its end, with which you hold it when you heat oil in it, or whatever liquid or fluid.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	And this is the shape of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	On the cure for nose bleeding.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	Often there is born at the end of the nose a lump which becomes larger, and increases with days until the appearance of it becomes ugly.
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	And because of that it is necessary to cauterize it at the beginning of its appearance, and eradicate all of it.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	Then put over the place either a cautery or burning medicine which stands in its place.
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	If therefore the incision of it is delayed until it has grown larger, then consider whether it is stony hard, dark in colour and insensitive; then do not touch it with the iron, for the ulcer is cancerous.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	For I have often seen one who incises this ulcer, and there happens great harm to him who has it.
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	And if the ulcer is soft to the touch, not dark in colour, and you see that incision of it all over is possible, then evacuate the pus, and incise it without fear or dread; and treat the place with what dries and contracts it until it is healed.
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	On the suture of the nose, lip, and ear.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26.
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	You know that when a break in continuity occurs in one of these cartilage pieces, surgery is of little benefit to it, except for some people.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	One should therefore, when something like that happens to someone, consider whether it is a fresh wound with its blood; and then bring together the lips of the wound with suture; then treat the wound until it heals.
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	And if the break in continuity has lips already separated, and each part is made healthy; then one should scrape all parts from their skin until it bleeds.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then bring together the two lips with suture and tighten them, and sprinkle over the blood dragon's blood and crushed frankincense; and place on top of the powders a piece of dauphine plaster, and another from the consolidated plasters; and leave it tied for two or three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then loosen it, and change the medicine; and leave it until the threads fall off by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment until it heals.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	The method of suture is to bring together the break in continuity either with needles as we described for the abdomen; or bring together a break using thread as I have made you aware.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	On removing lumps of lips.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27.
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	Many people often have hard growths like herb seeds inside their lips; and some are smaller, others larger.
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	One should therefore turn the lip over, and cut into every lump of it; then lift it with a hook, and cut it from all sides.
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Fill the place after the incision with a mixture of egg yolk and powdered gallnut until the bleeding stops.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Next, it should be washed with vinegar, and the place where there is a styptic effect should be treated with it until the wounds heal.
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	§ On cutting flesh born on the gum.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28.
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	Many times flesh grows on the gum which the Ancients call Abuluss.
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	Therefore you should hang it with a hook or hold it with forceps and cut it at its root allowing the pus to flow out, or blood if that is what there is.
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Then apply over the place a mixture ground up, or other styptic, drying powders.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	But if that flesh returns after healing as it often does then cut it a second time and cauterise it for it will not return after being cauterised.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	§ On the treatment of teeth with an iron instrument.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29.
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	Sometimes rough, ugly bark-like matter accumulates on the surface of teeth from within and without as well as between the gums; sometimes they turn black or yellow then green until that corruption spreads to the gum making the teeth unsightly.
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	You should make the patient sit between your hands with their head in your lap then scrape away with a knife any bark-like matter you see as well as that which looks like sand: do not stop until nothing is left and do likewise for blackness, greenness and yellowness until they are clean.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	If therefore that which is in them from the beginning of reason be removed, it is good; and if not, then repeat reasoning upon them on another day, a second and third time, until finally you arrive at what you wish to study.
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	And you should know that razors of various forms and many shapes are needed; as is prepared for your operation: for the razor with which the tooth is shaved from below is different to the one used between teeth, according to other shapes.
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	And these forms of razors should be prepared for you as you see them.
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	On the extraction of toothache.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	You should take care to cure the tooth of its pain with all your skill, and proceed slowly in its extraction.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	For there is no substitute for it when extracted; since it is a noble substance: until such time as there can be no excuse for not extracting it, then when the patient is compelled to extract it, you should make sure and confirm that the painful tooth is indeed the culprit.
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	For often the pain deceives the patient, and they think it is a healthy tooth and extract it; yet the pain does not go away until the sick tooth is removed.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	We ourselves have seen this from the operations of blood-letters.
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	When therefore you are sure that the painful tooth itself is to blame, then you should make an incision around it with a small spatula, in which there is something sharp, until the gum is loosened on all sides; then move it with your fingers, or with fine forceps first little by little, until you shake it.
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then place large forceps on those places in a good position, and hold the patient's head between your knees; now you have held them well, so that they do not move; then pull the tooth according to its straightness, so as not to break it.
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	If it does not come out, then take one of those instruments and insert it underneath from all sides gently, and try to move it as you did initially.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	However, if the tooth is perforated or corroded, you must fill that hole with cloth; and tie it tightly with a thin piece of stick so that it does not break when you grasp it with forceps.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	And make sure that you carefully scrape around the gum from all sides.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	You must also be careful with your strength so that you do not break the tooth and a piece of it remains inside causing worse pain for the patient than before.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	Beware of doing what ignorant bloodletters do with their haste and boldness when extracting teeth, other than the methods we have described above.
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	For often they bring about great harm to people when they break teeth and leave some or all of the roots behind; or extract them along with parts of the jawbone, as we have seen many times.
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	After extraction, it should be rinsed with wine or with vinegar and salt.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	If bleeding occurs from the site of extraction (which often happens), then take some powdered frankincense and fill that place with it; if not, cauterize it with a hot iron if you do not have any frankincense.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The shapes of fine forceps with which the tooth is first moved should be long at their tips and short at the handle, thick so that they do not double up when pressed against a tooth: you will see them made of thicker handles, yet when you squeeze them together, they will not pinch themselves nor bend; the tips are to be short and made out of iron or good steel with straight tips. There should be teeth on these, some of which fit into each other and close firmly with a strong grip.
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And sometimes the tips should be made in the shape of the beak of a bird called a stork, which has a strong grip.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	Regarding tooth removal, as well as extraction of fractured jaw bones...
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When a bit of tooth remains and needs to be removed, you should place over the site a poultice with butter for one or two days until the area softens; then introduce into it an algest or forceps: these have tips that are shaped like the beak of a bird called a stork.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	The shape of these forceps is as follows...
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	Their tips should be made like a file on the inside; or like an awl.
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	If it does not obey you and come out with these forceps, then you should cut over the root and remove all the flesh, and introduce a small instrument called a palanca, of this shape...
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	Its tip should be short, thick but not too much so that it does not break.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	If the root comes out through it then that is good; if not, you should help with these other instruments of which the shapes are as follows...
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The shape of the first triangular end, which has some thickness.
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	The shape of the thin triangular end.
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	It is also used with this instrument having two branches, which has the following shape.
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And together with other instruments and tools that have preceded it in regard to teeth extraction.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	It is also helpful to use this instrument which resembles a large hook, of the following shape - twisted triangular end with some thickness so that it does not break; and ensure it is not soaked.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	And know that there are many dental instruments; similarly other tools cannot be counted and a skilful practitioner, skilled in their craft, will invent for themselves the tool which is signified to them by the task and specific illness.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	Since from the many [teeth] there are some for which an instrument has not been described by previous authors owing to their diversity of type.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	If however a jawbone or other bone of the mouth is broken or has decayed then examine it in its place with that which suits him from amongst the instruments and forceps I have described for extracting roots; and assist using a lever of this shape.
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	There should be some thickness to it gradually so that the bone is grasped or held and does not slip away nor slide until the bone comes out; and restore the place with suitable medications for it.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if there is slight decay in the bone then scrape it from its decay and treat it until it becomes healthy.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	On locking prominent teeth above others.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter 32.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When teeth emerge not according to their natural course, it becomes an ugly deformity; especially when this happens with women and girls, namely those of noble birth.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	It is necessary that you give consideration to it.
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	For if a tooth is born after another and does not find its place, or its socket is impossible as well as the filing of it; then pull out this tooth: and if it is attached to another tooth, then cut it together with that other using this instrument which has this form.
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	It is like a small beak, and it is made of very sharp steel.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	And let your incision be made over many days, and because of the hardness of the tooth, and so that no other may be moved from among the teeth.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	But if it is an exposed prominent tooth that needs filing; then file it with a steel file whose form is this.
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	It is all made of steel, and its handle has very small points like the file with which needles are made: with this the tooth is gradually filed over many days easily so that it does not move nor fall out; then soothe it afterwards and finally shave it smooth using some scrapers.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	If there is a tooth from which a part has broken and it injures the tongue; then you must also file that one until its roughness caused by breakage be removed and levelled; and smoothen it so that it does not injure the tongue nor corrupt speech.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	Regarding setting teeth with gold wires.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When the front teeth suffer concussion and commotion due to blows or accidents: and the patient is unable to chew without food falling out; and you have treated them with astringent medicines, but the treatment was not successful; then it is appropriate to bind them with gold wire: since silver turns green and decays after some days, while gold never changes.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let the wire be of moderate thickness and fineness according to the amount that fits between the teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	The form of the binding is as follows: take a length of wire and insert twice its thickness between two healthy teeth; then weave it with both ends of the wire around the loose tooth or teeth until you reach the healthy tooth on the other side.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Then repeat the weaving process back to where you started; and tighten your hand with care and wisdom until it cannot be moved at all: and make sure that your binding is tight around the roots of the teeth so that it does not come loose.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Cut off the excess ends of the wire with scissors; then gather both together and bend them so they are concealed between a healthy tooth and a loose one, taking care not to damage the tongue; finally, leave the binding in place until healing is complete.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	If it comes loose or breaks, bind them with another wire, and it will remain in place for the whole period of healing.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	This is the arrangement of teeth and form of binding for two healthy teeth and two loose ones, as you can see.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	Sometimes it happens that one or two teeth return to their place after falling out and are retained as we have described; but this is only done by a skilled and experienced practitioner.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And sometimes a replacement is made from calf bones; it takes the form of a tooth and is placed where the missing tooth was secured and fastened, as we have said; it remains there and serves for a long time.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	On the incision of the ligament that occurs under the tongue and prevents speech.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	Sometimes this ligament that occurs under the tongue is either natural, with which a person is born, or accidental, resulting from a wound that has already healed.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	And the operation for this is to open the mouth of the patient as wide as you can with your hand, then lift their tongue; next, cut that sinewy ligament horizontally until the tongue is freed from its restraint.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	If there is any hardening and knotting in it due to the healing of a wound, then place a hook on this area and pass the hook across horizontally until you cut through the ligament and release the knot.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And take care not to make an incision too deep into the flesh so as not to cut through the artery there and cause a flow of blood.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then let the trace of the incision be rubbed with rosewater or vinegar or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Next place some flaxen lint under the tongue which the patient should hold there every night; this will prevent a second healing.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	Should any flow of blood occur, then place on the area some pounded egg white.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if the bleeding defeats you, then cauterize the area with a fig-shaped cauterizer appropriate to this; next treat it with the remaining cure until it heals.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	The extraction of a ranula which occurs under the tongue.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	Sometimes there occurs under the tongue a pustule resembling a small frog, preventing the tongue from performing its natural function; and perhaps it grows so large that it fills the mouth.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	And for treating this condition, you should open up the patient's mouth facing towards the sun: then inspect the pustule.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	If you see that it is of a dark or black colour, hard, and the patient feels no pain upon touching it; then do not touch it for it is cancerous.
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	And if it slopes towards whiteness where there is moisture, then thrust into it a hook, and cut it out with a thin scalpel, freeing the whole of it.
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	If blood defeats you during the procedure, then place on it bruised figwort until the bleeding ceases; afterwards return to your surgery, until you have removed it and all of its contents.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Afterwards it should be treated with vinegar and salt: then tend to the wound using appropriate dressings until it is healed.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	The treatment of an abscess in both tonsils.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	Sometimes there occur between the throat and the jaw, two glands resembling cotton balls that sit externally; these are called tonsils: when you treat them with what we have described elsewhere and they do not heal, then consider the following.
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	If it is an abscess that is hard, dark in colour, with little sensation upon touching; then do not touch it with the iron [scalpel].
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	If it is red in color and its root is thick, then do not touch it even with an iron [instrument], fearing a gush of blood; rather leave it until it matures.
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	Then either you will pierce it, or it will rupture by itself.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	And if it is white in colour, round, and its root is slender; then you must cut into it.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	And the procedure is as follows: consider before performing it whether its abscess has cooled to complete quiet or diminished somewhat; then make the patient sit facing the sun with his head in your lap and open his mouth so that a servant takes hold of [the tongue] between his hands, pressing it down with an instrument of this shape.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	It shall be made of silver or copper, thin as a knife.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	When you press it against his tongue with this and the abscess is revealed to you, catching your eye: then take a hook and fasten it into the tonsil and draw it outwards as far as you can without tearing anything from its coverings.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then cut into it with an instrument of the following shape:
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	It resembles scissors; however, its tips are curved so that the opening of each is directed to the point of the other, and care should be taken that it be made of iron-inlaid silver or bronze dipped in alum.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	If this instrument is not present, then cut it with a spatula of this shape:
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	Let one side be sharp, the other blunt.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And after you cut one tonsil, cut the other in the same manner.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	Then after the incision, let the patient gargle with cold water or vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if there is bleeding, let him gargle with water in which boiled pomegranate rind or myrtle leaves and similar astringents have been steeped until the bleeding stops; then treat it until it heals.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	And sometimes other abscesses appear in the throat besides the two tonsils.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	Cut them accordingly, as I have said about the incisions of the two tonsils.
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	Indeed, I once treated a woman for an abscess that had formed in her throat and was causing it to swell, with very little movement; the swelling almost completely blocked her throat, so she could only breathe through a narrow opening. She could no longer eat or drink water, and she would have died within a day or two if left untreated.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	The abscess had grown so much that it sent out two branches until they came out through the nostrils.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	I therefore hurriedly seized one of them with forceps.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	Then I pulled it out, drawing forth a large portion of the abscess.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	I then cut through it where I could reach from within the nostril.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	Then I did the same for what had come out of the other nostril.
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	Then I opened her mouth and pressed down on her tongue; afterwards, I seized the forceps at that abscess, cut a portion of it away without much bleeding, so her throat was cleared out. The woman could immediately drink water again and then she started eating.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	I did not cease to cut out that abscess many times over a long period; and an abscess followed in the place of each one I cut out until it became too extensive along with the one around it.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	I devised a plan and cauterized the abscess between the throat.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	I stood back from adding anything; then I walked away from that side, and did not know what God did with it after me.
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	§ On the cutting out of an abscessed uvula.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 37.
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When a discharge flows down to the uvula and an abscess forms there, and it is long; then it itself is called "perpendicular"; and if it is on the lower part thick and round, then it itself is called "uva".
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When it is treated with what we have said in the division, and the cure does not come about; and you see that the abscess has cooled off from that, and it is thin; then you must cut it out.
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And that which is on it round and bunched together, and has no length, and is bloody or of a dark colour or black, and has no feeling; then you must deepen the cut into it.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	For in that there is fear over the sick person.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	You must therefore when you see it according to the manner I have described from its whiteness and length, make the sick person sit facing the sun; and press his tongue down with an instrument, which has been previously described; then fix a hook into the uvula, and draw it downwards; and cut it off with one of two instruments that I mentioned for cutting out two tonsils.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	You must not cut away any part from it unless it is what naturally protrudes without causing an extension.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	If you remove more of it, you will harm the voice and speech.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	After the incision, use what we have described for incising two tonsils: and treat it until it is healed.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	However, if the patient is afraid of the incision: then you must use skill without fear or trepidation when cauterizing him.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	The manner of the cautery is not proper unless with boiling water: and it is best to put the patient's head on your lap.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then press his tongue with the instrument that we mentioned.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Next, take some of the water that I told you about in the chapter on cauterization, and mix it with unslaked lime, making it neither thick nor thin; fill the hollow part of this instrument, which is shaped like so.
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	Let the end of it that holds the medicine be hollow like the bowl of a spoon.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	Place the instrument with the medicine on the uvula itself: and let the patient lie on his side so that saliva may flow out of his mouth from within the medicine, so that nothing runs down into his throat and harms him.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then hold your hand with the medicine over it.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	You must hold it over the uvula for a space of time equal to half an hour's length until you see that its color has already turned black and the pungency of the medicine has subsided.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	If you wish to apply the plaster and wrap it around the end of the radius bone, pour the plaster mixed with medicine into a tube, and insert the radius with the cast inside the tube until the plaster adheres to the wound.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do this many times until you achieve the desired result with regard to cauterizing the wound.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then leave it; for it dries up and falls off by itself after three or four days.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	If you need to apply more medicine, do so; and after the cauterization, clean around the wound with a plaster soaked in butter, and cleanse it with whatever medicinal ointment is available; then wash it with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And treat the wound externally with embrocations (ointments) and internally with gargles (mouthwashes), until it is healed.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	This type of treatment, then, is more beneficial than cutting open the wound and less frightening.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	Sometimes the wound is even healed with a method gentler than cauterization and incision; it is healed by fumigation (smoke inhalation), as follows.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take chamomile, hyssop, marjoram, rue, savine, wormwood, southernwood and similar herbs; put all or some of them into a glazed pot, cover with vinegar and boil; the pot should have a hole in its middle, over which place an instrument shaped like a ladle.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	It should be made of silver or brass; and insert the end with the pomegranate grains into the patient's mouth until the vapours rise to the wound through the tube, so that the wound is greatly darkened.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Repeat this process over it many times until it dries out.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And be careful not to do this treatment at the beginning of the appearance of abscesses.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	It often adds to the abscess: and you must not do this unless it is at the decline of its hot stage.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	But if you don't have this instrument available to you, then take a reed and attach sheep's skin to its end so the patient's bone is not burnt because the sheep's skin prevents the vapour from burning the bone; and this is good treatment with successful results.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	On extracting thorns and bones from the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Often there is a bone or fish spine or other object stuck in the throat.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	You must therefore extract any object that is visible to the naked eye after you press against their tongue with an instrument under a bright light and then tell them what it is stuck in their throat.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And if you cannot see it and it is hidden in the throat, then you must make the patient vomit before their food has been fully digested by the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps it will come out with whatever is brought up through vomiting.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or have the patient swallow a piece of turnip, or lettuce root, or a dry rusk; or take a piece of dried soft sea sponge and tie it with thread then have them swallow it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When it reaches the place where there are spines or bones and is extracted, then they come out.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If therefore it does not exit with what we have said, then use a lead instrument in this form.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	It should be thicker than a radius and at its end there is a curve that can easily be inserted into his throat; he himself should have his head elevated upwards.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And take care that it does not touch its epiglottis, so that coughing does not happen to him, and push with a bone or spine, or the doctor should insert his hand himself.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	Whatever the patient inserts is better: because of his knowledge about what is attached there; and push down or pull up with his hand holding an instrument, all that is prepared for him until it comes out.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On the removal of leeches.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When a leech is treated with what I said earlier when dividing the cure by medicines and it does not take hold, then look at the patient's throat facing the sun or near the sun after you have pressed its tongue with an instrument as described to you.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If your sight falls upon the leech, remove it with a small hook or with slender forceps as shown to you.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	If it is not possible to do so with those: then take a hollow tube and insert it into the patient's throat near the leech; next, place inside the cavity of the tube a red hot iron over fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this many times; let the patient abstain from water for that whole day.
