Sit superius cannulae ad sublimitatem trahens surdum inuolutum, ut alleuietur super digitum apprehensio eius et ipsius reuolutio.	Place the upper part of the cannula towards the earlobe, drawing it around and upwards so that its grasp is loosened from your finger and its rolling-up.
Et si uis cauteriza Formicam secundum quod praemissum est in cauterizatione Athelil in capitulo de cauterio.	And if you wish to cauterise an ant, do it as has been mentioned earlier regarding the cauterisation of Athelil in the chapter on cautery.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum quae administrantur ad Clisteria in aegritudinibus Ani, et solutionis uentris, et colicae.	On the shapes of instruments that are used for enemas in diseases affecting the rectum, as well as evacuating the belly and treating colic.
Caput LXXXIII.	Chapter 83.
Quandoque Clistere fit ex argento, aut ex aurichalco, aut ex aere fuso, aut malleato.	Sometimes an enema is made of silver, or gold-copper alloy (i.e., brass), or cast bronze, or sheet copper.
Et quandoque fit ex istis Instrumentis paruum, et magnum, secundum illos in quibus administrantur.	And sometimes it is made of these instruments small or large depending on those to whom they are administered.
Illud ergo quod administratur in curatione puerorum paruorum, sit paruum: et quorum ani sunt debiles, aut dolorosi, sic et clisteria eorum.	Thus that which is administered for the cure of small children should be small; and so also their enemas if those children have weak or painful rectums.
Clistere magnum.	Large enema.
Cistere paruum.	Small enema.
Canna eius, id est, caput superius in quo ligatur uter, sit amplum secundum hunc modum: et sit ei distinctio ut ligetur uter sicut uides, et extremitas eius inferior quae intromittitur in anum, sit surda, id est, non aperta, lenis, ualde, trahens ad subtilitatem: et in uno laterum eius sint duo foramina, et in latere altero foramen unum.	Its tube, that is the upper part to which the bag (i.e., the bladder used as reservoir) is tied, should be wide like this: and have a mark so that the bag is tied on like you see, and its lower extremity that is inserted into the rectum should be deaf, i.e., not open, very soft, drawn out to a point; and let there be two holes in one side of it, and on the other side one hole.
Et sit amplitudo foraminis secundum grossitudinem radiorum, et grossius parum, et sit uter in quo ponuntur medicinae ex uesica animalis: aut ex charta ouis, quae sit secundum formam asofrati paruae: cuius radix sit palmus unus.	And let the width of the hole be according to the thickness of rays (i.e., thin branches) and a little thicker; and let it have a bag in which medicines are put made from an animal's bladder, or from sheep paper that is like the shape of a small asofra whose root is one palm.
Et perforetur foraminibus multis sicut reuoluitur, et sit spacium quod est inter omne foramen grossitudo digiti.	And it is pierced with multiple holes as it revolves, and there should be a space between each hole the thickness of a finger.
Deinde intromitte in illa foramina filum forte ex filo crudo, quod sit ex decem filis, aut circiter ea, et aggrega cum eo utrem sicut asofrati.	Then insert into those holes a strong thread made of raw silk, which should be ten strands or thereabouts, and attach to it the bladder as with a sausage casing.
Cum ergo ponitur in eo uter, stringatur in capite clisteris inter duo distinguentia constrictione forti.	When therefore the bladder is put on it, tie it at the end of the enema tubes between the two distinguishing marks with a strong ligature.
Deinde clisteriza cum eo.	Then enema with it.
Et haec est forma circuli utris hic depicta, et foraminum.	And this is the form of the circular bladder depicted here, as well as its holes.
Qualitas autem clisterizandi cum eo, est: ut impleas utrem, aut uesicam ex medicina, quae sit calefacta secundum quantitatem tolerantiae infirmi: et caue ne sit calida ualde, aut frigida ualde.	The quality of enema with it is such that you fill the bladder or wineskin with medicine which should be heated according to the extent the sick person can bear; and take care that it is not very hot nor very cold.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et eleuet crura sua ad superiora: et pone sub eo inthaan, id est, corium super quod iacent homines, aut linteamen.	Then the sick person is laid on their back and their legs are raised upwards; and put under them an inthaan, that is to say, a skin on which people lie down, or a cloth.
Deinde inunge extremitatem Clisteris cum oleo, aut cum albugine oui, aut cum mucillagine foenugraeci, aut similium.	Then anoint the end of the enema tube with oil or with egg white or with fenugreek mucus, or the like.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in anum cum facilitate.	Then insert it into the anus easily.
Deinde accipiat minister utrem cum duabus manibus suis simul, et exprimat ipsum cum uehementia, donec euacuet totum quod est in Clisteri in intestinum.	Then the attendant takes the bladder with both hands at once and squeezes it vigorously until everything inside the enema tube is evacuated into the intestine.
Deinde extrahe Clistere, et eleuet infirmus crura sua ad parietem.	Then withdraw the enema tube and raise the sick person's legs to the wall.
Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	But if the medicine makes him want to defecate then he should hold on for as long as he is able.
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	If he sleeps with her for a whole night, it is all the more beneficial.
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	If however you give him an enema during the illness of abdominal pain and his discharge hastens; then repeat the enema until he is cured.
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	If there are haemorrhoids or painful abscesses in the anus, then use a very gentle enema, soft, of the type that is used for children's enemas.
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this is the form of a gentle enema, which applies to cases where the skin is tight.
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	On the treatment of head wounds without bone fracture.
Caput LXXXIIII.	Chapter 84.
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have already said in the section on wound treatment that a book was appropriate, and I will say here the treatment of them with the hand, and with medicines as a supplement.
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	I say, therefore, that wounds are differentiated according to the instrument by which they are caused and the place where the wound occurs.
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	The things by which wounds are caused, such as a stone thrown or an incision with a sword or knife, or being struck with a spear, wooden stick, arrow; and many similar objects.
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	Wounds that occur according to the place on the body are, for example, a wound which falls on the head, or neck, chest, stomach, flanks; and similar parts of these members.
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	And I will describe the treatments of some wounds, so that I may establish this reasoning and rule for other types of wounds.
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	I shall begin with simple head wounds, since the description of compound injuries will be given at the start of chapter three.
Dico ergo.	I say therefore.
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	When there is a simple head wound and no bone fracture occurs: consider this; if it was caused by the impact of a stone or something similar, and has already broken only the skin. If it is a large wound and you fear an adverse outcome with hot abscesses then proceed quickly to perform a cephalic phlebotomy without delay and extract from his blood according to the strength of the patient: unless there is some impediment to performing the phlebotomy, especially if the blood issuing from the wound is scant.
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let the phlebotomy be performed on the side opposite to that of the injury.
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	And caution the patient against overeating, drinking wine, or eating fatty foods.
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	If, however, something prevents the patient from taking liquid foods then reduce their solid food intake and avoid meats or wines altogether.
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And if a hot abscess forms on the wound then apply to it lard that has been melted in rose oil alone or mixed with wine having an astringent effect.
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	But if you are assured that there will be no hot abscess then apply to the wound, while it is still fresh with its own blood and before it has been exposed to air, the powder which I shall describe shortly: but if the injury has already been exposed to the air then use certain ointments instead until healing occurs.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	But if the wound is large or caused by a sword-cut or something similar and its lips do not come together naturally then use stitches to bring them together as I shall describe for wounds of the belly.
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	If however the wound has already separated from the bone, and it is hanging, and there is no way to retain it except with a small sling; then cut it off.
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Then treat the wound with medicines and restore hard flesh to it instead of skin; instruct the patient to be fed with foods that are coarse, such as cabbage heads and boiled wheat, until it is like porridge, along with similar fare.
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	If you find a case of skin-deep gangrene that does not adhere to bone; then cut out the entire gangrenous area and throw it away; afterward treat what remains.
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	If however an artery or a vein from which blood is flowing should be found among these wounds; and it cannot be severed by medicine alone, then make a ligature above the vessel.
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	If therefore you find that it has not been severed; then sever it with a scalpel or ligate it.
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If need requires it when what we have said does not suffice; then cauterize until the blood stops flowing.
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	If however these wounds are small and simple; then their treatment is easy, light: so that you sprinkle this powder on them: for it solidifies them before the air changes them.
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	Recipe puluerem ex lapide talco, et sanguine uenarioso commisto parum cum salicacae, et commisce eam in mortario.
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Take one part frankincense and two parts dragon's blood with three parts quicklime; grind all thoroughly together in a mortar, then sieve it: fill the wound with this powder and dress it well so that it adheres firmly to the powder and clots with the blood.
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then secure it from above with small sticks and leave it, do not release it as long as it remains so that it does not come off.
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	Make sure the medicine is not removed from it until it heals.
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	And sometimes lime alone does this, when you do not have frankincense at hand, and the blood of a dragon also performs the same operation in many large wounds, when it is appropriate to place it on them and secure them, and they are fresh wounds with their own blood which has not been altered by air.
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	But if air has already altered them in some way, especially when it is summertime, then this powder is not appropriate for the purpose: so treat it with what we have said, such that you place on it certain digestive ointments: or place poultices of barley flour made with water and honey until they discharge pus.
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then treat them with the remaining treatment until they heal.
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	If however there is a fracture with the wound in the bone and it is small, then extract it with Gesht: and I will now describe the treatment of head fractures later.
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	On wounds of the neck.
Caput LXXXV.	Head 85.
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	But if a wound occurs on the neck, then there is no difference between it and a simple head wound with regard to treatment.
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	But if the nerve of the neck has already been cut, or an artery: then if it is a nerve, there is no skill in treating it except to abandon its cure with what causes severe contraction such as Zinnia and Zea and similar things.
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	For they harm nerves and contract them.
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	And do not place anything cold on the wound at all: for the substance of nerves is cold, and its continuation is with the brain, which is loftier than the members; and let it be cured by medicines that are soft, such as lime washed with water often poured in with oil, or with rose oil, and tutia, when it is also washed with sweet water: and the rest of the mineral stones, in this way, and moist ointments.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	But if the wound is large, then apply a suture; or draw together its lips with stitches.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it is healed.
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	But if the wound is deep, or if there is an abscess in its lower part, where now pus has already gathered, then pierce it in a deeper place on it.
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	If an artery has already been cut in the wound and its flow of blood has followed, then separate it or tie it off, and bind it; or cauterize it if necessity calls for that.
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	But if the larynx has already been cut into, or all of it, and the alhaudegi are saved: then gather together the lips of the skin with a suture over the cane of the throat, and do not touch the throat, rather equalize it, and bring it back to its natural shape.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then bind it with a suitable restraint, and leave it for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointments that have styptic and drying properties until it is healed.
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	But if the wound has already made an impression in bone, then probe it; then if there are fragments of bone in it, take out all that you can of them; and what is not prepared, leave it until the wound festers, and its discharge separates and lessens.
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	If the wound is fresh, then sprinkle over it the powder I described.
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	If there appears to be bone in the wound and a fistula forms, then treat it with that which I mentioned in its own chapter.
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	On wounds on spathels.
Caput LXXXVI.	Chapter 86.
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If it is the strike of a lance or knife, and you see its depth, then consider this.
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	If breath escapes from the wound when the patient gasps, then you know that the wound is fatal.
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	But if it is not deep and is fresh with its blood, then do not put on it at first any powder nor bind it up tightly so that the blood may not be retained in its depth and return to the heart and kill the patient; but apply to it an attracting ointment twice a day.
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	If you have no ointment at hand, then put on the orifice of the wound a warm poultice to draw from it what comes out of its moisture; and make the patient sleep upon the wound so that what collects in it may run out.
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	If three or more days have passed since the wound and no spasm nor heart tremors, tightness when breathing, or other signs of illness occur in the patient, then you know that the wound is healed.
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Treat it therefore with linen cloths and other treatments until it is cured.
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	If its healing is neglected and it always reopens, then you know that a fistula has formed.
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	Take care of it yourself from its own chapter.
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	And if the wound is from an incised sword or knife and is simple on the surface of the chest or back, then treat it with what was described earlier regarding sutures if it is large, or with powder if it is small.
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	But if it has already made an impression in the bone and has cut off pieces from it, then investigate the wound, and hurry to remove those pieces if they are separated.
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	If however they are not separated, then leave them until the wound decays as their removal will be eased.
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	The judgement of the remaining accidental wounds in other members regarding treatment is the same as we have said.
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	On abdominal wounds, and on protruding intestines, and their protrusion:
Caput LXXXVII.	Chapter 77.
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	The rupture that occurs in the abdomen is large, medium, or small.
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	From a large one, sometimes an intestine or several intestines protrude.
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Why does their protrusion happen and their suture is more painful and difficult.
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And the small rupture also occurs in another way.
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	Therefore it follows that their reduction is more difficult if you do not hurry to push them back into place immediately because they become inflated, open up and thicken which makes getting them in again challenging.
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	For this reason the medium rupture is better than that of complete ruptures because with it the reduction of the intestine is not difficult as it is in these two types.
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	You should know that there are four methods for sewing veins.
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	Two common stitches are used for the abdomen and other bodily injuries; two other types of stitches are specific to other wounds.
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	However, they are more specific when it comes to abdominal stitches; I will describe each one for you with an explanation and clarification.
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	I say then that when a wound is small and something comes out of the intestine, making it difficult to close, it must be done in one of two ways.
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Either because of the small size of the wound, as we said; or because there is an inflammation inside due to cold air.
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	When this is the case, you should warm it up by dipping a sponge or damp cloth into lukewarm water only.
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Or you could boil water with squills, rushes, spikes, and embrocation, using it to soak the intestine until the inflammation subsides.
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	Sometimes alcohol with astringent properties will do this, and it's better than water alone at reducing inflammation.
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	Once you see the inflammation has subsided, moisten the intestine with water that has been boiled with marshmallow root or apples.
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For it soothes the entrance with something soft.
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	But if its exit is obstructed after this treatment, then you must look for a small opening in the wound with an instrument that cuts haemorrhoids.
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	The first treatment is better when it's prepared beforehand compared to cutting; there's no force necessary for the cutting once the tool is needed and fails.
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	One part of it is the curved, pointed end and the other part is not sharp; its fine point should not be as delicate as a spatula, rather let it be somewhat blunter; and that which resembles chalk you see there.
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	Thus when a wound is enlarged and penetrates the intestine, then it should be reduced back into its natural form in its proper place according to its own nature if possible; for this is better.
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	When there is a wide rupture in the lower part of the belly: then you should make the patient lie on their back and place their legs higher than their head.
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	And if it is on the upper part of the belly then place their head and chest higher than their lower parts.
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	Similarly if there is a rupture on one of the two sides of the belly then direct your mind and always consider that the side where it has occurred be elevated higher than the other.
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	And so you should administer this treatment for both large wounds and medium-sized ones.
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	For small wounds, place it according to what is prepared for you.
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then ensure that there is present a diligent attendant who holds the entire rupture with his hand and brings its lips together.
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Then expose it to the one who follows with something after something else for a single suture.
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And it is such that you take a needle or the number of needles according to the size of the wound.
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then measure from the edge of the rupture a quantity equal to your ring finger (that is, the physician's) and fix one needle beyond that, then thread it through both ends of the skin with two ends of suture beneath the skin until you have made them penetrate on the other side; and now you have brought together two ends of the skin and two ends of the suture: there are thus four strands.
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then bind with double thread around the needle several times from both sides simultaneously until the two lips of the wound are brought together in a proper union.
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Then discard the bulk of the finger as well, and fix another needle into them; afterwards, draw it taut with thread, just as you did with the first needle.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	Therefore do not cease doing this with as many needles as you need until you complete the suturing of the entire wound.
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And let the needles be of medium thickness between coarse and fine; for thin needles pierce the flesh very swiftly, while thick ones are difficult to insert through the skin; hence it is necessary that they should be of medium thinness and thickness.
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	And one must not fix the needles too close to both edges of the skin so that flesh is not quickly cut through and the wound opens up before it has healed or stretched out with the suture so as not to prevent healing of the wound.
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Then blunt the tips of the needles so as not to hurt the patient while they sleep; and place on either side of them small pads made from cloth which hold the ends of the needles; and leave these in place until you know that the wound is now healed.
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	And this particular type of suture with needles, thus described, is more suitable for small wounds.
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	Since one needle or two or about that number is sufficient for the suture of these wounds.
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	The second type of suture is common to bring together the four edges - two skin edges and two edges of subcutaneous tissue with a needle which has thread wound around it uniformly in terms of thinness and thickness.
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	Then, when you have penetrated with the needle these four extremities, bring the needle back from the side where you started it so that the threaded filament falls down from the upper part of the wound: let there be a suture like the stitch used to string clothes together, and place between each suture the thickness of half a finger.
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	People refer to this as 'sewing'.
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	And with this stitch I sewed together the wounds of a man who had been stabbed in the belly with a knife and whose wound was gaping open wider than a palm; about two palms' worth of his intestines had come out through the middle, and there was a rupture right across the abdomen.
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	I brought those intestines back inside after they had been hanging outside the wound for twenty-four hours.
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	So the wound healed after about fifteen days; I treated it and he recovered, living many years afterward and going back to his old ways.
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	And the doctors had judged that it would not heal.
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	It was truly miraculous because I did not treat him with any ointment.
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	Because I was in a place where there were no ointments to be found nor any medicines.
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	So I put an old linen cloth on the wound twice a day and kept washing it with honey water until it was healed.
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	I will now describe to you two types of stitches that I have used successfully in my practice.
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	And this is how you start with an acute suture: the needle should go in from the outside to the inside.
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	When the needle therefore has penetrated into the skin and having entered the muscle according to the length and width of the whole body: release the end on that side where you have inserted the needle, and make it penetrate from the inside to outside at the other end at Mirach.
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	Once you have made it penetrate, then make it penetrate according to this into the same Mirach end from outside to inside: and release the Sifac end which is on this side, and make the needle penetrate into the other end from inside to outside: and make your penetration as you do when penetrating into the Sifac Mirach end, which is in its part, until it penetrates the whole thing.
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	Then begin again from this same side, and guide it with the end which is from Sifac on the other side, and extract the needle from the skin through which it has penetrated.
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then return it to that skin and guide the Sifac end which is on the other side with this Mirach end: and extract it from the skin of its part, and make one after another, and one after the other: and do so until you have extracted all of it externally according to that example.
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	The essence of this suture is that the sutures of hides are like those of skins: so that you guide Sifac one after another from one side with an end of the skin: and release it one after another from the other side, until you have completed it.
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	The second type of suture proper, which Galen calls.
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	His discourse about this is that you guide it according to the similarity of how some physicians use it, so that they bring together all parts to their appropriate counterpart by nature: and apply the Sifac end to its other end, and the Mirach end to its other end.
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And it happens just as I tell you.
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	You must fix the needle at the tip of Mirach close to you from the outside part and make it penetrate inward only; and release the two ends of Sifac.
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then rotate the needle, and make it penetrate from the outside to the inside into the two ends of Sifac, that is, on both sides.
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	Then rotate both of them as well, and make both of them penetrate from the inside to the outside into the other two tips of Mirach which are on the opposite side.
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And this method of stitching is better than the common and easy stitch, and it is a kind of stitching that has been mentioned before.
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This, therefore, is also Galen's saying.
Et dixerunt quidam.	And some have said,
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	The abdominal wound is stitched with two needles.
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	Which is to insert into both of them one thread; and start with the insertion of the needle from what is near you, and make it penetrate up to the other side according to the stitching of those who are equal in skin.
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	And you should know that when there is a tear in the middle of the abdomen; then its stitching is more difficult than other parts of the abdomen.
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	The judgment of the wound's healing is the judgment of other wounds.
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	Which is because when you acquire a fresh wound with its blood, before it changes itself by air; and you bring back the intestine, follow it, and make it fit; then place it over red powder.
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	If the air has already altered the wound: then place over it certain ointments, which are available to you, until they produce pus; and let the filaments fall out, and let the sinews become consolidated, and the bone.
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it like the healing of other wounds until it is healed.
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	But if these medicines are not available to you, then place over it immediately, from the moment that it begins to discharge pus, an old linen cloth; and change it twice a day as I have taught you until it is healed.
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	For you do not need any other medicine for many treatments when the wounds are simple ones.
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	But if you fear that the wound may communicate with any of the principal members during their dislocation, then it is necessary to immerse soft wool in oil of a moderate warmth or in rose oil; and place them around those places which are between the groins and under the armpits.
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	If he feels pain or gripes, or putrefaction in his intestines (for this often happens), then administer an enema to him with astringent wine, black, tepid; especially if the putrefaction has already reached the intestine and is about to break out penetrating right up to his hollow belly.
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And know that the part from the large intestine is easier to heal; and that which comes out of the finer intestines is more difficult to heal.
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	The intestine which is called the jejunum does not admit of healing from a wound which occurs in it at all; and this is due to its great multitude of veins, and the size of them, and because of the fineness of its body, and the proximity of its nature to that of nerves.
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	If, however, what proceeds from the wound is zirbum, and you follow it while fresh: return it according to your own method of reducing intestines evenly.
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	But if some time has passed, and it has already become green or black: then you must tie it with a thread above the place that has darkened from it, so that there is no bleeding.
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	For in zirbum there are veins and arteries.
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	Then cut what is beyond that ligament, and place the two ends of the thread hanging from the lower part of the wound outside it: so as to relieve yourself of drawing out its attraction, and extracting it in case of a zirbum, and emitting pus of the wound.
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	Remembrance of the wound that happens in the intestine.
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When disruption happens in the intestine and is small, then it may be possible for it to be restored in some people; because I have seen one who was wounded in their belly with a lance blow, and there was a wound from the right of the stomach, and the wound had become old; and it became a fistula, and there came out from it discharge, and flatulence.
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	So I treated him until I was not confident of his healing; nor did I cease to treat him until he had healed and the place had consolidated.
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	After I saw the place now consolidated, I feared for the patient that there would be an unfortunate accident in their belly; and no misfortune happened to them from it.
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	And he remained in better condition, eating and drinking, and having sex, and entered the bathhouse, and exercised at his meals.
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And now some experimentalists have said that when a wound occurs in the intestine and it is small, then it should be sutured in this manner.
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	It happens that you take ants of large heads.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then gather the two lips of the wound, and place one ant with an open mouth on top of the two lips of the wound.
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	When it therefore bites down on them and tightens its mouth, cut off its head, for it adheres and does not let go.
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	Then place another ant near the first one, and keep doing so with an ant after each ant according to the size of the wound.
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then draw it together, and sew up the wound.
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	For those heads remain attached inside the intestine until the intestine has healed and there is no longer any harm to the patient.
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	And now it is possible that the intestine be sutured even with fine thread: which has been removed from the gut of an animal and attached to it after being passed through a needle.
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	It is necessary that you take the end of this thread from the gut, and it be thoroughly cleaned of flesh.
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then bind to its end a thin linen thread wrapped around it.
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then pass that thread through a needle, and sew with it the intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then draw it together at the wound.
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And this method of suturing with ants and gut is only by way of trust and hope.
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	Know that a wound which is large and wide, especially if it is on one of the thinner intestines, then there is no cure but subtle treatment, nor is its healing at all.
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	On the cure of boils and fistulas.
Caput LXXXVIII.	Chapter 88.
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	Know that any wound or abscess when it becomes old and ages, and turns into an ulcer, and does not consolidate, and discharges pus constantly, and is not cut off: then it is universally called a fistula on whatever part of the body it may be, and we call it a boil.
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	A fistula is indeed correctly a hard, white nodule with filtering, without pain, which has the concavity of a bird's feather; and on account of this some call it Risati, that is, feather.
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	And at certain times it becomes moist, discharging pus.
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	And perhaps the moisture is split up at some times.
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	And sometimes this moisture is plentiful or scarce; it is thick and thin.
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	And I have already mentioned in the division, then when I said wounds, that any ulcer which does not heal and flesh is not born in it, it is not except for one of nine causes.
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	Of which one is either because of the scarcity of blood in the body or due to its ill-nature; or because between it and above its lips there is hard flesh, preventing the birth of flesh; or because it has an abundance of filth and dirtiness; or because the ulcer itself is putrid, and the matter sent to it is of poor quality: or because the medicine used for its cure is unsuitable; or because the corruption falling on that region is a type of pestilence, or due to some property in that region, as happens at Caesaraugusta: where recovery from illnesses takes place with difficulty, and healing of boils by nature is delayed there; or because there is one bone, or number of bones, in it.
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	And now I have shown you all these causes and signs of the conditions, and their treatments along with the medicines in the section: and here it is necessary for me to make you aware of the treatment of fistula and zukën, which are carried out by means of manual operations.
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	Therefore, you should know that fistula occurs in all body parts.
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	For among them are fistulas that reach major veins and arteries, or nerves, or the spine; or [those that reach] the intestine, or the bladder, or one of the ribs; or one of the vertebrae of the backbone, or one of the compound joints such as those of hand and foot; and among them are some which go towards the proximity of a main limb, and similar areas.
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	The fistula from among them that is like this is one of the difficult illnesses to heal, and it does not accept treatment, and dealing with it is labour-intensive and requires expertise.
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	But if there is any fistula whose depth does not reach these places that I have mentioned: and you are hopeful, and confident in its treatment, and want to attain knowledge of it, then take a probe made from brass or iron, if the fistula runs straight, and use it to trace [the path of] the fistula.
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	But if there is curvature in the fistula, then investigate it with a fine lead probe.
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	Because the softness of the lead enables it to be bent and conform to the curvature.
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	But if the fistula has many openings, you cannot trace it with a probe.
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	Therefore, you must inject liquid into one of its openings from among the openings.
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	For the moisture which the enema brings, enters via one orifice and runs out through others.
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then carefully inquire as to how you can tell whether it is bone or nerve, and if the cavity of the fistula is deep or shallow; or whether there is one fistula with multiple openings that covers all of this, using your utmost strength: through questioning the patient and finding pain upon compression with your hand on the site, and similar signs and causes and symptoms.
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	When you have thus stood at your true station, then go to the cure with confidence; and consider then whether the fistula is a shallow one that appears close by, or in a safe place far from a joint, nerve, artery, vein, or any of the places I mentioned: then cut open the fistula as previously described, remove whatever may be draining from it and corrupted flesh which forms at its opening out of flesh or membrane and similar things; treat this until it is healed.
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	But if the fistula is deep and straight, then you must cut it open as deeply as possible.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	Then clean it of all its corrupted flesh.
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then apply linen wraps soaked in sharp medicines; insert these into the fistula cavity which you have opened with your knife: do this several times until the sharp medicine has eaten away all that remains of corruption within the fistula's cavity. 
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with salves which generate healthy flesh until it is healed.
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	But if it does not heal by this means, then cauterise it as we have described.
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	If the cause of the fistula is bone, and you ascertain this, then expose it and cut into it as I have described to you; if nothing prevents you from among veins, nerves or main members, as we said.
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	If you find bone and there is some decay or blackness within it, then scrape it until all the decay is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with something that promotes flesh growth until it heals.
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	But if it does not heal and still discharges pus as before, then you should know that you have not succeeded in removing all the decay.
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Therefore expose it again, and make a thorough investigation of its condition and cleaning with all your strength.
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then restore it.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	If it heals, that is good; but if not, then know that the decay lies deep within the body, beyond your reach.
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	It is not within your skill to cure it, other than to leave it to nature.
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	But if the decayed bone is small and it is possible for you, draw it out with fine forceps that suit it.
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	If, however, there are many bones, then make a thorough extraction of them all, and do not leave any behind with your strength.
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	If any of the moist tissues offer resistance and there is no fear or mistake in cutting them open: then cut into those moist tissues and flesh if they are present there, and free the bones.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	If you do not have the means to remove bones immediately, then place on the wound something that will cause it to rot; and leave it until what is around those bones rots away from flesh and moisture.
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And guard the wound so that it does not heal.
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And constrict the incision you made during your procedure.
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	In my opinion, place on it, if you fear it, a poultice of sulphur pounded with oil and moistened; or a poultice steeped in Egyptian ointment, or any one of the green ointments.
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when those moist parts decay, and the bones are separated from them, the removal of the former and the drawing together of the latter will be facilitated.
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	But if it is one large bone, such as a leg or hip bone, and what is corrupted of it is a large part; then scrape it with the ultimate razor until that blackness and corruption are removed.
Deinde restaura uulnus.	Then restore the wound.
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	But if what is corrupted of it is a large part and the corruption has already reached the marrow, then it must be sawn through and cut away entirely down to the place where the corruption has reached; then take care of it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I will tell you, Zuken, what happened to a man in his leg; so that you may take it as an example and help for your procedure.
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	There was a young man around thirty years of age, who experienced pain in his leg from a cause that originated inside the body; until the pus reached the leg and formed an abscess - and there was no external reason for it.
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	Thus was extended over time with him the error of the physicians until the abscess opened and many substances had mixed with it.
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And his cure was postponed until the leg became fistulated and many holes were made in it: all of which discharged pus and body fluids.
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	Thus he was treated by a multitude of physicians for about two years and there wasn't among them one skilled in the art of surgery until I was called upon and saw his leg and the substances that were flowing from those holes at great speed: also all the man's body had already wasted away and his colour was yellow.
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	I therefore inserted a probe into one of the holes, and the probe reached the bone.
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I examined all the holes, and found that they interconnected with each other from every part of the leg.
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	Therefore I sawed and cut away the tissue over one of those holes until I uncovered a part of the bone; and found it to be corrupted: for it was already corroded and blackened and putrefied and perforated right through to the marrow.
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	I therefore sawed away what had been uncovered by me and prepared it from the corrupted bone.
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I judged that there was nothing in the bone but that corruption which I had cut away and sawn off.
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	And by this point, I had already eradicated it.
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I applied a long-term healing remedy to the wound as a means of restoration.
Et non est consolidatum.	And it has not healed (consolidated).
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	I then tried and placed a splint on the second bone above the first one; and I found that it was also contaminated with decay, so I removed what appeared to me from this contamination as well.
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	I then tried to restore it.
Et non est restauratum.	And it was not restored.
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	I placed a splint on it again and did not stop cutting the bone piecemeal in an effort to restore it; but it was not restored until I cut out about one palm's width of bone with its marrow.
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	I then treated it with medicines and it healed quickly; this repetition of the operation and incision would not have been necessary had it not been for the condition of weakness and frailty of the patient, and his lack of endurance as well as my own fear over him of death: since he was fainting every hour from an excess of evacuation.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He has thus been completely cured; hard flesh was formed instead of the bone and a good condition established in his body, so that he regained strength and returned to his normal state, conversing with people again: there is no sign whatsoever of injury or difficulty while walking.
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	But if a protruding bone has already been broken at the body of it; then you must saw it off like this: take a ligament and tighten it to the end of the prominent bone, while someone else stretches it upward, and place another thicker woollen bandage on top of the first one.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind it to the flesh above the bone; and stretch its end so as to pull the flesh downward while you cover the area of the flesh that you wish to saw with a splint so as not to hurt it.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place a wooden stick or board under the lower bone: for when you do this, it is not prohibited that it cuts through the corrupted flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	The lock must be placed over the infected area for a short time to prevent infection from entering into the hollow of the bone; this will not appear as an obvious wound and forces the use of another lock instead.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	If the bone is infected and not protruding, but it continues into a connected portion; the infection being within its center or one of its sides, then you must remove all flesh from every side (of the injury).
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place a wooden stick below it.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	After that, lock it from the first side where there is infection until the lock continues to the other side; and let the lock be slightly longer than the area of infection as we have said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If the infection is at the joint, cut away that infected part of it; then lock down the bone from where it continues on its other side.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	However, if the infection is between two joints there is no remedy other than to scrape it out.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	If the infection is at the comb of the hand or foot, then the situation becomes very difficult to treat.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	But it is necessary that you inquire how exactly the infection presents itself to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And you should scrape it out and clean it according to any arrangement that is possible for you; with whatever remedy appears right to you as long as this does not go against the vein or nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	You should be aware that there are many different types of scalpels and locks for cutting these bones; according to the location, preparation, thickness, fineness, size, smallness, hardness, and rarity of each bone.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore, it is necessary that you prepare every kind of instrument suitable for that particular operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations indicate to you the type of instrument needed, which you require when you have a lengthy study.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And knowledge of the techniques of this art is a guide to the nature of illnesses; for then you will discover for yourself which instruments are suitable for every illness.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am providing you with a list of instruments at the end of this chapter, which serve as examples on which you practice, and as tests by which you may experiment with others.
Forma Serrae.	Shape of the Saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	Shape of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Shape of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	Shape of another saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This drawing of the shape of the saw is off-centre.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its upper rim be made of iron wire; the handle, of boxwood; and let the pyramidal point be off-centre.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	Shape of the scissors with joined blades.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of these scissors be made according to the shape of a star-shaped nail; and let its points be like those of the eyelash-curling iron.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it is not suitable unless the blades are rubbed with them when they become blunt or a large and thick bone is to be cut.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	Shape of the larger scissors.
Forma medii Rasorii.	Shape of the medium-sized scissors.
Forma Rasorii lati.	The form of a wide rope ligature.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	Form of a curved clamp.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	The form of another thin rope ligature.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	Form of the other curved clamp with a hooked end.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	Form of a small pair of thin forceps.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The form of an instrument with which bones are sawn.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	Form also of the large clamp.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This resembles a lever; its end is like a saw: it appears in many places because of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	Form of the clamp which suits its purpose for perforated bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its end is triangular; it has sharp ends.
Fit ex Indi.	It is made of Indian steel.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And similarly it is necessary that all of the instruments we have mentioned be made of Indian steel, whether they are clamps, knives or saws.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	On amputating limbs, and sawing bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter 89.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	Limbs become putrid either from an external or internal cause.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	Therefore when you have treated that putridity by medicinal cure and it does not bring about healing; and you see the putridity spreading into the limb which is unaffected: then it is necessary to amputate that limb as far as the extent of the putridity, so that the patient may escape death or a serious ailment.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	The sign that this has occurred is when the limb turns black and remains so until it is thought to have been burned by fire or to have gone bad after turning black; until that rot is cut away right up to what follows that limb and spreads throughout the entire body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore make the first cut appropriately, and likewise if the cause of the rot is from the sting of certain venomous creatures such as the sea scorpion, viper, adder, and similar things.
