Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore the rot or sting is on the tip of a finger then cut off the finger and do not give space to the rot so that it may spread to the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And likewise if it happens to the hand then cut it off from its root at the wrist and do not give space to the rot so that it takes hold of the forearm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it invades further then cut off the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if the rot spreads beyond that point then there is no hope for the patient's life.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And administering anything further in treatment at this stage is pointless.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And likewise for the foot; when rot invades a toe then cut it off at its first joint and if it takes hold of the whole of the foot then amputate the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	If however it ascends to the knee then cut off the leg at its joint with the knee.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	If however the rot has already reached above the knee then it is not a matter of skill but rather resignation and leaving the patient to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the method for cutting a limb or binding it is to tie the tendon below where you wish to cut and then tighten another tendon above that place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And the attendant should stretch one tendon downwards, and the other upwards.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh that is between two tendons with a broad chisel until all the meat is exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it should be cut or bound.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	It is necessary that you place a linen cloth on all sides and not touch the healthy area with the saw; for if an unhealthy part is struck, there will be added injury and hot abscess.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	But if internal bleeding occurs while you are operating, then quickly cauterize the place or put some styptics on it.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your dressing until it is completed.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Next bind the wounded limb with appropriate bandages and treat it until it is healed.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you that this same accident happened to a man in his foot.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	Which is because a blackening occurred in his foot, like a burn resembling fire combustion; and that corruption first began in his toe until it started to affect the whole foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	So the man decided to take action for himself after he saw that the corruption was spreading into his limb with increasing severity; which he found from its pain and burning sensation, and it had occurred at the joint, but now he is healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	After a lengthy period had passed, he experienced the same decay in his index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He came to me, and I attempted to treat the excess flesh with medicine that I applied to his hand after cleansing his body; however, the superfluity was not rectified, and it began to spread to another finger until decay set into his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He called on me to cut off his hand, but I refused, hoping for a recovery from the excess flesh and fearing death during the amputation of his hand itself.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Since the man's strength was above adversity.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	After losing hope in me, he returned to his land and hastened back to me, having cut off his entire hand; thus, he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	I have related this account not only as an aid for treating those who suffer from this illness but also to signify and describe what may be done in such cases.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	On the treatment of fistulas and the nature of enemas with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When a swelling occurs in some fleshy parts and the condition persists until it forms an accumulation of pus; then it breaks or is pierced, discharging its contents and leaving an empty space like a vessel with only thin skin covering it: and this does not extend to complete decay nor affects bone, nerve or ligament. It should be called a Sinus rather than a Fistula; however, if the condition persists until decay reaches one of these structures then it is named a Fistula or zuken.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And its treatment is to cut that skin entirely as it peels off; especially when it has been thinned out and made like cloth; and be confident that it will not stick with the site because of its decomposition.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	But if you hope that the skin will adhere and it does not follow from that last corruption; and if there is thickness in the skin from flesh, then treat it with an enema; and it is necessary to pay attention to the cavity.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large and the pus that comes out of it has a foul smell; then treat it with an enema using Egyptian medicine made up of equal parts vinegar, oil, and ziniar, combined in a vase: boil them over a fire until the remedy reddens and becomes as thick as honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take as much of it as you need; dissolve it with water and honey, and administer an enema to the cavity using that mixture; squeeze its opening, and leave the medicine inside for about two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it by pressing; do this for as many days as necessary until the cavity is cleansed and the stench removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And sometimes it is treated with an enema of ash water when this remedy is not available to you; and be sure to use the ashes of grape vines or the ashes of holm-oak wood, throwing them into the water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then mix it well and administer an enema with that water until you are confident that the cavity is now cleansed.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	But if the patient cannot tolerate Egyptian medicine or ash water, then treat them with an enema of just water and honey to which some ground ziniar has been added.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	The enema itself with honey and wine mixed in it because of the property of honey is cleansing and washing out; and wine makes it adhere to the sinus, especially when there is excess astringency and dryness in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you have done this a few times, and are confident that the corruption of the sinus has now been removed, then use an enema with what makes flesh grow there.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is necessary that you take some dyaphinitis plaster: and dissolve it with rose oil and astringent wine: or use an enema with those medicines and other ointments, whose properties I have described in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	But if the sinus orifice is narrow and does not admit the enema's cannula: then stretch it a little with an iron instrument: or place over it a linen cloth wrapped in Egyptian ointment, or in balsam-ointment, until it is stretched.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if it is also a wide orifice, then draw together its lips with a suture: and leave of it the amount into which the enema will go without any extra length.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if its orifice from which the pus issues is elevated above the rest: then cut it at a lower spot on it so that the pus runs out downwards; for when pus is confined deep within the sinus, it prevents flesh from forming there.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	If you cannot cut the sinus as low down on it as you wish: then try to prepare the member with a preparation that will make the pus run out of it easily as is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try to ensure that no vestige of pus remains within it at all: and take healing medicines which are put on the wound, suitable for what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend them over a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the cloth be of such quantity that it accommodates the entire cavity.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then make an incision with scissors along the center of the cavity's hole, somewhat beyond the cavity's opening.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then apply a fresh poultice of soft ointment to another cloth, according to the size of the hole; and place it on top at a distance from the cavity's opening so as to ease the flow of pus from it: and do not remove the large cloth unless after some days have passed.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	The one that is on the cavity's opening, you will remove every hour to allow what has accumulated in it of pus to drain out; and so that you may know whether what flows from it is more or less, cooked or raw.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And with this again consider the place of the cavity itself, whether its owner feels pain in it or not; and whether there is abscess in it or not.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When therefore your treatment is extended like this and you see the material that comes out over the cavity's opening, then you know that the cavity has already healed or is close to healing; so then dissolve it in the morning or on the third day: and when you heal the wound, then change the other cloth and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if a refined material comes out of the cavity after a long time has passed, then do not despair over its healing for it is near; since there are men who delay the growth of flesh in their wounds and some act contrary to that.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if raw pus comes out of the cavity after many days have passed, then you know that the cavity is not healing.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If the adherence of the sinus is delayed and its condition prolongs, then add in desiccation medicated substances, but physicians should ensure that these medications are moist by substance yet dry by virtue; such as dyafinicon unguent when added to it an excess of zegi.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And for the more advanced treatment, take dyafinicon unguent and dissolve it with rose oil, then moisten an equal amount of old wine by substance over it.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then prepare it with that and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And it performs a similar action to this when you do not have dyafinicon unguent at hand: honey, when cooked until thickened, can be used instead.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, aloe, and frankincense; grind everything together and powder it over honey while it is over a flame.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then spread over it a cloth and bind it to the sinus; coat with the honey you cooked until thickened and powder spices over it; place over the cloth and bind again.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And sometimes it is administered with long aristolochia, heaven lily roots, and true lily; the herb's flour and centaurea are also used.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use these simple substances or combine them; grind them together and sieve; powder over the honey I described earlier and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the condition of the sinus prolongs and does not heal with this treatment, then know that there is deep corruption; or it has already impacted the bones, hard tissues, or ligaments; in such cases treat as for fistulas, as previously mentioned.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	On the treatment of panaritium and abraded nails, as well as incising and cutting a finger.
Caput XCI.	Chapter 101.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	A panaritium is an abscess that forms under the nail of the thumb or toe, but may also occur on other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	If it is left untreated and the abscess becomes hot to the touch or filled with pus until the root of the nail is destroyed—or even the entire nail itself—and perhaps reaching the bone until its smell is foul; then the finger's tip will swell, and its color darken.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	So then when you treat it, along with what we mentioned earlier regarding the types of panaritium, and your treatment does not help; then you must cut away all remaining superfluous material left from the nail using an iron tool.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound afterwards.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	For cautery is indeed very beneficial.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	But if the bone is healthy and both nail and flesh are also so, yet its supporting nails now press against this interior flesh, pricking it and causing pain; then place a slender probe under the offending nail's edge that pierces the flesh, pushing it upwards: then cut away that flesh with ease, and apply what remains of any cauterizing and corrosive medicinal substances until all is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Afterwards treat it with ointments until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	But if the rot has already set into bone then it is necessary to cut away and remove that bone; for it will never heal so long as the corrupted bone remains.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see decay and deterioration progressing into the finger, then cut it off at one of the joints, according to what has been mentioned above.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	But if the nail suffers abrasion or a blow, and severe pain occurs within it, then you must first use phlebotomies on the patient.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then cut the nail with an acute spatula, making a transverse incision from top to bottom.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And be careful not to let the incision reach the flesh underneath the nail, for you will cause severe pain in the patient and it may result in an addition of flesh by nature at that place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then treat this place with what soothes the pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	However, the extra finger that is born in some people's hands may be fleshy throughout; and perhaps there are bones in some of them, or even a nail; and some of these fingers are born at the root of the joint, while their nature is native to some joints of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	Therefore the one that is born on some joints of the finger does not move; and the one which is born at the joint of the finger may well be movable.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	The sectioning process for the fleshy one among these is easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	This means that you should cut it at its root with a wide spatula.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	However, the treatment of that one whose nature is native to some joints of the finger is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore abstain from cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	However, if the tumor is born on a finger at the end of the joints, you must first cut his flesh with a round incision down to the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then saw through the bone with one of those saws suitable for this task.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	After that, treat it until it is healed.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	However, the stiffening of the fingers against each other often happens either from birth, that is, they are born with it, or as the result of wound-healing, or by firebrand, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore you must cut away that stiffening until the fingers return to their natural form.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them strips of flesh, or cloths soaked in rose oil: so that they do not stiffen quickly, and separate them; or put between them a thin sheet of lead until the site is healed as it should be.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly if stiffening happens to some fingers with the palm of the hand, then cut away that stiffening as is prepared and appropriate for the shape of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	On the topic of incision for a hernia.
Caput XCII.	Chapter 92.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	There are twisted veins, thick and full of melancholy superfluities that happen in many parts of the body; and their outcome is often in the legs, especially the legs of those who walk long distances and labour and carry heavy loads.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore you must administer the expulsion of black bile from the body by strong pounding several times.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then apply leeches to the patient's basilic vein.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The treatment of these conditions with an iron instrument is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One of them is that they are incised, and black blood is extracted.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other method is that the vein is raised, and the whole thing is removed.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	Its incision is according to this method.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Soak the patient's leg first with hot water until the thick feculent blood is loosened.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then bind the patient's leg from the upper part of their hip to the lower part of their knee with a bandage.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then make an incision on one spot, or two, or three places with a wide cut.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then raise it, that is, extract the blood with your hand from the lower part of the leg upwards, and you must have leeches on the patient first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then make an incision to the nail down below until you see enough blood coming out and as much as the patient can tolerate.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Afterwards bind it and instruct the patient to avoid foods that produce black bile; and repeat the evacuation and leeching when the veins are full and harmful to the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	Its elevation is according to this method.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Shave the patient's leg if there is much hair on it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then immerse it in a bath or apply hot water to their leg until they turn red and the veins swell; or have them exercise vigorously if there is no bath present, until their limb becomes warm.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then cut the skin along the vein's length, either at its end near the knee or in its lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with hooks and scrape the vein from all sides until it becomes visible; you will know when it appears because it looks reddish-black.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	So when it has been removed from the skin you see that it is white like a cord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then insert the rod beneath it until, when lifted up, it emerges from the skin; hang it with a blunt hook gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then make another cut close to that cut, about three fingers away.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then lift it up with rods as you did before, and hang it with another hook just like at the beginning.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then make another cut or several cuts if you need to.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Lift it up again and make the final incision near the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then extract it to the cut that is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this until you have extracted it from the top cut or highest of all cuts; when it is fully out then make an incision in it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	But if it does not obey you by coming out and lifting up, then insert a needle with strong thread doubled over and tie it, and pull it out; or insert beneath it a rod: turn your hand in all directions until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And beware, lest it be cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is cut, it becomes difficult for you to raise it greatly, and it enters the patient from that harm.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	So when you have extracted it all: then place over the wound a piece of wool soaked in wine and rose oil, or oil; and take care of the patient until they are healed.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	But if the artery is contracted, having a twist with an inward bend to its parts, and it is not as we have said straight: then you must cut over it on every side of its twists, and at the places of that bend.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then lift it with hooks until you have raised it completely: and beware at your incision over it lest you cut the vein or wound it; for it will be difficult for you to raise or extract it.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore, preserve your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The manner of the cutting whereby an artery is healed.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The manner of blind stitching.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It does not have a curved edge like other stitches, nor is it sharp-pointed so as to wound the vein; and it has a thick, undulating shape that is gentle; for if it were thin, its thinness would cut through the vein: rather, let there be superfluous thickness to it, as we have said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the extraction of the femoral vein.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter 93.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the legs in hot lands, such as Alexandria and Arabia; and in dry, hot lands of little moisture, that is, where neither grass nor trees are born.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	Its generation indeed comes from the putrefaction that occurs under the skin, just as happens inside the bodies of snakes and roundworms, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the onset of this varicose vein is a severe inflammation that occurs in the leg.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the place should be cauterized.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to emerge from that place of cauterization, like the root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When its tip appears, you should wrap around it a piece of lead weighing from one to two drachms, and tie that in place; then leave the lead suspended from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever anything comes out of it to the outside, wrap that in the lead and tie it up.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	But if it extends too far, cut off a piece of it, and wrap up the rest.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it off at the root until it has come out completely.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut it off, it contracts and reenters the flesh; this causes an abscess to occur at that place, and rot, and a bad ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it should be handled gently and extracted little by little until its very end comes out, so that nothing of it remains inside the body; indeed this vein extends outside some people's bodies to a length of five or ten palms.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	He has now arrived because a man left with twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	However, if it happens to you during the hour of your medication: then insert a rod into its hole and perforate it with a long hole, with the body, until all that is in it of matter is evacuated; and apply putrefaction of the place with medicine for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then cure it with the treatment for boils.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein indeed sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the ankle joint, or on the foot itself: and there are multiple openings to it, and a branch comes out of every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Therefore treat it as we have said in the division, and with what has been mentioned before.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	On cutting over worms generated under the skin, which is called Bovine Disease.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter 94.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This disease is called Bovine Disease in a certain region among us: because it often happens to cows, and there is one small worm that is born between the skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it enters the whole body, ascending and descending: and is felt during its walk from limb to limb, until it bursts wherever it bursts on the skin, and exits.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the putrefaction of certain juices.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	As happens with worms and snakes, that is, earthworms, and ascarids in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And it is feared for its harmfulness.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it enters the body and is raised towards the head, and reaches that place, then perhaps it opens there, comes out, and destroys the eye; and this happens many times.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	So if you want to cure him and extract it, then this can only be done when he walks around, and its presence is revealed to the senses.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	It's necessary, therefore, to tie up what is above him and what is below with a strong binding ligature.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut over it and extract it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	But if it is deeply embedded in the flesh and you do not find it, then place a cauterizing iron on the spot until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And greater than that which is feared is its corruption, by which it corrupts the eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If however you see that it has already reached the head near the eye, then bind beneath it the eyebrow with a good ligature.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut over it and extract it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And the patient must use cleansing of his body with medicines that dissolve bad putrid humours.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And he should beware of foods that cause putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	On the operation for the illness of Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Chapter 95.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This illness is called Nakir in our land, and it is a pain that occurs in certain limbs; then it changes from limb to limb.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	I have indeed seen it myself, just as I am telling you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to attend to an ailing woman in certain villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And I found her arm with a small swelling on the vein of the bicep.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after I remained for an hour, I saw one swelling move with a whip, like a worm, ascending to her shoulder faster than could be believed; so that it was as if live silver were running from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	So the pain retreated from that spot and fixed itself on her shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then I sat for an hour, and it rushed into the rest of her body until it reached her other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then she told me that the pain was revolving throughout her entire body, just as I had observed.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I was amazed at the speed of its transformation from limb to limb.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	I had never seen this illness with my eyes in such a manner before.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However I have seen many who experience pain that shifts from limb to limb; and I have not witnessed it with my eyes as I did with this woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think it is anything other than the fact that she was among those from dry villages where the veins were often found to be exposed; and thus this sensation of windiness appeared when it shifted.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that such sensations not appear according to this reasoning among those who are luxurious and whose bodies are moist with concealed veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When you wish to treat it and the patient feels that pain, then if it is visible to your eye as we said, then squeeze above it, and beneath it quickly; and cut over it until that trapped wind comes out; and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If however you do not see it with your eyes, then treat it with body shaking and with that which expels wind, and makes it fart with foul-smelling pills, and pills made from serpent's flesh, and similar things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	On the removal of arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter 96.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows vary according to their kinds, and according to the places in which they fall out of the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	Their variation is because among them are those which have large and small heads, concave and convex.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And among them are those which have three edges.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And among them are those which have barbs.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And among them are those which have stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	But those that fall into the limbs do so in two ways.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	For either the limbs are from the main concave members such as the brain, and heart, and liver, and lungs, and kidneys, and intestines, and bladder, and things similar to them.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When therefore it falls into one of these members and the signs of death which I tell you about later appear to you, then you ought to avoid extracting that arrow from them, for death follows him in whom it is, in many cases.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these bad signs are not evident to you, and the arrow is not hidden deep within the limb, then extract it and treat the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For when an arrow strikes the brain and pierces the bone, exiting towards the membrane that covers the brain, the following signs will occur: severe headache, scotomas, vertigo, redness in the eyes, swelling, reddening of the tongue, spasms, mental confusion, and vomiting bile.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood will exit through the nose or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is cut off, and the voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And from the place of the wound, a white moisture like pus will exit.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And it exits with a moistness similar to that of flesh.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If these signs appear to you, then refrain from treating it, and extract the arrow if it has not exited.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow having struck the heart are that it is near the left nipple, and with it comes a feeling as if it were fixed upon something hard, not empty.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the movement of the arrow is similar to the pulse, and black blood flows from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	Afterwards, it is followed by coldness of the limbs, cold sweat, and fainting.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Therefore, you should know that death has surely descended upon them.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of an arrow having struck the lung is the exit of foamy blood from the wound, and the veins that follow down the neck will swell, and the patient's complexion will change.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	He breathes a great, deep sigh and seeks to draw in cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If the arrow falls upon the diaphragm which is in the chest, then it is near the small ribs; and there will be a great panting with severe pain, together with a sigh; and all the limbs of the shoulders move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if an arrow falls upon the stomach, then perhaps something undigested may come out of the wound.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if an arrow falls into the belly and pierces it, then something of faeces will come out of the wound or the zirb (a looped gut) or a ruptured intestine.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is therefore no hope of cure nor of extracting the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If an arrow falls into the bladder and urine comes out, and something goes from it to the outside, and the pain is stronger below (in the lower parts of the body), then you know that it is a mortal wound.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The remaining parts such as the face, neck, throat, jaw, aid (hyoid bone), spinal vertebrae, wishbone, hip, leg and similar limbs shall be treated according to many different methods; when an arrow has not struck an artery or nerve: and is not a poisoned arrow.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you that I have seen these arrows so that you may judge by it concerning your treatment.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	Which is to say that an arrow fell into the tear duct of a man's eye at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	I therefore extracted it from him on the other side beneath the fat of his ear; and he was cured without any harm to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	I extracted another arrow from the eye fat of a Jew under his lower eyelid; and the arrow was already hidden, and I only found its small end with which it was attached to its wooden shaft: and this was a large arrow from Turkish bows, without ears on its iron tip.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	The Jew therefore healed up, and there was no ill accident befall his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And this was an Arabian arrow, which has ears on its iron tip.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	So I secured it above the wound with two sutures, although by then the arrow was already submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I therefore operated on him with great care until I extracted it; and the Christian healed up.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from the man's belly; we thought that he would die of it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	So after thirty days had passed without any change in his condition, I made a suture over the arrow and then devised a plan to extract it; and the man healed up completely with no ill accident befalling him thereafter.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man with an arrow that had pierced his back; the wound over it was healed up.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	So seven years later, the arrow came out at the root of his hip bone.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	I saw a woman with an arrow that had pierced her belly; the wound over it was healed up and remained so, nor did she suffer any ill effect from its presence: no change came to her condition, and during all her natural functions the woman found no harm in it.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	I saw another man who had an arrow lodged in his face; the wound had healed but remained, causing him little pain; and there were many similar cases like this.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted an arrow from the nose of a man who was one of the king's nobles; it had struck him right between his eyes and then veered off slightly to the right, becoming entirely hidden within.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was called upon to treat him three days after the arrow struck.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	The wound from the arrow had become very constricted.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I therefore tested it with a fine probe but could not feel the arrow; however, he himself did find the puncture and pain beneath his right ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I hoped that this was simply due to the tip of the arrow having pierced him there.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I therefore plastered the area with an ointment possessing both drawing and digestive qualities, trusting that it would form a pustule, revealing to me some sign of the arrow so I could cut above it; however, this did not happen at all.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I thus tended to him with the plaster for many days; yet still no incident occurred that indicated the arrow had followed some course beneath his skin and meanwhile the wound healed over completely: he remained weakened by the extraction, until one day he felt something inside his nose – it was the arrow.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And so he narrated this to me.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I therefore applied a sharp corrosive medicine to the wound for many days until it opened up; and when I probed with my probe again, I felt the fine tip of the arrow adhering to wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the opening of the wound with that sharp medicine until the tip of the arrow appeared visibly to us; and it passed by me with him for about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the wound was enlarged and it became possible for me to introduce forceps into it, and move them without their obeying at the outlet: then I did not cease from sharpening and devising ways over it with devices until one day I began on it a certain device made of forceps according to what will come in form at the end of this chapter, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And indeed physicians judge that the cartilage of the nose is not restorable.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	Therefore I restored it, the wound became consolidated, and the patient was healed with a complete recovery; nor did anything at all harm him.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the nature of the extraction of some arrows: so that you may put it as a rule and a sign over what I have not said.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Since the parts of this art and their distinctions are not covered along with the narration: nor does a book comprehend it, and a prudent craftsman compares little over much: and what is present over what is absent: and he discovers new procedures, and new instruments in dealing with foreign matters that happen to this art.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore that arrows do not come out of the members in which they are fixed except according to two methods.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Either by attracting them from the place through which they entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by opposing from the other side.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which exits where it entered, or is an arrow proceeding through a fleshy area; and it is drawn out, and exits.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	If it does not obey and exit from the hour in which it falls, then you should leave it for a few days until the flesh around it becomes rotten; and its attraction and its exit will ease.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if it is stuck in bone and does not obey you to exit, then leave it for a few days; and repeat with attraction and movement every day until it exits.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If it does not obey you to exit after those days, then you must bore around the arrow in the bone itself from every side with a fine trepan, until the arrows are enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then attract it, and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	But if the arrow is fixed in the skull bone and has already pierced into one of the chambers of the brain, and some of those accidents appear in the patient which I have described; then refrain from attracting the arrow, and leave it until it becomes equal with [the brain] after a number of days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow reaches the sifach, then death is not prolonged for him/her.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed except only in the body of a bone and has not penetrated up to the sifach; and he/she remains unwell for some days, yet none of those accidents befall him/her: then employ skill in attracting the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	But if it is fixed very firmly and does not obey you to be attracted; then apply a trephine around the arrow as I have described to you; then treat the place until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If, however, the arrow is already concealed within the body and hidden from sight, then you must search for it with a probe.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then draw it out with certain instruments suitable for its extraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	But if you cannot [draw it out], because of the tightness of the wound and because of the length of the arrow inside deep down; and there is no bone or nerve or vein in that place: then make an incision over it until the wound is enlarged, making it possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If there are ears by which it is held fast, then free the flesh that has become attached to them from all sides with every means at your disposal; and if it cannot be extracted due to the tearing of the flesh in splitting those ears or twisting them: continue until it comes out.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you are extracting the arrow from whatever location it is in, use hand movements and twisting with the scissors on all sides until you cause it to come out: using ultimate skillfulness so that the arrow does not break during this process making its extraction more difficult for you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you cannot extract it from the first moment onwards, then leave it there for several days until those things around it decay.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then try again; it will be easier due to the loosening from [the decayed flesh]. But if you encounter trouble because of a profuse flow of blood, then do what has been described in its own chapter regarding treatment: and guard your strength against cutting into any veins or nerves or tendons.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	Use every means at your disposal for the extraction of the arrow: and let that be done with ease or tranquility; slowness and strength, as I have described to you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	You must ensure that when you are removing an arrow [sagittam], the patient is positioned according to the angle at which the arrow entered their body.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	As it is more beneficial.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If this is not possible for you, then use whichever of the positions that is feasible.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	An arrow which exits from the opposite side of the body; or if part of it has already come through to the outside; or if one end of the arrow is causing a lump under the skin on the upper side, and you can see this protruding: cut over this area with a knife, and make an incision large enough for you to grasp in forceps.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then pull it; it will be easy now to remove.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If the arrow is stuck to bone, then rotate your hand following the curve of the bone until the arrowhead cuts into it and enlarges its hole; then pull on it.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not, leave the arrow for several days; then try again until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If there is any wood from the arrow shaft still present inside the wound, then push it out with this.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If the shaft has broken and you wish to push it out with an implement, then insert a concave tool inside the wound so that its cavity fits over the tail of the arrow; then use this to push on it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If the arrow is concave, however, then use an instrument which inserts inside it to push on this.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	The arrow will be pushed out by the implement.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the arrow is poisoned, then you must scoop out all of the concave flesh where the venom is; if this is possible for you to do.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then treat it with what is appropriate for that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the arrow has fallen into the chest, or abdomen, or bladder, or side; and is close enough to be reached with a hook, and it's possible for you to cut above it: then cut, and avoid cutting any veins or nerves, and extract it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then sew the wound, if you see fit, and treat it until it is healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of the forceps with which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	The ends should be like the beak of a bird, which are made sharp like iron; when they grasp the arrow, they do not release it.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And many kinds are made from them, large and small, and medium, according to the size of the arrow, its slenderness, and the width and narrowness of the wound.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	Form of the concave driver.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the form of the deaf driver.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the form of the deaf end like a wedge, to ease its entry into the concave arrow, and drive it with that.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The concave driver's end is hollow like a bird's feather; to ease the arrow's entry into it and drive its force.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On the cutting of veins.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter 97.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	There are thirty veins that are regularly opened for bloodletting.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Among these, there are sixteen in the head: two pulsatile veins located behind the ears called 'Herbae', and two arteries visible at the temples; also, there are two veins found in the lacrimal ducts of each eye known as 'Aspicientes'; additionally, there is a vein situated on the midline forehead, and one placed at the tip of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two 'Guidegis', which are found in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	Also, there are two veins that are present on the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And another pair of veins located below on the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	These, then, are the vessels known as 'Algecherichs'.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And there exist two veins situated beneath the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	The veins typically used for bloodletting in the arms consist of five vessels on each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One is the Cephalic vein, positioned on the outside of the forearm; it's commonly referred to as the 'head' or 'capital' vein by laypeople.
Et Fusca.	And then there is the Fusca, or the dark/brownish one.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	The next is the Median vein, composed of branches from both the Basilica and Cephalic veins; it's commonly known as the 'body' or 'trunk' vein by laypeople.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	Following is the Basilica, found on the inside of the arm; it's also known as the 'Titillicar'.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	Laypeople call this the 'belly' or 'abdominal' vein.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the tendon of the arm, which is located above the wrist: it is the one that is bled and appears over the thumb with a clear manifestation.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the Salvatella: it is the vein that lies between the ring finger and little finger, and has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	In the leg and foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is the one that lies beneath the thumb's curve on the side of the forearm.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is the Saphenous vein, which lies at the heel on the inner side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the Nesse Vein, which is located at the heel on the lateral side.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	In the other leg there are three veins similar to these.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	Regarding venesection of two veins behind the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The venesection of two veins behind the ears is helpful for old catarrh, headaches, facial swelling and long-standing head ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	The method of venesection should be as I describe it.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	The patient's head should be shaved, and their occipital region rubbed at the site of the two veins with a rough cloth using vigorous friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the patient should tightly bind their neck with a cord until the two veins become visible.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	Their locations are behind the ears, in the two hollows of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Feel for them with your finger, and where you detect their pulse beneath your fingertip, there make a mark with an ink-soaked swab.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the lancet, which is called the 'Incidens.'
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then introduce it beneath the vein into the skin until you reach the tip of the lancet.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then lift your hand with the vein and skin upwards, and cut the vein along with the skin using the Incidens.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be equal to that of two joined fingers, or around this amount: and make as much blood come out as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then compress it with small bandages, and leave it until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And already at the beginning of this book was described the incision of such things, as well as their cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	On the lancet used for puncturing two arteries during seizures.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	Indeed the puncturing of two arteries in the temples is beneficial for an old headache; an evil sore, and frequent eye-ache; as well as a superfluous flow of sharp matter into the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And here is how you puncture them, as I describe it to you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The patient must hold their neck very tense until two veins become visibly apparent and their pulsation is felt beneath your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then mark these with the encaustic pen.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then lift the skin above the vein upwards with your index finger, introduce the Incidens underneath and then raise the vein upwards.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut it like you did with the other two veins; and make as much blood run out as is necessary for you.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then release the patient's constriction and place your finger over the vein for one hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	After that, place cotton and poultices over it, and tightly bind it with a strong compression; leave it until it heals.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And now there has already been a reminder of those things, their incision, and their extraction at the beginning of this book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	Regarding the venesection of the frontal vein after the venesection of the cephalic vein.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	However, the indication for the venesection of the frontal vein is after the venesection of the cephalic vein, for old facial diseases; and for headaches, swelling; and foul ulcers.
