Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	Then he should be content with his food, cool vegetables, and the meat of birds and kids; avoid wine, fatty meats, and foods that fill the veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	Until you are safe from hot inflammation and no longer fear the discharge of matter to the limb then let the sick person return to their original diet, with which they are accustomed.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	When the broken bone begins to heal, it is necessary that the patient be fed nourishing food with much nutriment, heavy, thick and viscous; such as foods made from cooked wheat with water, and rice, heads, feet, and stomachs of fowl, eggs, and fresh fish: also coarse wine and similar things.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	For with this regimen the clotting of the fracture occurs more quickly and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	And know that broken bones, when they are in men who are in the first stage of old age and decrepit, it is not possible for them to be strengthened and consolidated according to their nature always, because of the desiccation of their limbs: but those parts which remain of them at the end [of life] become hardened and strengthen like bones of young children.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	However nature applies to the broken bone from all parts some substance similar to glue which has thickness, by which it adheres and binds itself together until they are cemented to each other, and bound firmly together, until it returns finally to its former strength and firmness, until nothing hinders it from performing its functions: and for this reason it is necessary that you feed the patient nourishing food in which there is weight, viscosity, and thickness as we have said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	And know that the types of fractures are diverse, according to the diversity of limbs; for a fracture of the leg is different from a fracture of the head-bone; and a fracture of the chest-bone is different from a fracture of the back bone: likewise all other limbs differ one from another. And I have come with a recollection of every kind of fracture set forth in its own Chapter distinct from others.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	And the types of bone fractures also differ within themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	Since it becomes an arched fracture, besides which accidents occur in the stars.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	And sometimes it becomes a fracture along the length of the bone; and its fractures are splintered, that is, stars, and extensions resulting from this, as in a reed when it's cut with a knife for writing.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	And they do not extend; and it is a fracture with wound and separation at the head, and there is a small crack-like fracture.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	And for each type there is a specific skill or tool required for its restoration; this will be discussed later, divided by the areas of the body.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	And from where the bone fracture is known, its curvature and prominence are seen; its appearance to the senses, and its sound when you press it with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	When there is no apparent curvature in its place, nor a sound upon your touch when you touch the bone with agitation, and the patient does not feel much pain; then there is no fracture here, but rather possibly a curvature or small crack - therefore one should not move it with the hand and compression at all, but instead put over it some medicines which will be recalled later, appropriate to the place; then bind it tightly with fine bandages.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And you should know that when the place is arched and split in two, besides splintering, yet all parts are removed from their counterparts; then it's necessary for you to begin your work on its straightening at once before a hot inflammation develops.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	But if a hot inflammation does develop, then leave it for several days until the inflammation subsides.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	Then it is equally possible to adjust it according to whichever method, depending on its softness and ingenuity.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	And you should know that its restoration and adjustment are easier than with bone, where there occur fractures.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	Then tighten it according to how you will remember it.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	If there are fractures in the bone, then it is necessary to extend this broken limb from two sides, if it is a hand or foot; or with one hand, if it is a small limb; or with two cords, or with a cord and a hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	And your position should be such that you place the limb over an equal spot, according to its natural shape, until when the parts of the broken limb are extended; then try to bring back those additions with all your ingenuity and in any way possible to their respective places: and beware, based on your strength, lest it happen on the weak through your operation some pain, nor injury: and try, according to your strength, to fit one of the two bones with its partner, according to better shapes.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	And it is necessary at that hour, that you try and touch it with your hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	If therefore you see something different there, correct it, and adjust it according to the amount of your strength.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	And beware excessive stretching, and strong pressure, as many fools do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	For they often cause to happen through their operation a hot abscess, or contraction in the limb: as we have already seen it from their operations many times.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	Then fasten after adjustment, and proper operation, and the setting of that limb, and rest, and tranquility: and advise the weak person about it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	And make it so that he does not move in the hour of his watches, and of his sleep at his turning, and his agitation, and at his excretion, and all his movements with his final strength.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	And to avoid having the position of the limb in a position that results in pain.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	That is, because when he feels pain or injury in the positioning of the limb, then it must be changed to another position where he does not feel pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	And take care with him so that his position is equal and straight; so that the limb does not become twisted when restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the fracture of the broken limb is as I describe it.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	You should know that broken limbs differ according to their size, magnitude, and shape.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	So those that are small among them, such as the arm, finger, and jawbone, and things similar to these, then there must be a soft, thin cloth wrapping.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	But those that are large among them, such as the thigh and leg, it is necessary that there be a broad, hard wrapping around them.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	Because a broad bandage connects the large limb and binds it from all sides of the fracture equally, so that no part is left uncovered.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	Then, after your evacuation from the area around the fracture, start to apply a suitable ointment with soft lint on the place of the fracture itself.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	Then begin to wrap the bandage over the place of the fracture itself with three or four turns, according to what the limb deserves; and squeeze your hand a little bit with the bandage.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	Go with him to the upper part above the site of the fracture, and bind it less tightly than you bound the fractured site.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	Extend yourself with the roll above the site of the fracture for some time, and gradually loosen the binding until you get hold of something large from the healthy place.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	Then take another bandage and wrap it around the fractured site with bindings.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	Afterward, go with the binding to the lower part below the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	And your action should be in tightening the binding and loosening it as we said about the first upper binding.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	Then place between the bindings some soft linen or cloth to even out any curvature of the fracture if there is such a curvature; and if not, do not put anything into it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	Then wrap another bandage over the top of that.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	Afterward, apply over these bindings warm compresses that are slightly off-centre if there is no swelling nor hot abscess at the site.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	But if there is swelling or an abscess, then place on it what will remove the abscess and reduce the swelling; and leave it on for several days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	Then bind compresses over them at that point.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	And the compresses should be made from the hollowed halves of wide reeds that have been skillfully stripped and shaped; or they may be fashioned instead from wood used to make wickerwork such as pine or willow, which is also known as palm branches, or rushes; and every compress should be the same size with this shape and form.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	However, it is necessary that the star-shaped instrument which is placed over the wound be somewhat thicker and wider than the other instruments; and the length of the instrument should be according to the size and smallness of the limb.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	Then tighten over the star-shaped instrument with another cord, in the same way as the first tightening.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	Then bind on top with threads off-center, as we said about the tightening; and it should be that your binding is over the site of the fracture more; and the further the binding is from the fracture, the less tight it should be.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	And it is necessary that the threads be of moderate thickness and fineness, and they should be made from soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	Because if the threads are thick, as I have seen in the work of fools who use their own twisted linen cords, it is a great mistake; for the binding slips with them beyond repair.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	And fine threads also are not suitable; for you will not achieve with them the tightening that you wish to have.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	And it should not be less than a finger's breadth between one star-shaped instrument and another.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	If the patient is injured by the ends of the instruments after the binding in healthy places, then place under them some soft tow or crimson wool until nothing is damaged by it.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	When there is a fracture with a wound, and it happens that there is a break in the skin, I shall come back to this point specifically in Chapter 2.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	And you should know that not every broken limb needs to be bound with star-shaped instruments from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	For it is because the limb when it is large, you must not place stars on it until after five days, or seven, or more, according to your judgment regarding avoidance of a hot abscess.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	And this is the method of plasters with which the ancients restored those that are placed on a fracture and dislocation.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	The method of a common shortened plaster, restoring fractures, suitable for many constitutions, especially women and children: since it is one which neither excessive heat nor cold overcome.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	And it is, as you take from the dust of the mill, and it is the flour which hangs on the walls of the mill by the movement of the millstone: and make it like that, except that you sieve it with a strainer along with the white of an egg: and put its preparation neither thick nor thin.
Deinde utere eo.	Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	The method of another plaster that restores fracture, and dislocation, and twisting.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	Take alum, and laudanum, and acacia, and enula, and mugwort: and juice of all, of myrrh each 10 ounces, and aloe both 5 ounces, and aletheel 20 ounces; pound everything, and sieve them, and mix with water of altheel: or with white of an egg if the patient's constitution is heated.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	Then use this plaster.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	For it is of good composition, restores broken bones quickly, and suits many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	The method of another plaster which also suits fractures and twists.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	Take mugwort, mallow, and white poplar, of each 10 ounces of myrrh, 5 ounces of aloe, 6 ounces of acacia, and 20 ounces of Armenian boulder. All these should be crushed thoroughly, then sifted, mixed with water or egg white, and administered.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	Method for a plaster to be applied to joints, and bones separated from their places: this soothes the accidental pain of them, bone dislocation, and fracture.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	Let newly shorn wool be taken, soaked in vinegar and boiled oil, then placed on the affected area.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	This plaster has no restorative power but is good for soothing hot abscesses; it specifically expels pain.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	Method of a plaster that restores a broken bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	Take leaves of the mulberry fig tree and wild poppies; grind both together to form a plaster from each.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	Method of an abbreviated plaster for the restoration of a broken bone; use when you wish to resolve any remaining abscess residue.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	Take white poplar root, chamomile, violet flowers, and herb flour, all in equal parts; grind them together then mix with wine unless the limb is warm.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	If it is warm then mix instead with moist coriander water or just water, and use this.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	Method of another stronger plaster for resolving harder abscesses when restoring a limb than the first method mentioned previously.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	Take white poplar root, flax seed, paeony, fenugreek, ginseng, violet flowers and chamomile, all in equal parts; grind them together then mix with willow water or fresh water or wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	The whole of it according to the warmth of the member, and the calm of its heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	Hippocrates however did not say in his book that anything should be placed on the broken member when restoring it, except for a poultice made of clay and oil; nothing else; and he described it as being midway between coarseness and fineness.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	Galen thought that things should be placed on the broken member when restoring it which dry out heat, such as myrrh, aloe and frankincense, and similar things to those we have described.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	Recipe for an ointment which helps with injury and pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	Take equal parts of mallow, chickpeas, human hair cuttings or bird feathers, althea root and salt; pound them up, sieve them through a fine mesh, and make an ointment from them.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	The amount of time for which the binding should stay in place is such that you should then remove it only after considering whether there's no pain or itching and the broken bone has not moved from its position; if these things are so, don't remove it for many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	But if there's severe itching or disturbing pain or inflammation at the site, then hurry and remove it within the hour; take off the ointment from them; get a soft cloth or a soft sea sponge, dampen it with water, immerse that in warm water, and wash the place with it until the itching stops and the pain eases.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	Then let the member rest for an hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	After that place over it a wadded piece of felt soaked in vinegar and oil or rosewater oil; bind this on top of it for one night until you're sure about the hot abscess, and the inflammation of the member has gone down, and its pain is removed.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	Then repeat this to a fine structure and apply a small plaster; do not tighten it with your first binding, but make the finer ones until it is healed.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	If you see that the abscess, redness, pain, swelling and all other symptoms have already disappeared completely and there is need for a plaster and binding, then repeat as was done initially.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	If nothing happens to the limb among those we have said, then do not remove it unless after three days or four or five or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	And when it is released after twenty days, according as you see the release of the limb, as we have said until such time that fracture adheres and flesh coagulates over it: then add also to your binding more than your first binding in entirety; and increase also in quantity of food by the amount previously prescribed.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	If however you see the place of fracture already dried and become more attenuated than it should be then know that nutrition is prevented from reaching it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	Scrub it with warm water near to every place where you release it and let this be done for all three days; also relieve the binding somewhat.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	By this method therefore nutrition flows to the limb and it is healed swiftly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	But that which foolish physicians do to restore a limb with another bone when the first is not restored as it should be and is restored crookedly, this error on their part and great fear; if it were right the Ancients would have said so in their books and acted accordingly.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	And I have not seen any traces of them anywhere at all, and it is better that it should not be done.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	# On accidental injuries to the head.
Caput III.	Chapter 3.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	The types of fractures are diverse, and their shapes are many; and its causes are distinctive.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	For there is a fracture which occurs from being struck with a sword: and the blow takes away the entire bone until it reaches the marrow, which lies under the bone, as an axe does to wood; and for that reason this type of fracture is called axial.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	Or the sword strikes some part of a bone and cuts its surface but does not penetrate the cut to its end; and this type of fracture is called *Kalaan*, that is, complete levation.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	And it is the wound of two fractures, either large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	And there is a fracture which is comminution or crushing; and its cause is being struck by a stone, or falling onto a rock, or something similar.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	And this fracture is also either penetrating, which approaches the membrane that lies under the bone; or it is on the surface of the bone; and it is a wound of these two fractures, either small or large.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	And there is a fracture which is concealed within the bone as fine as a hair; and it is a small crack, and for that reason this type of fracture is called *capillaris*.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	And there is a fracture which occurs from a fall or being struck by a stone, or something similar, that causes a piece of the bone to enter inwards towards the internals, and creates a concavity; as happens with air bladders, when they are struck, and part of them enters inward.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	Indeed, it happens mostly on the moist bones' heads, such as those of children's.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	And all these types of fractures occur separately, and I shall come with a reminder of that whole thing in its place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	And we recognize all these types of fractures through an examination on it and by investigating them with probes and removing the corrupted flesh that is upon them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	The hairy type is recognized by this fact; it is detected on the bone and cleaned off, then wiped with caustic medicine over it because indeed a fracture shows up black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	However, when treating a fracture, first consider the patient's condition; if you see among his symptoms any that clearly indicate fearfulness, such as vomiting and diarrhea, fainting, loss of consciousness, loss of voice, and chills, high fever, bulging eyes with redness in them, or similar terrifying conditions found in many disorders, by all means it will not heal. And if you see non-terrifying symptoms and hope for recovery, then begin the treatment process.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	That is, if an injured person comes to you when he was first wounded and the injury happened during winter days, then it's necessary that you pay attention to removing bone pieces before fourteen days have passed since his wounding according to all disorder scenarios.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	And if the injury occurred during summer days, then you should hasten to remove bone pieces before seven days have passed lest soft tissues underneath them become corrupted and those frightening symptoms we mentioned occur.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	If the bone fracture has already reached membranes touching brain matter and is accompanied by fragmentation and tearing of flesh, then you must cut away any broken or torn pieces as I shall describe to you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	And it is necessary that you shave the head of the wounded person; and expose the bone according to whichever way is possible for you; and following the shape of the wound, and what is light on the patient.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	If it happens to you that during the exposure of the bone there is a flow of blood or a hot abscess: then oppose this with what is appropriate.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	And you should fill the place with cloths soaked in wine and rose oil; and let the wound rest until the abscess is settled, and be sure of no flow of blood.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	Then begin treating the bone, and its removal.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	And this is done in one of two ways.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	The first way is to cut the bone with an Incision Knife of fine steel; and this is its form.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	Apply another knife, slightly wider than the Incision Knife, after the former; and this is its form.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	Then apply yet another knife, wider still than the previous one.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	The second way is to have a set of different knives, some wider than others and some shorter; they should be very sharp at their tips and made of iron or steel: you can ease the striking on the knife to avoid shaking the head and harming it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	If however the bone is strong and hard: then you should bore around it before applying any of the knives with a Trephine, which is what they are called because it does not pierce through to that which is behind the bone, since its tip is round like a pin and a small circle prevents submerging and piercing the depth of the bone.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	You should take a great number of drills from these, each one appropriate to the thickness of the bone, until you have for every part of the skull a suitable drill, whose acutely pointed end is in length and breadth proportioned according to the thickness of that part of the skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	These are three types of drills or trepans.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	However, the quality of boring round the circumference of a broken bone is to place the drill upon the bone and turn it with your fingers until you know that the bone has been penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	Then shift the drill to another spot, and place within every aperture a roller equal in thickness to a finger-joint or thereabouts.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	Next cut with a knife what is between every aperture in the bone; and make it thinner than you can over that part from one end to another as lightly as possible, as we have said, until you remove the bone either by hand or with some other of those instruments which you have made ready for this purpose such as pincers or delicate scissors.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	And take care with all caution that the drill or knife touches no part of the brain.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	When therefore you have bored round the bone and separated it from the brain without injuring it so that it remains continuous with it, and drawn it out, it is necessary to smooth and trim evenly with another instrument like a knife what part of it remains in the bone.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	However, it should be thinner and more delicate than other knives.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	But if anything of the little bones or membranes remains then take them up easily with what you have among your instruments for this purpose.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	Then treat the wound afterwards with dressings and ointments as we have described.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	And another method of operation is easy, completely remote from danger: this was described by Galen, and he praised it highly; and these are his words.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	It is necessary for you first of all to begin by exposing that portion of the bone where the fracture is more violent and obvious: until when you have exposed it, and placed under it this end of the Lenticular knife, which is of this shape.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	And the Lenticular part, being smooth, cuts nothing; and its pointed part on either side of it tapering to a point as you see: so that the Lenticular part shall be applied against this saw with its cutting edge acute towards the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	Then strike upon the knife from one side with a small mallet until you cut through the bone completely as it turns; and you may be sure that there will happen to it no accident which you fear at all.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	And if the surgeon were not more stupid than other men, and less acquainted with it, nor sleeping, then should there remain any part of the membrane attached to the bone in certain places, he would cut it away from that with the end of this same Lenticular knife, and free it from that easily.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	It is freed from it without injury and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	And if the fracture of the bone does not penetrate to the membrane, and what is torn away from the bone is its surface, while irregularities and fine splinters remain in it; then you must scrape off that irregularity, and root out those splinters with fine scrapers of which you have prepared a number of different sizes, so as to be able to apply from them more suitable and proper ones in every place, according as the operation leads you, and the fractured bone and its shape.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	And it is necessary that you hold your razor at an angle wider than that which first cuts the bone.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	Then use the finer one after it.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	And do not stop doing this continuously until you reach the point of administering the thinnest and finest [one].
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	In each of the remaining small hairline cracks and fine fractures, it is necessary that you administer care according to what leads to its correction.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	And it is a matter that is not hidden from anyone who has any interest in this art, and has stood over what we have written, and shown in large fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	But if a piece of skin is found to be retained when you remove the bone: then it is necessary that you take a piece of linen cloth according to the size of the wound, and immerse it in rose oil, and place it over the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	Then take another piece of cloth that is doubled or tripled, and immerse it in wine and rose oil, and place it over the first cloth; and make it as light as you can so as not to burden the wound.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	Then apply above it a wide bandage: and do not tighten it unless to the extent that it holds the wound; and leave it in place for one day or two days until you are certain about the warm abscess.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	Then remove the bandage and apply afterward medicines with which excessive dryness is superfluous; such as lily roots, herb flour, incense powder, aristolochia, and similar things to them: and it is useful that you make from these medicines a powder that is powdered onto the wound like they are dry.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	And universally administer to it all medicine that has the property of cleansing and does not sting.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	And ensure that according to your skill the wound is clear during its healing process; there should be no greasy stains nor any dirt within it.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	Nor should you allow pus to gather there at all; for when pus gathers over the brain's membrane it corrupts and rots it, and a great deal of harm befalls the sick person afterwards: this can already happen with skull sores if the bone is cleansed but care of it is neglected, leaving blackness on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	So consider then that if any of the conditions we have mentioned befall a sick person you may know for certain it is extremely harmful.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	And if blackness does not occur unless caused by the medicine applied to it and this is in the power of that medicine to produce such blackening: then you should take one part honey, three parts rose oil, and dip a linen cloth into them.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	Then apply this to the sore; afterwards treat it with appropriate healing spices until it is cured.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	On resetting a broken nose:
Caput IIII.	Chapter 4.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	You should know that only the two upper parts of a nose break together or one of them: since it is made up of two bones; for its lower part is cartilage and so breaks neither but suffers instead abrasion, twisting, and creases.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	If one of the two parts breaks you should insert a little finger into the nose's hole and with your index finger and thumb equally align the broken part until the nose returns to its normal shape: this must be done skilfully yet gently.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	And beware, lest through your operation that pain befall the sick person.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	If the fracture is in the upper part of the nose and does not reach it with your finger: then you should make a splint for it using a small piece of wood.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	But if the fracture is in two parts, then make a splint for it like that one and hurry with its restoration on the first day of the fracture, if possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	And if not, then after seven or ten days when the swelling is warm.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	Next, insert a linen thread into the end of the nose, if the fracture is in one part; or insert two threads if the fracture is in two parts; and let the thread be of such thickness as to fill the nostril.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	And some of the ancient restorers said to pour butter over the threads and change them every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	That however does not seem right to me; rather it should be that the linen thread is dipped in egg white mixed with flour from a mill.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	Then leave the threads until the bone is firm and the cartilage hardens.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	And sometimes a goose feather is inserted into the nose instead of the linen thread after it is wrapped in soft cloth; and this holds the broken nose more firmly so that the sick person is not prevented from breathing.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	And this thing is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	If you wish, do that; and if you wish, use the threads.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	If a hot abscess occurs on the nose again while you are operating, apply to the nose a plaster with a kerchief or with a cotton wool pad soaked in rose oil, or with a small amount of dyakylon.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	If a hot abscess does not occur, then you should apply plasters made with sesame flour and powdered incense mixed with egg white.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	Next, place on it a soft rag made of tow, and do not bind the nose with anything at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	If the bones of the nose are broken in a minor fracture or shattered, then you should cut it open above this and remove them with the appropriate instruments.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	Then suture the incision and take care of it so that it heals and becomes firm with appropriate plasters or ointments.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	If there is a wound between the nose bones, then you should treat it with linen cloths and insert into it a leaden cannula until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	On the restoration of the lower jaw when it is shattered.
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	When the lower jaw is shattered and its fracture is not accompanied by a wound, look then to see if it is fractured on the outside only, and has not been broken into two parts, and treat it for the inside (of the mouth): then its treatment is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	If its fracture is on the right side, you should insert your left index finger into the injured person's jawbone; similarly, if the fracture is in the left jawbone, then insert the index finger of your right hand; and push with it the swelling of the fracture inward from outside with ease by your other hand from the inner part of the displaced bone, and align it.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	If the jawbone fracture has already separated into two, then you must administer an extension from both sides, following the straight line, until it is possible to achieve alignment.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	If there is already loosening or breaking of the teeth, then bind those you hope will remain with gold wire or silver wire, or silk thread.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	Then place a poultice over the broken jawbone.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	Then place over it a doubled cloth, and put on the cloth a large flat splint, or an equal piece of leather, matching the length of the jawbone.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	Then bind it from above with bandages as prepared for you, and apply the splint appropriately until it is not destroyed; and instruct the patient to remain calm and still; and give them soft food that can be sucked or sipped.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	However, if you think the shape is changing somehow then hasten to remove it on day three.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	Then correct the deformity with poultices of bran flour and white of egg or sesame meal after you remove the poultice; and put a soft wool pad over the poultice.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	While the poultice remains attached to it, and there is no alteration in the position of the bone, leave it be without removing until it heals; or bind the fracture again.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	Many times this fracture is bound for three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	If meanwhile a hot abscess appears then administer that which we have spoken of many times for its reduction until the abscess is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	And if there is a fracture with a wound, consider it.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	Now if the fragment has already separated from the bone, or is very small: then you should be careful here to remove those fragments of splinters along with what suits you best for their removal using the instruments.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	If however, the wound opening is narrow, then widen it with a lancet according to what you judge necessary.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	Then when you have removed the splinters and none remain, either close up the wound if it is wide; or if not, put on it a plaster appropriate for such a wound, and apply flesh-forming ointment until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	On the restoration of a fork when broken.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	The fork is broken most frequently from the front part of the arm bone, and its fracture occurs according to one of three ways.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	Or it breaks and separates into two parts without any splinters appearing; this is easier to restore.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	Or such that there are splinters in the bone; this is more difficult to restore.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	Or such that it has fractured with an accompanying wound.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	The procedure in such a case when there is fracture without an accompanying wound is to have two assistants present: one should hold the support that follows a broken fork, and the other should extend the neck towards whichever side.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	Then equalise the fracture with your fingers until it is of a form that suits its shape; and there should be no prominence nor depression within it.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	If you need more extension, then it is necessary that you place beneath the patient's ticklish area a sphere made of cloth or wool; and let its size be according to your needs; extend and raise the fork, and shorten the sphere with your hand until the fracture is reduced as required.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	If you cannot pull the end of the fork outwards because it has gone too deep, then the patient must lie on their back with a pillow under their shoulder and the assistant should press down on the patient's shoulder until the head of the fork is raised up; then straighten the fracture and adjust it with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	If you feel a splinter in the fork and it moves around, then you must cut open that spot and remove the splinter with ease.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	If it is retained within the bone, then use your knife which you have prepared for this purpose to make an incision over it after you have placed beneath the fork a protector made of wood or iron; and this is the instrument for safeguarding the nerves.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	It resembles a spoon which has no hollow.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	Its width should be according to the size of the bone you need it for, and its slenderness.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	Its length should also be according to what is possible for the operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	And it has two ends as you see; one end is wide and the other slender.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	If the wound you made when extracting the splinter of bone is wide and you fear it from an abscess with pus, then sew together the two lips of the wound with a suture.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	And if the rupture is small or you fear a hot abscess: then fill the wound with cloths and soft dressings according to the size of the wound opening.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	If a hot abscess occurs, then dip a cloth in rose oil, vinegar, and wine, and place it on top of the abscess.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	However, if there is a bone fracture without any wound or break, you should place a plaster made of flour and egg white on the bone.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	And put soft oakum on top of it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	Then place a ball under the armpit if necessary.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	Take a bloodletting cup, which is long and has a width of one palm or thereabouts.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	Then place a doubled soft pad on top of the oakum and plaster.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	Take a disk of thin wood whose width is three fingers and its length likewise.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	Then wrap it in cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	Wrap the cloth with the disk at the bloodletting cup site over the fracture and joint.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	Then place the bloodletting cup over the fracture as it was rolled up and wrap it around his neck, under the healthy armpit, and under the injured armpit, pulling it taut across all parts so that you can see how the bone is held by the plaster: and be careful not to cover or obscure any part of the broken bone with the disk.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	And for this reason, it is necessary that you examine the patient every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	As many times as the ligament is softened, and you see that the dislocation has already been removed; then correct it, and tighten the ligament.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	Then put the patient's leg on top of his other leg, and place under his testicle near his scrotum a small pillow at night, so that it elevates his testicle from its side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	Therefore, the fracture of the furcula is elevated by the elevation of the shoulder.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	Or bandage his arm to his neck; and do not loosen the bandage unless an accident occurs at this place due to itching or from a pustule, until twelve days have passed.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	Then renew the plaster, if you see its face becoming visible.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	And add some more bandage material to the tightness of it, and leave it there until it is restored and coagulated.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	Indeed, the fracture of the furcula is tightly bound and takes a long time to heal, typically twenty-eight days; although sometimes it can be less for some people.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	On the restoration of the fracture of the spatula...
Caput VII.	Chapter 7.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	It is rare for the spatula to break; but when it does happen, the break occurs over a large area of it; and only the edges will be broken.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	So when a break occurs to it, and the spatula is broken through its middle; but you would only know about this by feeling for it; then prepare accordingly based on how bad the fracture is.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	And restore it to its natural shape in every way possible with your skill.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	Then place over the wound mill dust with egg white, soft lint, and a small pad of doubled cloth on top.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	Then place over it a wide plaster made from thin wood, matching the size of the entire spatula or slightly larger.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	If there is any depression under the plaster in certain areas of the spatula, then fill that depression evenly with soft lint until the plaster lies level.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	Then bind it firmly with long bandages of linen, applying them tightly to secure the plaster in place so that it cannot be moved.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	Check the bindings every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	Whenever the bandages become loose, tighten them and adjust the plaster if it has shifted from its position; let the patient lie on their healthy side.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	The wound will heal within twenty or twenty-five days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	Once this number of days is complete, untie the bandages; you will then be secure.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	For it is made up of bones whose fracture or dislocation is not feared.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	If, however, a piece of bone protrudes through the skin and causes irritation, then cut it off above that point and remove it.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	And do what we said for the fracture of the collarbone resulting from an abscess with inflammation, if anything similar should happen.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	# On Restoring the Fracture of the Chest Bone #
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8.
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	The chest sometimes breaks in the middle, and this rarely happens.
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	Its limbs indeed break and shatter most often because of its accidents.
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.	When his middle breaks, which leans towards the lower parts, and it causes him severe pain, with difficulty breathing and coughing; he may also vomit blood, and a concavity is apparent in the broken bone, and this is not hidden from sense perception. The patient should be laid on their back, with pillows placed between their shoulder blades to support them.
Deinde preme humeros eius, et aggrega costas a duabus partibus uel lateribus cum manibus: et subtiliare in aequatione eius, secundum omnem modum quo possibile est illud et conuenit, donec redeat figura ossis, secundum quod oportet.	Then press his shoulders and bring the ribs together from both sides with your hands; then realign it carefully in every way possible until its shape returns as it should be.
Deinde pone super ipsum emplastrum et stuppam, et pone desuper astellam ex tabula subtili ex salice, aut chalingi, et ex eis similibus in leuitate, postquam tu inuoluis eam in panno.	Afterwards apply a plaster and linen bandage to him; then place on top of this a willow or hazel board, and similar ones as light as possible after you have wrapped them in cloth.
Deinde subtiliare in ligando eam super os fractum, ut non remoueatur: et uade cum ligatura secundum rotunditatem ad dorsum aliquotiens, et stringe ipsum strictura decenti.	Then bandage it tightly above the broken bone so that it is not moved; and run the bandage around its back several times according to the roundness of its shape, tightening it with an appropriate bandage.
Deinde considera ligaturam in omni hora, et quotienscumque mollificatur, stringe eam: et si necessitas eius prouocat ad solutionem eius apud pruritum, uel corrosionem quae accidit in loco, aut dolorem, aut apostema: tunc propera, et solue eam, et eradica emplastrum, et rectifica quod accidit cum modo curationis eius.	Check the bandage every hour and whenever it loosens, tighten it; if need arises due to itching or corrosion occurring at that site, or pain, or abscess: then you should quickly loosen the bandage and remove the plaster, then rectify what has occurred according to how his treatment goes.
Deinde reduc emplastrum, si uides ad illud faciem: et annecte ei stricturam, donec sanetur.	If you see its face swelling then replace the plaster, and attach to it a bandage until he is healed.
¶ De restauratione Costarum, quando franguntur.	The restoration of ribs, when they are broken.
Caput IX.	Chapter 9.
Scias, quod Costarum fractura non accidit, nisi in locis grossis quae sequuntur dorsum, et ex extremitatibus earum ab anteriori parte.	You know that a rib fracture does not occur except in the thick places which follow the spine and from their ends on the front side.
Et non accidit eis attritio, nisi propterea, quia sunt cartilaginosae.	And they do not suffer abrasion except because they are cartilaginous.
Et cognitio ipsius non occultatur sensui apud inquisitionem cum digitis.	The knowledge of this is not hidden from the sense of touch during examination with the fingers.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, ut aeques fracturam cum digitis secundum modum possibilem, donec aequetur figura, secundum quod oportet.	And its restoration is done in this way: equally treat the fracture with your fingers according to what is possible until the shape becomes equal to what it should be.
Deinde emplastra, et stringe os fractum cum astella, si indiget illo.	Then apply plasters and strap the broken bone with splints if needed.
Et si fractura Costarum est decliuis ad interiora: tunc accidit infirmo dolor uehemens, et punctura, sicut punctura illa quae accidit illi qui habet pleuresim: propterea, quod os pungit uelamen, et etiam ei accidit difficultas anhelitus, et tussis, et uomitus sanguinis multi: et haec est difficilis curationis.	And if a rib fracture is sloping towards the interior then the patient suffers intense pain and stabbing sensations as with the stabbing sensation that occurs in someone who has pleurisy because the bone is piercing the lung and also he suffers difficulty breathing, coughing and vomiting of much blood; and this is difficult to treat.
Et iam ingeniati sunt antiqui in ea cum ingeniis multis: et ex eis sunt qui dicunt, ut ponas cibos infirmi qui generent inflammationem et uentositatem, ut inflammetur uenter, et extendatur, et impellatur fractura ad exteriora.	And the ancients have devised many devices for this and some of them say that you should give foods to the patient which generate inflammation and wind so that the stomach becomes inflamed and extended and pushes the fracture outwards.
Nos uero abhorremus, ut non fiat caussa uelox ad faciendum apostema calidum, si non accidit.	We however avoid that there is a swift cause for the formation of a hot abscess if it does not happen.
Si autem iam accidit, tunc addit in eo.	But if it has already happened then you should add to it.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: ponatur super locum uentosa, deinde sugatur cum fortitudine, et est similius ratiocinationi.	And some of them said: place a windy substance on the spot then suck it with strength and this is similar to reasoning.
Verumtamen timetur, quod attrahat uentosa superfluitates ad locum, propter dispositionem debilitatis.	However, it is feared that it may draw superfluous humors to the site due to its weakness.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: oportet ut cooperiatur locus cum lana quae iam submersa est in oleo calido: et ponantur puluilli inter Costas, donec impleatur: ut sit ligatura aequalis quando inuoluis eam secundum rotunditatem.	And some of them said: it is necessary that the site be covered with wool which has already been soaked in warm oil; and let pads be placed between the ribs, until it is full, so that there may be an equal binding when you wrap it according to its roundness.
Deinde curetur infirmus curatione pleuresis ex cibo et medicina.	After that, the patient should be treated with treatment for pleurisy from food and medicine.
Quod si coartat infirmum res uehemens, quam non tolerat, et os pungit uelamen punctura laedente, et timemus super infirmum: tunc oportet, ut scindamus super locum, et detegamus a Costa fracta.
